XML.Hansard-Body: The Legislative Assembly met at 9.30 am.
Mr Speaker (Hon. John Mickel, Logan) read prayers and took the chair.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Speaker’s Statements
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: I remind the House that the annual general meeting of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Queensland branch will be held in the Legislative Assembly chamber today at 1 pm.

Mr SPEAKER: I have received a letter from the member for Maroochydore seeking an amendment to standing orders as to how petitions are tabled in parliament. The member correctly points out that often members will present paper petitions for tabling or sponsor e-petitions, even though they do not personally agree with their contents, on the basis that it is the right of citizens to expect their elected representatives to present or sponsor petitions on their behalf. The member is concerned that, unfortunately, the media and members of the public do not always understand that a member, in presenting or sponsoring a petition, is fulfilling a representative role and does not necessarily support or endorse the substance of the petition.

The member suggests that an additional method for ensuring petitions are tabled in parliament be devised, whereby the public can lodge petitions for tabling directly with the Clerk. I have directed that this correspondence be copied to each member of the Standing Orders Committee for consideration.

In the interim, however, I believe that it is appropriate for me to state that I have considerable sympathy for the member’s concerns about the misunderstanding by the media and members of the public about the member’s role in the petitioning process. I wish to place on record that a member is elected to represent their entire electorate. Sometimes this entails making representations or actioning matters which the member may not personally or ideologically be in agreement with. One role of a member is to present paper petitions or sponsor e-petitions from their constituents--even if they do not agree with their contents.

Mr SPEAKER: I wish to advise the House of three significant events that will soon be held here at Parliament House. On Monday, 23 November, I will launch the Speaker’s Christmas Tree Appeal. I urge all members, parliamentary and electorate staff, and members of the public to support this appeal. Donations to the appeal will be directed to two very worthy charities--Project: Love and Care, and ACT for Kids, formerly the Abused Child Trust. I want to thank Channel 7 for partnering with the Speaker’s Christmas Tree Appeal and for the upcoming publicity support it will provide, together with any other media outlets that wish to join in promoting the appeal.

The second major upcoming event will be held on the morning of Thursday, 26 November. At 8 am on this day, prior to our final sitting day for the year, I will host a multi-faith service in the Legislative Council chamber. Eight of Queensland’s religious leaders will jointly deliver this service of prayer that is themed ‘Caring for our community’. I extend an invitation to all honourable members to attend.

Finally, on Wednesday, 16 December, the Queensland parliament will host its first citizenship ceremony. I have received the honour of being granted Presiding Officer status for this event, and along with the Governor, Her Excellency Ms Penelope Wensley, I will welcome 100 new Australians as they become citizens. I encourage all honourable members to attend this historic ceremony.

XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.37 am): The liquefied natural gas industry has the potential to rival coal and tourism in terms of importance to the Queensland economy. Eight companies have expressed their intention to construct LNG production and export facilities here, with seven of them intending to locate in a dedicated industry hub in Gladstone. Should even a mid-size, 28 million tonnes per annum LNG industry eventuate, it would result in massive economic benefits for Queensland--over 18,000 jobs and an increase in gross state product of around $3 billion.

That is why my government has worked tirelessly to ensure the industry has every possible support and backing. We have extended the Gladstone State Development Area to the southern part of Curtis Island to accommodate large LNG plants. While more than 70 per cent of the State Development Area will be locked away to protect the environment, we will still have room for an industry precinct occupying more than 1,500 hectares.

We have created an infrastructure corridor between Callide and Gladstone where gas pipelines servicing LNG plants can be located. Last month, we released our blueprint for Queensland’s LNG industry to help guide development in coming years. That blueprint gives certainty to intending industry in relation to matters such as their environmental requirements and their royalty obligations.

I am pleased to inform the House today that our support of the industry is starting to pay off in real and concrete ways. Tonight, the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy will open the new headquarters for one of those companies that is vying for these plants, Santos, a major LNG proponent. Santos’s new Queensland headquarters in Turbot Street has facilities for more than 550 staff and it will also be home to the new Australian headquarters for Malaysia’s Petronas, Santos’s partner in the Gladstone liquefied natural gas project.

We will see Santos and its partner Petronas located in a new office here in Brisbane. This is happening today--even while the project is still going through the full approval process. More importantly than the opening of a new building--much more importantly--is the commitment of this gas project to jobs. Today Gladstone Liquefied Natural Gas is announcing a $50 million program to employ more apprentices and trainees, more Indigenous workers, and increase education and training in LNG related skills. As part of the plan to be rolled out over five years, it will spend $16 million for up to 100 new diesel mechanics and electrical apprentices and traineeships in plant operations. It will spend $4 million on a special training package to support an ambitious target of 300 Indigenous jobs. It is committing $30 million to curriculum and training packages in Queensland schools, TAFEs and universities to further develop LNG and coal seam gas skills here in Queensland.

Up to 6,000 workers will be required for this one project, and around 1,000 permanent operational staff will be required in regional Queensland. Many of the skills needed to deliver this project simply do not exist in great numbers yet in the Australian workforce, and this is an important opportunity for a massive program of upskilling.

I welcome the announcement from Santos today. I look forward to similar announcements from some of the other major proponents. I see this as a vote of confidence in Queensland, the long-term resilience and prosperity of the Queensland economy and particularly to regional Queensland in Gladstone and in the south-west that will be the major beneficiaries from this major new industry and investment.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.41 am): My government has a strong and proven commitment to meeting the challenges of climate change head-on. To reflect this, today I would like to outline for the House two significant and important events taking place next week to address this important issue. To begin with, next week I will be attending the Council for the Australian Federation meeting in Adelaide. This is a critical opportunity for first ministers of all of the states and territories of Australia to come together to discuss issues of national importance. The major focus of this Council for the Australian Federation meeting will be climate change.

Queensland is not only the state most vulnerable to climate change impact but also the region with the most to gain from effective national and international action and cooperation. State and territory governments have an important role to play in addressing the challenges presented by climate change and differentiating their obligations from the Commonwealth. The meeting will start off with a business round table so state governments can hear firsthand from business about how we can best work with them to transition Australia to a low-carbon economy.

The round table will identify opportunities for states and territories to work together with business on collaborative projects to deliver tangible benefits for the community. This will include looking at ways in which to provide support for electric vehicles, infrastructure for renewable and low-carbon energy, more efficient and effective land use planning, new innovations in buildings and promotion of lasting energy efficiency savings. States and territories will be working together in key areas including supporting innovation in the development of low-carbon technologies and building a workforce that is capable of meeting the needs of new and emerging green industries.

One of the significant things about this meeting is that it recognises that regional governments, both here in Australia and around the world, have a distinct and important role to play in assisting in adapting and mitigating the effects of climate change. It is regional and state governments that have responsibility legislatively and constitutionally for matters such as land use planning, electricity supply, building codes and other similar issues. This is critical in the lead-up to the Copenhagen talks. The Premier of South Australia will be chairing the regional government section of the Copenhagen talks.

Also next week my government is hosting the Queensland Climate Change Summit here at Parliament House. This summit will be held next Wednesday in partnership with the world’s leading international climate change non-profit organisation, the Climate Group. This is one of a number of international events the Climate Group is supporting in the lead-up to a critical climate change meeting in Copenhagen in December. We are staging next week’s summit to have a timely dialogue with businesses here in Queensland on the challenges ahead. We want a business-to-business exchange of strategies for dealing with the emerging low-carbon economy, its challenges and, importantly here in Queensland, its opportunities.

The participants in this summit represent big industry in Queensland, including the coal and energy sectors, developers and retailers. We are urging them to promote low-carbon leadership within the broader business community as we move to Copenhagen and beyond. The eyes of the world will be focused on Copenhagen in December when the 192 members of the United Nations and hundreds of delegates attend the United Nations climate leaders summit. Together with the Victorian and South Australian premiers, my government’s climate change and sustainability minister, Kate Jones, will be joining the official and vital Australian delegation to Copenhagen. We face a unique dual challenge--the challenge of promoting economic growth while at the same time ensuring that Australia can play its part in addressing the prospect of dangerous climate change impacts. That will be the focus of my minister, Kate Jones, at this summit as Queensland looks forward to working with other states and territories and the nations of the world in meeting one of the biggest challenges of our times.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.45 am): Community cabinet this weekend will take place in Barcaldine and Longreach on Sunday and Monday. Once again, my government will be taking government to the people of Queensland wherever they live. This will be my 19th community cabinet as Premier, and I can honestly say that I have enjoyed every one of them and that I am looking forward to Barcaldine and Longreach this weekend. Community cabinet is about ensuring that we as a government are staying in touch with the people of this state. That concept is especially relevant in these vibrant communities which are thousands of kilometres to the west of Brisbane. It is a great opportunity for all to come along and meet the state’s key decision makers, ministers and directors-general.

So far there have been 55 scheduled formal deputations for Barcaldine on Sunday and another 28 for Monday in Longreach. That is a 66 per cent increase on the most recent previous community cabinets in the area. In 2002, the total number of deputations was 50 and in 1998 it was 48. That turnout shows that Queenslanders continue to take up the opportunity to meet with their government on their turf and on their terms. I thank the local member for his assistance to his constituents. His electorate office has been very helpful in passing on the details for those seeking deputations. Everyone is welcome to attend this forum and I look forward to spending some time with the people of Barcaldine, Longreach and the surrounding region.

I can also announce that the final community cabinet of the year will be held on Sunday, 29 November and Monday, 30 November. This will take place at Forest Lake, and I am sure it will attract members of the community from across the western suburbs. Taking government to one of our great outback communities and then following that with a community cabinet in one of our newer Brisbane suburbs is a perfect example of how the community cabinet program operates. I look forward to many more in the future.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.47 am): Finally, let me talk about rugby league. I think I speak for every Queenslander when I say for too long New South Wales has claimed bragging rights as the heart of rugby league in this country. While it may still be home to a majority of the teams, Queensland has now emerged as the passion state when it comes to the great game of rugby league. Throughout the NRL season Queensland has become hypnotised by the sport. Our three teams are consistently among the best in the country and our fans are the truest through and through. It is time the National Rugby League grand final moved north. Queensland has the fans and the facilities, and we are the best holiday destination in Australia.

Our job-creating stadiums are up to twice as popular as those south of the border. The Broncos are averaging around 35,000 people at their home games at Suncorp Stadium. That creates jobs for 1,200 people at the stadium alone. The Gold Coast Titans are attracting an average crowd of more than 18,000 at Skilled Park, and at Dairy Farmers Stadium on average we see more than 16,500 North Queenslanders. In every one of those stadiums the average crowd attendance is above the average crowd attendance for the entire NRL. In Queensland I have no doubt that it will not be too long before we see two Queensland teams go head to head for the rugby league grand final. I have made no secret of the fact that we will be in there fighting hard to get the grand final to Queensland after the current New South Wales contract ends in 2012.

As David Gallop rightly said yesterday, Queensland will be the frontrunner. Not only do our teams have the backing of long-term Queenslanders, but as 1,000 people move to Queensland every week--the majority from New South Wales and Victoria--fans of southern teams are also hankering to have a final here in the north.
We will continue talks with the NRL to get the best deal for Queensland. We on this side of the House want to see the rugby league grand final in Queensland. That is where we think it belongs.
Opposition members interjected.

Ms BLIGH: This is the one thing that I thought we would have bipartisan support for this morning. But, no, those opposite cannot even back the rugby league. The National Rugby League is clearly keen to make the most of Queensland’s fan base and our fantastic facilities. Frankly, it would be crazy to miss the opportunity to showcase that event right here in Queensland.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! We will wait for the House to come to the order. I call the honourable Deputy Premier and Minister for Health.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health)
(9.50 am): Australians have one of the longest life expectancies in the world. As medical technology advances and as we understand more about healthy living we are living longer. But the flip side of this is that we are seeing a rapid rise in cancer. This is partly because we are living longer. Men who used to die of old age are now dying of prostate cancer because old age is now older. Part of this is because technology and awareness has improved and we are diagnosing more cancers.

Cancer currently accounts for around a quarter of all Queensland Health treatments. The number of new cancers diagnosed each year is expected to grow by 40 per cent in the next decade. But the good news is that cancer survival rates in Australia and Queensland are amongst the highest in the world. Five-year survival rates for many common cancers are now more than 80 per cent and more than half of all cancers diagnosed are successfully treated.

Since 2005, the Queensland government has invested more than $463 million in cancer services. This has delivered more than 500 cancer specialist doctors, nurses and allied health workers; an additional 2,500 overnight admissions a year; an additional 21,000 extra ambulatory treatment places per year; an additional 162 palliative care beds; a $6.5 million cancer oncology centre at Rockhampton; $3.1 million in Cairns for six additional chemotherapy chairs; and $5 million to support 19 new cancer treatment drugs which previously were not accessible due to the high cost.

In the 2009-10 federal budget the Rudd government committed a record $2 billion to provide the infrastructure and support to introduce new and better cancer treatments and improve access to necessary care for patients in rural and regional Australia. As part of this investment, funds from the nation-building Health and Hospitals Fund will be used to support around 10 regional cancer centres, networked across the nation.
I remind people in other states that we actually have a regional state unlike places like Victoria or Western Australia. People actually live in the regions in this state.
An opposition member interjected.
Mr LUCAS: No, I am pointing that out to people in other states.
An opposition member interjected.
Mr LUCAS: You obviously think you live in another state, because I said people in other states. I know you are in another state of mind, but I did not know that you live in another state.

Funding of $560 million will be provided to establish new or enhance existing regional cancer centres to optimise outcomes for patients in rural and regional Australia. It takes about an hour to drive from Bendigo or Ballarat to Melbourne, for example. It takes a lot longer in Queensland.

Queensland, as the nation’s most decentralised state, will be working closely with bodies such as Cancer Council Queensland to secure funding for several sites across the state. One of the Bligh government’s core election commitments was to provide $15 million in grant funding to non-government organisations to build or enhance regional accommodation for patients travelling to receive treatment. This included $1 million already granted to the Central Queensland Cancer Support Centre constructed by Cancer Care Queensland and opened by the Minister for Public Works and I recently.

In July, Queensland Health called for offers from suitable NGOs to build or enhance patient accommodation under this election commitment. A total of nine offers were received. A full evaluation process was undertaken and the director-general has approved seed funding of $100,000 for an initial five organisations. They are the Yumba-Meta Housing Association and the Leukaemia Foundation in Townsville, the Australian Red Cross and the Cancer Council Queensland in Cairns, and the Cancer Council Queensland in Toowoomba.

This seed funding will allow each organisation to work up the initial planning with an additional $3.5 million in capital funding to be further allocated to assist in either the refurbishment of existing facilities or the construction of accommodation facilities for patients travelling to receive treatment at Queensland Health facilities. Our non-government sector plays a vital role in supporting and caring for Queenslanders suffering from a range of serious conditions, and I am very pleased that we can support them in this work.

The Bligh government is committed to improving and enhancing cancer services throughout the state. I am pleased to announce that we are delivering on this commitment. To use the Rockhampton centre that we opened recently as an example, it is not just a win for Rockhampton in terms of providing further critical mass which we need for cancer treatments in a centre but the cancer accommodation in Rockhampton is really for people who live around Rockhampton and not in Rockhampton. So it provides that win as well.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (9.54 am): I lay upon the table of the House the 2008-09 annual economic report and the 2008-09 report on state finances.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Annual economic report on the Queensland economy--year ended 30 June 2009.
Tabled paper: 2008-09 Report on State Finances.
XML.Hansard-Body: These two reports lay out in black and white the carnage visited upon us by the global financial crisis. This is a crisis that has strangled the life out of the global economy, causing the first contraction of global output since World War II. And Queensland has not escaped the violence. Our growth has been close to five per cent on average over the last decade. The global deceleration has reduced that to below one per cent for the financial year 2008-09. But, this is growth, still positive growth of 0.8 per cent, and the result released today is up from the forecast handed down with the 2009-10 budget of half a per cent.

It is clear that 0.8 per cent is marginal growth, but it remains positive--something most developed economies around the world cannot claim. It is by any measure a remarkable result. Contributing to this growth were the last echoes of the resources boom which boosted investment through the rollout of projects already committed to before the crisis hit in earnest. This is evidenced by business investment which experienced its fifth consecutive year of double digit growth. Critically, public final demand--the measure of government effort, including the building program--grew by 4.6 per cent compared with 2.1 per cent growth in private final demand.

Its critical importance is underlined by the fact that public final demand contributed 1.1 percentage points to the final growth result. There can be no denying the fact that our nation-leading building program, locked in by this government, helped the Queensland economy stay above the line.

While we continue to face serious challenges in employment, Queensland actually saw jobs growth of 2.2 per cent over the financial year. But here lies the rub. Queensland’s continued population boom and higher participation rate saw the labour force grow by three per cent offsetting the positive jobs growth.

As I have previously outlined to the House and to the Queensland public, Queensland’s revenues have been dramatically affected by the global recession. At budget time we forecast a massive wipeout in future revenues. The report on state finances details the hits to revenue in 2008-09, with $1.2 billion worth of state taxation revenue forecast at budget gone in the actual wash-up and hits to other areas such as GST of around $740 million.

When I handed down the 2009-10 budget in June, Treasury forecast a deficit of $574 million for 2008-09. I can report that that outcome has improved. For 2008-09, the final budget operating balance is a surplus of $35 million. This is largely due to some very specific, technical additions to the state’s bottom line that were accounted for at the end of the financial year.

The result has not been driven by a sudden turnaround in revenue outlook. Projected taxation revenue did improve, but only by 1.3 per cent as activity in the economy, and in the housing sector in particular, remains subdued. Final dividends and tax payments from across the entire GOC sector increased. There were also changes to accommodate the treatment of the contribution of land from developments which now includes a valuation of the land underneath roads, reflecting a new national accounting standard--an accounting policy change that boosted the final audited result by some $322 million. If not for the accounting change to value land under roads, the quantum of these contributions would be less than $100 million. Actual operating expenses were slightly below those forecast in June, while an increase in Commonwealth grants revenue of $168 million was also recorded.

It is important to emphasise that this surplus result is a substantial improvement, and a welcome one. It does not mean, however, that Queensland has defeated the global recession and victory can be declared. We face many continued challenges, most particularly, we are largely facing a ‘revenueless recovery’ which means that our key revenues, such as transfer duty, payroll tax and coal royalties, are flatlining, if not decreasing, in the near term.

As our farmers and our tourism industries will attest, a rising Australian dollar is not all good news. For the state, given coal companies write their export contracts in US dollars, a rising Aussie dollar is a revenue risk. For every 1c rise in the Aussie dollar, the impact is $27 million off our royalties.

Yet a sense of optimism is prudent in these circumstances. Queensland’s fundamentals remain strong. Our trading partners are forecast to return to growth during the second half of next year and, as I have mentioned, we have maintained strong population growth as people demonstrate their faith in our prospects.
It is fair to say that the global recession has put the brakes on growth. Queensland, in my view, will be in the future, as it has been for so long, a key driver of the nation’s economic performance.
Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport) (9.59 am): I rise to make a ministerial statement and table the report into an investigation regarding a tragic level crossing accident.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Final report, Rail Safety Investigation QT2459, fatal collision between the Cairns tilt train and B-double truck, Rungoo level crossing, Queensland, 27 November 2008.
XML.Hansard-Body: On 27 November last year, two QR train drivers were killed when the Cairns tilt train collided with a B-double truck at Rungoo, north of Ingham. My department instigated a full, independent, no-blame investigation under the Transport Infrastructure Act 1994 to identify the cause of the collision and make recommendations to improve safety. The investigation was chaired by an investigator from the Australian Transport Safety Bureau. It examined all aspects of the crash from obtaining eyewitness accounts to complex engineering and technical advice. The police investigation is separate and, I am advised, ongoing.

The investigation found that the primary cause of the crash was that the truck driver failed to respond to the flashing lights at the crossing. By the time he saw the train approaching, he was not physically able to stop in time to avoid a collision. Eyewitness accounts and subsequent testing confirm that the warning lights were operational. The report notes that the driver says that he did not see the flashing lights. It finds that the driver may have been experiencing a degree of fatigue which could have affected his performance and that he ‘had a poor driving history in terms of licence suspension due to an accumulation of demerit points for speeding and logbook irregularities’. The investigation also confirmed that the level crossing was essentially compliant with the relevant standards and that neither the truck nor the train had any defects.

During the investigation QR temporarily suspended service of the Cairns tilt train while additional information on the safety of the cab structure was sought. The report found that, even if the train had been built to higher standards, it is unlikely that the survivable space in the cabin would have been significantly greater.

The report proposes a number of safety actions. First, it recommends that the Australian Transport Council further investigate intelligent systems to monitor heavy vehicle speed and compliance. I will raise this at the ATC meeting in Sydney next week. Second, it suggests that my department take further steps to ensure drug testing of drivers involved in serious crashes. I commit to that review being undertaken in conjunction with police. Third, it recommends that Queensland Rail make policy changes around passenger manifests and how to respond to offers of medical assistance. I have written to the CEO of QR on those matters today. I can also advise the House that work is continuing on the Rungoo crossing to improve safety, with boom gates to be installed by mid-November.

This was a tragic incident which led to the loss of two lives and which has caused distress to the many people involved. I offer my sincere condolences to the family, friends and co-workers of the two men who passed away.

Hon. CA WALLACE (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads) (10.03 am): I have good news for Queensland. I would like to inform the House that the final 3.5-metre gap in the main span of the second Gateway Bridge was closed overnight, bringing the $1.88 billion Gateway Upgrade Project another step closer to completion. Last night 75 cubic metres of concrete was poured into the final piece of formwork, marking the completion of the 1.63-kilometre bridge superstructure. This follows two concrete pours earlier this month to close the 2.5-metre gaps between the side spans and the northern and southern approaches to the bridge.

This is a great achievement, considering that construction of the four 130-metre cantilever spans only began in February this year. A total of 25 workers were involved in the operation, which took about five hours to complete, finishing around midnight. Over the past eight months a team of 80 workers have cast 123 concrete segments. Now that the final section of concrete has been poured, the 260-metre main river span will be stressed using high-tensile steel cables to hold the two ends of the superstructure firmly together. The focus will then turn to finishing works, which include the installation of concrete barriers, lighting, safety screens and fire mains, asphalt surfacing, line marking and the completion of the dedicated pedestrian and cycle paths. The project is ahead of schedule, with the bridge scheduled to be completed by mid next year.

Following the opening of the new bridge to southbound traffic by the middle of next year, refurbishment of the existing Gateway Bridge will be carried out as well as the completion of other features of the project. Three northbound lanes will remain open to traffic on the existing bridge during the refurbishment, which is expected to take about seven months. Once complete, all Queenslanders will be able to celebrate the achievements of the project, as the twin bridges are lit up with permanent themed lighting and features unmatched by any bridge of this size in Australia. As a centrepiece project in the government’s current $18.2 billion road infrastructure plan, the Gateway Upgrade Project is protecting our Queensland lifestyle through more reliable, safer and easier travel on the Gateway Motorway.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (10.05 am): Existing laws in Queensland prevent couples from using altruistic surrogacy as a last-resort option to create a family. This is a situation that the Bligh government is determined to address. As part of our commitment to resolving this issue, in August 2009 the government released for public comment a position paper outlining our reforms to the law relating to surrogacy, namely, to decriminalise altruistic surrogacy but to continue to make commercial surrogacy arrangements illegal. This model received support from an overwhelming majority of stakeholders and commentators. The government has now prepared a draft bill, taking into account the feedback and input we received. This legislation will have a significant effect on people’s lives and I now table for the benefit of all members and interested Queenslanders the consultation draft of the Surrogacy Bill 2009 and the explanatory notes.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Consultation of draft Surrogacy Bill 2009.
Tabled paper: Consultation of draft Surrogacy Bill 2009, explanatory notes.
XML.Hansard-Body: This bill heralds a new era for Queensland couples. These reforms mean that many people who once only ever dreamt of starting a family will now be able to make those dreams a reality. Under the bill, a surrogacy arrangement is where a birth mother agrees to become pregnant and for the child born as a result of this arrangement to be treated as the child of another person or persons--the intended parents. The parties involved in an altruistic surrogacy arrangement who wish to seek an order from the court to transfer the legal parentage of the child must meet certain strict requirements. Among others, these include satisfying the court that the parties have undergone counselling, received independent legal advice and have established a medical or social need for the surrogacy.

This legislation demonstrates the Bligh government’s commitment to social reform, equality and the importance of family. The bill and explanatory notes will be available on the parliamentary website as well as the Justice website at justice.qld.gov.au. I anticipate that the final version of the bill will be introduced into the Legislative Assembly in late November.

Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (10.07 am): I am pleased to inform the House that today I will table the first annual report of the Family Responsibilities Commission. As a key plank of the Cape York welfare reform trial, it links parental responsibility with welfare assistance to restore Indigenous authority and social norms in the trial communities of Aurukun, Hope Vale, Coen and Mossman Gorge. It is not just about school attendance, as important as that is. What a parent has to do under the new arrangements is to make sure that their children are fed, that they have a good night’s sleep and that they get off to school in the morning ready to learn. Over the past 12 months the commission has held 951 conferences and referred 616 people to support services, with nearly 280 undertaking programs such as anger management and alcohol treatment. There were also 89 orders for conditional income management.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Annual Report 2008-09 of the Family Responsibilities Commission.
XML.Hansard-Body: Today’s annual report shows that positive things are happening in the trial communities. The commission reports that people are coming forward voluntarily--people such as pensioners and carers--and asking for their income to be managed to help them meet their family’s needs. The Bligh government joins the Family Responsibilities Commission in asking the Commonwealth for the necessary administrative flexibility to enable voluntary income management to happen.

I would like to share with the House the story of Alice--which is not her real name to protect her identity. This young woman from one of these communities has kindly given permission for her story to be shared in the hope of influencing others. Alice is a client of the commission who is subject to conditional income management and has almost completed her case plan. At first Alice said she was very unhappy, and even angry, about having her income managed. After going through the commission, completing an alcohol management program and getting a job for three days a week Alice says she now has many reasons to smile. She enjoys spending time with her children, has money to buy food and even has some money put away for a rainy day. She says she is planning her next job move to work as a landscaper or maybe even a ranger.

Coen local commissioner, Garry Port, reports that children in his community are coming to school prepared and they are learning. Commissioner Port says that attendance is up, students’ education standards are starting to fall into place and they themselves can see the importance of learning. Stories like Commissioner Port’s and Alice’s are as stirring as they are real. Without doubt one of the biggest strengths in this trial is the local commissioners, elders and community leaders who are working behind the scenes every day to get their residents on and up.

I commend family responsibilities commissioner, David Glasgow, and his staff for their work. I look forward to continuing this important partnership with the Family Responsibilities Commission and, most importantly, with the good people of these four communities for the benefit of this generation and the next.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.11 am): The Bligh government is helping create a smarter and greener Queensland. This year we have been making our schools more sustainable by installing solar panels and energy efficient lighting. Since July, 167 schools have had solar panels installed and 314 schools have had energy efficient lighting installed. By March 2010 more than 600 schools will have solar panels, energy efficient lighting and an information technology data system installed through this partnership with the federal government.

It is also a program that is creating jobs; more than 463 jobs statewide, in fact. It is because of our commitment to programs and partnerships like this one that the Bligh government is continuing to create and support Queensland jobs. But we are also improving education standards through projects like this. Getting students more engaged with science is one of our key goals because we know this will help boost their achievements. We need to find new and innovative ways to get them interested and keep them studying science. The solar energy efficiency program gives students a real-life view of what is actually happening up there on the roof and in the lights.

Each school’s solar panels and lighting come with a smart meter. These smart meters collect data on electricity generation and consumption. It is a great way for students to see how they are saving energy, to learn how the technology works and why it is so important. Teachers will be able to use their own school’s data to explore topical issues such as greenhouse gas emissions and sustainable energy use. This is a great program for Queensland: it creates jobs, it saves energy and it helps students learn and love science. As we enter the Year of Sustainability in 2010 I look forward to seeing schools all over Queensland reaping even more benefits from this wonderful partnership.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (10.12 am): It is fair to say that for some time we have witnessed emotionally charged and exaggerated allegations that our wild rivers initiative is a deliberate strategy to shut down economic opportunities for Indigenous communities in Cape York. This is demonstrably untrue. The Wild Rivers Act is a visionary approach to protecting some of Australia’s most ecologically healthy river systems. There are few countries in the world that can boast having rivers in such pristine condition.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr ROBERTSON: I would just remind the House that the opposition actually supported our wild rivers legislation. Our overarching intent is to ensure that any new development within a wild river basin does not impact on those natural values that make these rivers so special. But does that mean opportunities for new jobs grind to a halt? The answer is an emphatic no. It is disappointing that so much that has been written has clearly not been informed by the declarations that are publicly available on my department’s website. Any reasonable consideration of these documents reveal new projects are, in fact, encouraged providing that the rivers are not unduly impacted upon. This is not unreasonable and is not so different from the protection afforded to any other waterway in any other part of Australia. Activities including mining, grazing, fishing and ecotourism can all still occur.

The declarations explain how and where such work can occur. For example, within a high-preservation area, which is the area immediately adjoining a river, there are no constraints on grazing activities. Similarly, the construction and maintenance of outstations, roads and facilities for tourism are also not prohibited in the HPAs. However, intensive agriculture, animal husbandry, in-stream dams and weirs, surface mining and aquaculture are restricted in the most sensitive areas. But even these activities can proceed if there is a property development plan which ensures appropriate environmental safeguards are in place. In such ecologically sensitive areas, this approach to development assessment is not too much to ask. The act also ensures traditional Indigenous activities such as hunting and fishing can still occur and native title rights are protected and respected.

We are committed to preserving the unique biodiversity of the cape while also creating jobs in cape communities. That is why we have introduced a range of specific initiatives to facilitate indigenous economic opportunities. Last year we released the Cape York and Torres Strait Tourism Action Plan, developed with Indigenous communities to encourage the growth of the tourism industry. In 2007 the Cape York Peninsula Heritage Act was enacted to clearly recognise the importance of ensuring an appropriate balance between the preservation of the cape’s unique culture and environment and the legitimate economic aspirations of Indigenous communities. For example, this act requires specific Indigenous water reserves be set aside in a wild river to enable communities to pursue opportunities for job creating projects that require a water allocation. We are also employing Indigenous people across the Cape and Gulf in our unique wild rivers ranger program.

An informed debate to encourage improvements in Indigenous health, education, employment and business opportunities on Cape York is always welcome. Meeting the challenge of Closing the Gap demands a robust debate about identifying the best ways forward. But that debate must also be factual otherwise too much time is wasted on having to correct the record.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology)
(10.16 am): Recently a Brisbane resident wrote to me regarding an unregistered business called Discount Roofing. This business has placed advertising billboards on power poles and in other public places advertising that a roof can be painted with two coats of acrylic paint for $895. This business is not licensed and, as far as I am concerned, consumers should not be using them. Consumers should always use a licensed contractor because the licence indicates that the contractor has met certain minimum standards. I will be asking the Building Services Authority to pursue this unlicensed company.

Our home is likely to be the single biggest asset most individuals own. Any investment made in that home should not be risked in the hands of an unlicensed contractor. A critical role of the BSA, and in particular over the past 12 months given the economic climate, is to target unlicensed contracting. The BSA has performed a number of unlicensed contracting blitzes over the past 12 months. These blitzes have included targeting unlicensed contractors advertising to do building work through media outlets and conducting licensing audits to detect unlicensed contractors who unlawfully perform building work.

The BSA was extremely active on this front last financial year. Some 1,175 investigations into non-compliant advertisements were conducted, which has resulted in 212 infringements notices being issued. The BSA also investigated complaints made by consumers and BSA licensed contractors with some 639 investigations undertaken into allegations of unlicensed contracting resulting in 525 infringement notices being issued.

Two licensing audits were conducted during the year with 7,470 contractors being interviewed at 1,916 building sites. It is pleasing that out of all these audits only 120 people were suspected of not holding an appropriate licence. It shows that there is indeed a great awareness and compliance with this system. The rate of unlicensed contractors detected has remained relatively steady over the last couple of years at approximately 2.5 percent. I urge consumers and members of this House to assist in removing these rogues and cowboys from the industry by simply not using unlicensed contractors and warning constituents not to do so. Consumers should check to ensure that contractors are licensed before engaging such individuals to do building work. Consumers should always check their contractor’s BSA card and then perform a licence check on the BSA’s online licence search before signing a contract. I urge the media to highlight Discount Roofing as an unlicensed contractor.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.19 am): I am sure all honourable members would agree that threatening or attacking paramedics while they are performing their duties is a despicable act. These dedicated men and women attend incidents to render first aid to those who need it, not to act as punching bags. One hundred and seven incidents of assault were self-reported by ambulance officers last financial year--a very disturbing figure. A further 35 reports have been lodged so far this financial year. One assault is one too many. The Bligh government has taken a hard line, changing the Criminal Code 12 months ago so that such attacks are deemed serious assaults which carry a maximum penalty of seven years in jail. This change covers any public officer, whether they be a paramedic, firefighter or child safety officer, while they are performing their duties.

I am pleased to announced today a pilot program on tactical communication training which will be offered to all operational paramedics in the state. The training includes tactical communication, situational awareness, conflict dynamics, a safety philosophy, open hand tactics and tactical withdrawal. The training pilot is scheduled to start in December and will be undertaken initially in the Brisbane metropolitan region. It is about giving paramedics the training they need to get out of dangerous situations where they feel their security is threatened. It will complement personal safety training that ambulance officers already receive during their training to enter the service.

Tactical communication training is yet another way officers can protect themselves in the field. Already paramedics who feel at risk can request the assistance of the police through discreet radio codes. In South-East Queensland, operational ambulances are fitted with duress buttons and automatic vehicle location technology. The safety and security of our front-line emergency services personnel is a fundamental priority of the Bligh government.

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (10.21 am): The Bligh government went to the last election with a promise to build Queensland out of these tough times. Furthermore, we promised to support the Queensland tourism industry through $36 million in additional funding. The Bligh government also listened to the various drive tourism and regional tourism stakeholder groups that called for new and improved roadside tourism infrastructure. That is why we promised $1.8 million in roadside tourism infrastructure projects.

I am happy to say that my department has already received a number of applications for infrastructure projects to help boost the state’s drive tourism market. Round 1 of the $600,000 Regional Minor Tourism Infrastructure Grants Program has been extremely popular, with applications from local councils, regional tourism organisations and local community groups. These applications have included requests for shaded picnic areas, tourism signage and other amenities in shires neighbouring the Matilda Highway, Pacific Coast Touring Route, the Country Way, Overlander’s Way, Savannah Way and Outback Way.

The drive tourism market is worth more than $4 billion to Queensland and accounts for around 70 per cent of the overnight leisure market. Considering the size of our state, existing facilities and infrastructure can be many kilometres apart, and that is something we can improve on. That is why this grant program is targeting regions that are popular for driving holidays and special interest experiences. It is all about making the experience more comfortable for the grey nomads, backpackers and other visitors.

I have appointed an industry consultative committee made up of representatives of the Queensland Tourism Industry Council, the Local Government Association of Queensland, the Campervan and Motorhome Club of Australia and an independent tourism planner to recommend projects. They will independently ensure the highest priority projects are funded to cater for the drive tourism market. These projects will not only provide tourism benefits but also support local jobs during their construction. The government has delivered more than $1.5 billion in tourism infrastructure whereas the last time the opposition was in power it had an infrastructure freeze. The Bligh government is united in its dedication to Queensland and is delivering on its promises.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (10.23 am): I am pleased to announce today that the Bligh government will be contributing $300,000 to purchase the Cromarty Wetlands in North Queensland. These wetlands will be guaranteed perpetual protection as a result of the purchase, which is a great result for all of North Queensland. I want to start by acknowledging the Townsville trio--the honourable member for Thuringowa, the member for Townsville and the member for Mundingburra--who have been tireless in their representations to the state government about this purchase. They have done a great job in advocating on behalf of the wetlands group. At the request of the member for Townsville, I recently met with the Wetlands and Grasslands Foundation to discuss the merits of securing this area for future generations. I congratulate the member for Townsville on her advocacy and on this great outcome today.

It is a significant site, covering over 1,600 hectares. That is 2,000 footy fields; I thought that the member for Thuringowa could relate to that. It is recognised as an important environment and natural tourism asset for this region. These wetlands provide a very good quality habitat for at least eight species that are listed as rare or threatened. Many bird species use this complex variety of habitats which include rainforest, open forest and swamps. This site is also home to the largest concentration of brolga recorded in Australia, with around 12,000 birds. It is also a very important breeding site for magpie geese. It is surrounded by protected areas on all but the southern end, so this purchase will prevent the fragmentation of a vital ecosystem.

This funding is being announced today because the Wetlands and Grasslands Foundation has an option to purchase the site up until 31 October when this option expires. Our funding is contingent upon other cash contributions being secured by the foundation and the success of the National Reserve System application, which is currently before the Commonwealth government.

I was encouraged to see in the Townsville Bulletin today that the Townsville City Council and the Burdekin Shire Council have also pledged $250,000 combined. The entire area is intended to be managed for nature conservation purposes and become part of Queensland’s ever-expanding protected area estate. It will be a welcome contribution to our 2020 target of achieving 20 million hectares of protected area estate across Queensland. I want to extend my congratulations to the member for Townsville, the other Townsville members, the foundation and also Townsville Enterprise. A lot of fundraising has been carried out by local businesses in support of this. I and the government want to see that that work pays off. We are putting our money where our mouth is.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (10.26 am): I recently had the pleasure of launching the Blue Skies Scenario in Brisbane on behalf of National Disability Services. Blue Skies offers a unique blueprint for building a truly inclusive society for people with a disability. The vision has been developed by people with a disability, parent advocates, service providers and government representatives. The Bligh government is working with the disability services sector to make this vision a reality. That is why the Premier has asked me to develop a 10-year plan for the future of disability services. I will be meeting with major stakeholders about developing this plan over the next few months.

The government’s vision is about ensuring that people with a disability have the same opportunities as all Queenslanders. It is about catering for the diverse needs of people with disability in every aspect of their lives. This means ensuring that they have equality in education, employment, housing and recreation. Over the past decade, it has been Queensland Labor governments that have increased funding for disability services from $250 million a year to more than $900 million a year. We support the Blue Skies vision and we want to take disability services in Queensland to the next level.

The government will pay close attention to the Blue Skies Scenario in formulating our 10-year plan. At the heart of this plan is a recognition that people with a disability have a right to an ‘ordinary life’. An ‘ordinary life’ is not just about the delivery of specialist disability services; it is about better access to transport, education, health care, employment and retail, tourism and recreational opportunities. It is about equality. A fully inclusive community is something that we need to create together. Queenslanders with a disability and their families and carers can rest assured that the Bligh government is sparing no efforts to build a more inclusive community for all people throughout Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Distinguished Visitors
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Before I call for question time, I would like all honourable members to welcome to the public gallery the Hon. Maxime Carlot Korman, the Speaker of the Republic of Vanuatu, and the delegation from the Republic of Vanuatu who are visiting Parliament House today. Would you please make them welcome.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Speaker’s Statement
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, in today’s session of parliament we will be joined at various times by the Chermside National Seniors, the Greenleaves Retirement Village, the Albany Hills State School in the electorate of Everton and the Elanora State School in the electorate of Currumbin.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Questions Without Notice
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LANGBROEK (10.30 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. On 6 October the Premier told this House, ‘I can advise the member that no member of my jobs task force at those meetings has ever raised the issue or raised any concerns with privatisation.’ Jobs Squad member Ron Monaghan has labelled the Premier’s privatisation plan ‘magic pudding economics’ and said, ‘The person in the street would be misled if they took the government’s spin at face value.’ Does the Premier still stand by her comment of 6 October that Ron Monaghan has never raised this issue with her at these meetings?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. The opposition of Ron Monaghan and a number of unions associated with the Queensland Council of Unions to the government’s plan to sell some assets is well known, is on the public record and is well established. Watch television and you will see it. It is not secret opposition. They are not keeping it to themselves.

The question that I was asked was whether this had been raised as part of the Jobs Squad activities. Mr Monaghan has not raised this at the Jobs Squad. It has not been a subject of any agenda item at meetings. Of course Mr Monaghan has raised it with me at every other opportunity he has had. I can barely ring the man without having a discussion about it. There is absolutely no secret that the unions have a very entrenched ideological opposition to this. There is no secret about that. As I said, turn on your television, turn on your radio, open your newspaper and you will find out about their views on it.

The agenda items at the Jobs Squad have included practical ways to take the regulatory burden off business where possible and have included how to create new opportunities to ensure that we do not see a lost generation of young people unable to get apprenticeships and traineeships. We have seen an opportunity to talk about how to best deploy new resources from government like the Green Army and how we can work with the Commonwealth government’s targeted employment zones. Mr Monaghan has been an active participant in all of those discussions, as we would expect him to be, as indeed have representatives of the Australian Workers Union who have been at those meetings.

I welcome the question from the opposition about the work of the Jobs Squad. I met with them last week. They are, as always, a group of people who deeply care about not only the strength of the Queensland economy but much more importantly the lives and working opportunities for ordinary Queenslanders who are threatened by the global financial crisis.
Mr Springborg: And privatisation.

Ms BLIGH: I note the continued view of those opposite that privatisation will not lead to growth in jobs. I have more faith in the private sector than they have obviously. I believe that private investment will grow jobs in coal. How are we going to have more coal go to port unless we have more train drivers and more coal wagons? This is about building Queensland Rail. Queensland Rail is a great Queensland organisation and our plans will see it go from strength to strength. There will be more jobs for Queenslanders in Queensland Rail--more jobs for train drivers, more jobs for rail workers, more jobs for those in the workshops.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is also to the Premier. I refer to the Labor Party’s ‘Fast Facts’ on privatisation, which I table, and the statement that $15 billion represents less than one per cent of $200 billion. Will the Premier reveal which economic genius concocted this calculation? Was is it the Premier or the Treasurer?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of document titled ‘Answering concerns about the assets sale’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: I do not have all the words that the Leader of the Opposition is referring to in front of me. When I identify it, I am happy to have a look at it. What we have put into the public arena--and it is a fact--is that what constitutes less than one per cent of revenue is the revenue gained from those assets which we intend to put into the market. It is very clear. There is a view out there perpetrated by those opposite that GOCs are cash cows for the government, that they are running the entire budget of government--nothing could be further from the truth. Sure, it is great to have income from any source, but the revenue from these assets constitutes less than one per cent of revenue to the government’s coffers. That is a fact and I am happy for Queenslanders to know it.

Again, we have those opposite whingeing and moaning, complaining and criticising. All they can do is outline the problem. They never have one single idea for themselves. Where is the shadow Treasurer’s alternative economic plan for Queensland? It does not exist. He does not have one. Where is the the Leader of the Opposition’s alternative economic strategy for Queensland? He does not have one. It does not exist.

As I outlined this morning, our plan is absolutely clear. We will keep building the infrastructure that Queensland needs and we have the courage to take the tough decisions to make that happen. We know that those opposite would cut that building plan. They think that now is a time when Queensland needs fewer roads not more, fewer hospitals, fewer schools. We disagree. We have population growth and we are going to get ahead of that growth and deliver the services and projects that Queenslanders need.

We are building new industries. The work that is happening in the liquefied natural gas industry is building an entire new export sector for this state. If we look at the aviation, biotechnology and ICT industries--all of those new and emerging industries--we will find Queensland government incentives and Queensland government investment programs driving growth in employment and creating jobs. Our plan for jobs is clear. What is equally clear is that those opposite have none.

Mrs KIERNAN: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier inform the House of the opportunities that the LNG industry presents to Queensland and what her government is doing to make this industry a reality?

Ms BLIGH: The state government of Queensland is not only committed to maintaining our massive building program and keeping and protecting the jobs that it relies on but also committed to building new industries wherever there is an opportunity to do so. We have worked very diligently over the last couple of years with proponents who are seeking to open up an entire new export sector for Queensland. We have provided certainty to those proponents about royalty regimes, we have provided certainty on location for proposed plants and we have provided certainty on approval processes. We have put in place a regime for environmental requirements, particularly in relation to the management of waste water from any of these processes.

What we have seen today is the announcement by one of the proponents to put in place a significant level of investment that will be dedicated to creating jobs in new areas where we currently do not have skills anywhere in the country, particularly not in the quantities that are needed, and, commendably, a program to ensure that those opportunities go to young people through apprenticeships and up to 300 Indigenous Queenslanders through their Indigenous employment program. What does all of that mean? It means jobs for Queenslanders. Potentially, when all of these proponents come to reality, it could mean up to a $3 billion increase in gross state product. That is worth working for. It is worth chasing. It is worth being passionate about--and that is what this government is delivering. What does a gross state product increase of $3 billion mean? It means that we can employ more teachers, more police on the front line, more nurses in our hospitals, more ambulance officers, more firefighters--more of what Queenslanders need.

What is the alternative from the opposition? As I have said, we know they will cut the building program. We also know that they want a three per cent cut on jobs like teachers, police, ambulance and firefighters. What they have admitted since the last sitting of parliament is that, while we have a target of 100,000 new jobs, their jobs target is zero. They have a zero target; their jobs target is zero. If the LNP were in government, LNG would mean ‘Look, No Growth’, because they would be taking us backward at a rate of three per cent every year.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to moves within the Labor Party to boot out Labor member and ETU organiser Stu Traill for opposing the Premier on privatisation. Will Labor’s former state president, Ron Monaghan, also be booted out of the Labor Party, or is it a fact that Mr Monaghan is only mouthing opposition to privatisation in public and saying something else behind closed doors?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I am not aware of any moves to cancel the membership of any member of the Australian Labor Party on this or indeed any other issue. One thing I can say about the Australian Labor Party is that it is a very broad church. As uncomfortable as the church might be, it is a very broad one. It has a remarkable elasticity.
Mr Lucas: How is Gary Hardgrave going?

Ms BLIGH: Unlike the LNP, which, in the council chambers this week, was disciplining one of its councillors; unlike poor old Gary Hardgrave, who served the Liberal Party as a federal member, and what thanks does he get? He gets disciplined. So the LNP is in the business of disciplining its former members of parliament.
Mr Lucas: They kicked another bloke out last week for criticising the Lord Mayor.

Ms BLIGH: They kicked another bloke out last week for criticising the Lord Mayor. Mr Traill is welcome to express his views on whatever he wishes, and I reserve my right to disagree with him on a regular basis. That is what the Labor Party is about--a party of ideas, and these matters are a matter for the party.

What an extraordinary turn of events we have had this morning. The member for Southern Downs is here selling himself as the champion of the Electrical Trades Union. This is the mentor who led the party that took their superannuation, that took their houses--the hero, the political mentor of the member for Southern Downs. The ETU were not happy when you owned SEQEB, I can tell you that much.

We have seen the member for Southern Downs try to reinvent himself so many times. Once it was the young socialist worker from Russia. Then he reinvented himself as ‘the Borg’. Now he seeks to be the worker’s champion, the champion of the ETU. It gets less convincing with every reinvention.
Ms CROFT: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier please update the House on any increases to important airline access to Queensland?
Mr SPEAKER: I call the Premier.
Mr Lucas: Lawrence is writing the Aeroflot tickets now.
Mr Springborg: The DC-10!
Mr Lucas: It’s like your leadership--a lead balloon.
Mr Springborg: How’s your leadership going?
Mr Lucas: I haven’t had three cracks at it, like you. You back a loser and want to take over; I back a winner and I am happy with her.
Mr SPEAKER: I call the Premier.
Mr Lucas: Three cracks at it. I wouldn’t have you on any leg of a trifecta.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The Deputy Premier!
Mr Springborg: He is so rude!
Honourable members: Ha, ha!
Mr SPEAKER: I am glad I am above it all and I cannot follow the politics. I call the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: I say to our guests from Vanuatu that this is typical of a Thursday, I am afraid to say. I thank the member for the question. She, like other members from the Gold Coast, understands that tourism, and particularly international tourism, is one of the lifebloods of this wonderful part of our state.

In 2006, the then tourism minister, Margaret Keech, travelled to Malaysia to convince AirAsia X to establish a new route to the Gold Coast rather than to Melbourne. I am pleased to say that she succeeded, and since then the route was launched in November 2007 and passenger movements have grown significantly. AirAsia X had 56,000 passengers travelling to the Gold Coast this year, which is 73 per cent up on the same time last year.

Our government, through the current tourism minister Peter Lawlor’s efforts recently, has worked with this airline to develop marketing campaigns in Malaysia to help grow this route. I am pleased today to advise the House that AirAsia X will again increase its commitment to Queensland. From February next year, it will start operating daily services from Kuala Lumpur to the Gold Coast, lifting its number of flights from six to seven.

So while we have been getting on with the business of scoring goals for the Gold Coast, of kicking goals for the Gold Coast, what have we seen from those members opposite? We have had a week where they have plotted to undermine a great car race, following on from a year where they have opposed the Carrara stadium. While we are on the attack for the Gold Coast, they are holding down the tackled player. What we want is a free-flowing game, but they are not even playing the same game. The only time the member for Surfers Paradise ever needs the video ref is when he has to check his profile.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Treasurer. Today’s tabled report on state finances shows that Labor has delivered the worst net debt position since figures have been kept in Queensland--it is up there on this diagram. Will the Treasurer now admit that debt is in Labor’s DNA?

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for the question, because this government through the last couple of months, and indeed most particularly this week, in the public arena has been pretty forthright about our views on what is required to address the pressures on the state’s balance sheet. We are out there with a plan. We have a plan to address this issue and we have delivered today a result on the 2008-09 year which is improved on what happened at budget time. Nevertheless, where is the starting point on this debate for LNP members? Their starting point is to say that this is not the issue, that an improved position should not be acknowledged. What do they offer in return? Silence. Silence is all we hear. What do we see from the Leader of the Opposition? Acres of nothingness.

What is the myth? That they have got a plan. What is the fact? That they have got no plan. What is the myth? That the member for Surfers Paradise will continue to be the leader of the LNP to the next election. What is the fact? We know that he will not. What is the myth? That they do not really believe in privatisation. What is the fact? That it is absolutely part of what they believe.

What has the shadow Treasurer said in this House on the record? Not only that he supports privatisation, but in a debate on electricity he wanted to go further and sell the poles and wires business as well. What is the fact? That is their view. What is the myth? That they do not believe in privatisation. What is the fact? What does the commission of audit say? That they supported in government selling the motorways, selling the ports, selling the forest. What is the myth? That they did not believe this before the last election. What is the fact? That they had it in their policy platform before the election.

What is the myth? The myth is that there are Liberals still left in this state. What is the fact? There are none of them left. As I said yesterday, it is a bit early for me to start on the concept of saying ‘I remember when’, but I remember when there used to be Liberals in this state. I remember when there used to be people who were actually able to contribute to policy development, when the Liberal Party in this state used to be the vanguard of promoting reform. They have been wiped out, rolled over by the old policy dinosaurs in the Nats. We can see that in their attitude to climate change, where they deny it.

Last week in the parliament the Leader of the Opposition did not even have the guts to ask a question without notice in the chamber which denied climate change. He slipped it in on the Notice Paper so that he could go and dog whisper to everybody about how he does not support a CPRS. What we see from both their stance on this and from their stance on climate change is the death of the Liberal Party. The reality is that this government has a plan. We are putting it forward. What do you hear from the opposition? Nought.

Ms FARMER: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the minister inform the House how bold reform by government leading to better work practices in our hospitals is delivering faster treatment and better care for patients in our health system?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. The honourable member, professionally speaking, is a speech therapist and very much understands the importance of all of our health professionals that operate within Queensland Health.
Mr Hobbs: You should book in.
Mr LUCAS: She did a PhD to understand you, pal.

Mr Gibson:
She still doesn’t understand you.

Mr LUCAS: No-one else does. Government is about constantly looking for new ways to get things done. To improve, we need better innovation and smarter initiatives to back record investment. Nurse practitioners are about patients being treated more quickly, with better efficiency and better outcomes. Previously, until a doctor was available often things did not get done.
Mr Horan: This is in the bill on the table of the House at the moment.
Mr LUCAS: How ridiculous to suggest that if a bill talks about one aspect of a role of a particular profession you are not able to discuss the rest of it. You silly person!
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The Deputy Premier will withdraw that.

Mr LUCAS: I withdraw it, Mr Speaker. They complete a masters level qualification, they can order diagnostics like X-rays, and they can prescribe some medications and issue referrals. People have made a few comments in this place about the level of qualifications of nurse practitioners compared to others. As well as a three-year undergraduate degree that a nurse completes, their masters degree is often in the vicinity of 12 months to 18 months, together with extensive practical experience that takes place usually in between the undergraduate and the masters degrees.

We have 84 nurse practitioners in Queensland. We will have 50 new nurse practitioner positions by 2012 and 30 in our EDs. This year we offered 30 scholarships for nurses to train as nurse practitioners. When I was first appointed health minister--
Mr Seeney: That was a bad day.

Mr LUCAS: It was a lot better day than when you got knocked off as Leader of the Opposition. You clearly go to hospitals with preconceived views based on what you read about the relationship between doctors and nurses. One of the things that has absolutely gratified me is the way that our doctors, nurses and nurse practitioners work in a team in places such as EDs. There are only a couple of troglodytes on the other side of the House who want to traduce the reputation of nurse practitioners. They are a wonderful part of our team.

In the past, the career structure for nursing after becoming a senior on the floor was to go to an administrative position. Any health practitioner will tell you--and we have a number here who are doctors--that they still have the yearn and the desire to be treating people. It is something they always want to do. Nurse practitioner positions offer a professional career structure that allows nurses to continue to have their hands on people to treat them. That is a very important aspect of it. We will see more development of the skills and roles of all of our professions in health, not less. Other people want restrictive work; we do not.

Mr McARDLE: My question is to the Minister for Health. The Park is a high-security mental health facility near Brisbane housing the most dangerous murderers and child rapists. Can the minister explain why, despite a security review undertaken earlier this year due to security locks repeatedly failing, on 9 September the external electronic doors failed twice and spontaneously opened and that, instead of fixing the locks, nurses are now required to check them every two hours?

Mr LUCAS: I take a significant interest in any allegation of the nature of security issues with respect to secure facilities. I am aware there was concern expressed that when the electrical storm happened the other night there was a malfunction. Clearly, that matter has to be investigated. One should remember, however, that even an electronic system has to have a fail-safe but also a system whereby in certain circumstances they will not continue to lock. For example, if you rely on electronic security and there is a fire and it defaults to a mechanism whereby it continues to be locked, then you can in a secure facility risk real difficulties.

One of the things about electronic systems is that there is always a role in appropriate circumstances for human testing of those systems. For example, we have electronic signalling in our rail system. That does not obviate the need for professionals or railway workers to deal with the human aspects of safety. Checking something, notwithstanding that it is electronically controlled, is not in any sense a bad thing.

I am very keen to understand the circumstances surrounding that. Clearly, when lightning strikes happen we have all seen in various places that systems are sometimes damaged. That depends on the nature of it. It is not just a power failure but a symptom of the strike. Where the strike took place, I do not know. Clearly, they are matters of legitimate concern raised by the honourable member. I am keen to have Queensland Health address them.
Mr WENDT: My question is to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. Can the Treasurer inform the House of the performance of the labour market in Queensland in 2008-09?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Ipswich West for his question and for his commitment to making sure that businesses and new businesses are welcomed to Queensland, particularly in the growth corridor of the western corridor. I know that the member for Ipswich West has been a strong advocate not only for existing industries in his electorate but also for the possibility of new industries, particularly in the aviation sector. He, like all members of this government, places job creation and the interests of working families at the forefront of our policy making.

I tabled the annual economic report in the parliament earlier today. That revealed that the performance of the labour market had been under pressure over the last 12 months. What happened in the Queensland labour market is very clear. Everyone should understand that, while unemployment was being visited around the world, while unemployment was on the march through all developed economies and unemployment certainly moved to 4.4 per cent--slightly above the forecast in Queensland--what was going on in the Queensland economy was job creation. Job creation was occurring at a rate of 2.2 per cent--twice the rate of the rest of Australia. Forty-eight thousand jobs were created in the Queensland economy last year in net terms.

Mr Nicholls:
How many were lost?
Mr FRASER: Forty-eight thousand jobs were created in net terms.

Mr Nicholls:
How many were lost?
