Mr FRASER: Forty-eight thousand jobs were created in net terms. It does not suit their view. What are our credentials on this? We are the party which drove unemployment in this state to under five per cent. We are the party and the government that delivered 48,000 jobs last year--twice the rate of the rest of Australia. What remains our resolve from election time to today? To deliver 100,000 jobs over the life of this government, because that is the central driving core of what this government is about.

What we hear from the other side is absolute silence. What is their job creation target? The shadow minister for transport admitted on radio the other day that their target is zero. What is their commitment? They have no policies. They are committed to dropping 12,000 jobs out of the public sector.
Ms SIMPSON: Mr Speaker, I rise to a point of order. That is misleading and offensive and I ask that it be withdrawn.
Mr FRASER: It is no personal reflection.
Ms SIMPSON: You referred to the shadow minister for transport.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I think that is the part of the point of order the honourable member is referring to. It will help the House if you withdraw.

Mr FRASER: Mr Speaker, I am happy to withdraw. I invite the shadow minister and any other member of the LNP to put forward in this House their job creation target, and that much will prove the point. I invite them at this point to yell out across the chamber what is their job creation target. What is their job creation target? They do not have one. Their job creation target is to expunge 12,000 workers--doctors, teachers and the sorts of people who are providing services to the people of Queensland every day--because they learned nothing on 21 March. They abide the three per cent cut to wipe out public sector employment. They continue to have no job creation target. All they do is wring their hands about the problem, and at the first whiff of having to do something they quiver and run away.

Ms SIMPSON: My question is to the Minister for Transport. Will the minister confirm that the reason seven out of 10 commuters reject go cards is their limited availability due to many newsagents being blocked from selling go cards, thus leaving major shopping centres, including Toombul, and whole towns without an outlet?

Ms NOLAN: I thank the honourable member for the question. I note that just recently the member for Maroochydore issued a press release on this very matter claiming that it is incredibly difficult to get your hands on a go card and claiming that in Ipswich, for instance, there was only one go card outlet. In fact, in Ipswich I think there are nine go card outlets. People can get them at 7-Eleven stores, at the Ipswich Railway Station and, of course, over the phone and online.

Nonetheless, I take it from the question that the member for Maroochydore supports the sensational product that is go card, understands why 460,000 people so far have bought one and supports the government’s stated policy of getting 100 per cent take-up of go cards by the end of next year. In order to do that, as the government has already announced, we intend to double the number of outlets at which people can buy a go card. We have already announced that we plan to roll out a seniors card that doubles as a go card so that older people can access this technology with the greatest of ease. We intend to rollout 400,000 go cards with $10 of free credit.

The go card is a sensational product. Unlike Sydney and Melbourne, which are still struggling to get a smart card technology, in Queensland there has been a great take-up rate of this product. Tens of thousands of people every day are using this product to get on and off buses in three seconds rather than 11 seconds. Some 50 million trips have so far been taken using go cards. One and a quarter million trips a week are taken using go cards. More than half of all trips in peak times are go card trips. The people of Queensland who use this product swear by it. We are ultimately committed to rolling it out to the remainder of public transport users. When the Gold Coast light rail is built, the people of the Gold Coast will be able to use their go card on the light rail system. I note that a day after I challenged the Leader of the Opposition to remove his name from the Stop Light Rail website he has failed to do so.

Mr WETTENHALL: My question is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. Would the minister please outline the progress of the government’s wild rivers ranger program?

Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the member for Barron River for his question and acknowledge his abiding interest in initiatives to create employment in Far North Queensland, including Cape York. The wild rivers ranger program currently employs 20 Indigenous rangers across the Gulf of Carpentaria and Cape York to look after Queensland’s declared wild rivers. These rivers are of outstanding national and international significance in terms of their natural and cultural features. The job of the wild rivers rangers is to keep them that way by preventing wild fires, invasive weeds and feral animals, land disturbance, rubbish and water pollution. This very successful wild rivers ranger program will be expanded this financial year with additional funding of $5 million over four years to employ an additional 10 rangers. Rangers deliver on this government’s election commitment to protect some of Queensland’s most magnificent natural assets. That is exactly what these wild rivers rangers are doing.

In the 2008-09 financial year the rangers program offered dozens of activities including treating over 3,000 hectares of weed infested country, eradicating in excess of 2,700 wild pigs, undertaking fire control management on 20,000 hectares using a combination of contemporary and traditional burning practices, erecting five kilometres of fencing of wetlands to keep out cattle and pigs, undertaking surveys of 10 river systems and gathering information on crocodiles and the monitoring of significant water bird nesting sites, and removing in excess of 190 ghost nets. As well as addressing issues in the wild river catchments, the program supports the generation of sustainable employment through an intensive mentoring model. This provides these rangers with nationally accredited training, improved confidence, leadership skills, extended networks and project management experience.

There are some who claim that these are not real jobs. I reject that. These are the kinds of jobs that sit alongside very well our aspirations for Cape York. These are real jobs. These are real skills that are being provided. There are some who allege that there is no long-term commitment. This program is funded in terms of all of the outyears that any government provides in terms of long-term funding.

It is about time some of the knockers actually got on board and supported programs such as this. That is why later today I will be meeting with seven of those rangers and coordinators who are visiting Brisbane to participate in the annual Premier’s public service awards. I wish them success in these awards and look forward to hearing more about their endeavours. Wild rivers rangers undertake an important role in protecting the environmental values of Cape York. Most importantly, the program is providing real jobs and real skills for young Indigenous people on the cape.

Mrs MENKENS: My question is to the Minister for Main Roads. Bearing in mind the moratorium on rent increases for single pensioners, how does the minister justify a $40 a week increase in rent for a single pensioner who has been a long-term tenant in a Main Roads house in Wooloowin, leaving her just $70 a week to survive on?

Mr WALLACE: I do not have those particular details with me. We have a large suite of houses across the state that we acquire for road purposes. We rent those back to tenants usually at market rates after they have been purchased. I occasionally get issues like this across the desk. The member for Brisbane Central raised a similar issue with me a couple of weeks ago. We do look at these cases individually. If someone is suffering financial stress, we will negotiate with that person and ensure that we look after that person and have a rate of return on that property that the person is comfortable with while also protecting the public asset.
A government member interjected.

Mr WALLACE: I take the honourable minister’s interjection that the Rudd government has increased the rate of the aged pension significantly. I welcome that. That did not happen with the previous government. The Rudd government has done the right thing and increased aged pensions to assist aged pensioners. Where an aged pensioner has accommodation that they rent from my department and they are in financial stress, we will look at the individual cases and assist them where possible, as we did in the case that the member for Brisbane Central raised with me. I make no apologies for looking after the most vulnerable in this community. We will do that right across the state.

It is essential that we acquire these properties across the state as we roll out better roads for Queenslanders. There is a big program over the next five years--$18 billion worth of infrastructure; $18 billion worth of roads for Queenslanders. Often we are required to acquire properties to undertake that work. If the member for Burdekin wants to give me the details involving that person we will sit down, negotiate and talk to that person, as we did with the pensioner that the member for Brisbane Central raised with me. We will do that and we will do that in a humane fashion right across the state. We will continue our projects across the state--rolling out road infrastructure for the benefit of Queenslanders and often renting back properties that we acquire from people who have lived there for a number of years. But we will sit down and talk to them if they have specific difficulties.

Mr O’BRIEN: My question is to the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. Last week I had the pleasure of joining the minister in officially opening the new Port Douglas Police Station. Can the minister advise the House of some of the other investments being made by the Queensland Police Service?

Mr ROBERTS: I thank the member for the question. It was indeed a great pleasure to join with him last week in Far North Queensland to open the new Port Douglas Police Station. It is a $3.2 million police facility right on the waterfront and it provides a fantastic facility not just for the police officers but it is also very well located for policing. I know that there were a number of issues in relation to the community during the development of that project. I thank the member for his strong advocacy.

I also joined the member for Dalrymple to open the new Ravenshoe Police Station--another great facility for that community. It also contains a duplex next door for officers. That is something that the Police Service endeavours to do in terms of providing the best accommodation possible, particularly in those areas where accommodation is hard to come by. That duplex cost $667,000.

Indeed, over the past six weeks or so I have had the pleasure of opening around seven police stations across the state, including in many electorates in Brisbane and in the Whitsunday electorate--a magnificent facility--in addition to others prior to that. In fact, this year, the government will be investing $57 million in new capital works projects across the state.

In addition to the very proactive capital works project, the budget provides for at least an additional 200 police officers this year--53 of those for traffic police, making a total of 106 extra traffic police over a two-year period. That is probably the biggest increase in traffic police numbers for a considerable period and, obviously, a great boost to road safety initiatives.

We have to contrast the Labor approach with that of the National Party. We know that the National Party went to the last election with a slash-and-burn policy--$1 billion to be cut out of the public sector, 12,000 jobs across the public sector. That would have equated to around 300 positions in the Police Service.

The opposition often holds up Western Australia as a great example of what you can do, particularly with an efficiency dividend. So let us have a look at a couple of examples of what has happened in Western Australia, particularly with police. I reported in September that in that state police spending had been slashed by $27 million. What were the other consequences? A quarter of Crime Stoppers staff have been scrapped as a result of the efficiency dividend, which was supported by the National Party in Queensland as well.
Another example came to light in the West Australian on 25 October, which reported that--

Mr ELMES: My question is to the Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability. Will the minister explain what her departmental officers are doing to monitor and stop the cruel and inhumane slaughter of dugongs and turtles by non-traditional methods in Far North Queensland and the black market sale of their meat?

Ms JONES: I thank the honourable member for the question. He will be aware that recently--and I think I announced it in this House--I released a discussion paper into the public arena on the protection of marine mammals such as dugongs and dolphins. So I encourage him, along with every other member of this chamber--and, indeed, the Queensland public--to make a submission.

I know that this issue is a concern and it is one about which I have been having meetings with traditional owners and also with departmental officers. It was one of the drivers for me to release publicly this discussion paper and call for people to make submissions. But I also want to make it very clear to members of the House that it is a myth--and we are talking about myths and facts today--propagated by a number of people that the major cause of dugong deaths in Queensland is from traditional owners. In actual fact, the major cause of injury and death of dugongs, as well as turtles, is from humans. It is from boat strikes. One of the key things that we have done to reduce this, particularly--
Mr Gibson interjected.
Ms JONES: I find that offensive and I ask the member to withdraw.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr Nicholls: You’re as bad as any of them.
Mr SPEAKER: The minister found what the member for Gympie said offensive. Accordingly, he will withdraw it.
Mr GIBSON: I withdraw.
Mr SPEAKER: Member for Clayfield, I was on my feet. I therefore warn you under the standing order provision.

Ms JONES: As I was saying, one of the major causes of deaths to dugongs and turtles in Queensland is from boat strikes. And to reduce those deaths, this government has introduced protections through the green zones in Moreton Bay. We have expanded them from .5 per cent to 16 per cent.
Mr Elmes: I was talking about North Queensland.
Ms JONES: I am talking about the issues that we are facing and the action that we are taking, which the members opposite oppose when it comes to protecting dugongs.

Once again, we have heard myths and facts from the opposition. The opposition members come into this House and pretend to say that all of a sudden they care about dugongs, when they are on the record opposing the greatest protection that we can provide to them by expanding the green zones in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the Moreton Bay Marine Park. Another myth that we often hear from the opposition is that they want to see--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Ms JONES: As I was saying, the members opposite have opposed every step that we have taken to increase the protection of marine mammals, including dugongs and turtles in Queensland. Expanding green zones--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Ms JONES: Once again, we are seeing the hypocrisy of the opposition when it comes to the environment. The members opposite come in here every now and then with an issue and say that they care and they--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Ms JONES: As I said at the outset, we have released a discussion paper on this issue. If the member for Noosa has genuine concerns about this issue, I encourage him to make a submission or, alternatively, come up with a policy.

Mr MOORHEAD: My question is to the Minister for Transport. Could the minister outline to the House the average patronage figures for public transport in South-East Queensland and the average customer service figures for assistance provided by Queensland Transport customer service centres?

Ms NOLAN: I thank the honourable member for the question and I note his interest both in public transport and in customer service centres, given that we recently opened a new high-quality customer service centre in his electorate.

During the last election campaign, I am sure all members will recall that the LNP promised a three per cent efficiency dividend across the whole of the Queensland Public Service. If you were to apply that three per cent dividend--as it is euphemistically called--to my department it would mean these things. Every day between 600,000 and 700,000 passengers travel by public transport in South-East Queensland. A large proportion of them, as I have previously mentioned, do it by go card. A three per cent cut in public transport would mean that over 18,000 passengers every day would not have been able to catch their daily bus, ferry or train. Every day there are 876 train services in South-East Queensland. A three per cent cut means that 26 train services would have been taken off the track. There are about 14,000 bus services. A three per cent cut means that around 420 bus services would have been taken off the busways, which, it is worth noting, the Labor government has built.

The question for the opposition is: which suburbs would have missed out? In the last six months around 213,000 customers have been served at Queensland Transport service centres. A three per cent cut would have meant that over 6,300 people who were waiting in line would not have been served. Interestingly, that 6,300 number happens to be the same number of people who would be directly and indirectly employed building the Gold Coast rapid transit project, which the Leader of the Opposition is today listed on the stop light rail website as opposing. But that is, I guess, just a matter of interest.

Had there been an LNP government, the jobs that could be considered to be ‘de-necessary’ include the transport inspector for auditing and compliance, which we are advertising in a number of areas, or perhaps the senior traffic officer, traffic analysis, which is a position in Brisbane that we are advertising at present. The question is this: does the opposition, which does not have a jobs target, still consider these positions to be ‘de-necessary’? The Bligh government is strengthening Queensland’s economy and ensuring jobs and job security. We are increasing services across the board when those opposite would have cut them.

Mr FOLEY: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. I have received disturbing reports that the Maryborough Base Hospital medical director has been seconded to the Bundaberg Base Hospital. Will the minister advise when the vacant position of medical director at Maryborough Base Hospital will be filled or when the seconded medical director will return to Maryborough?
Mr LUCAS: Sure.

Mrs SULLIVAN: My question without notice is to the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning. The Sunshine Coast Regional Council will introduce water conservation measures from December 2009 in line with the rest of South-East Queensland. Could the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning please update the House on what is being done to secure water for South-East Queensland now and into the future?

Mr HINCHLIFFE: I thank the honourable member for her question. Like the people of South-East Queensland, including the members of Chermside National Seniors who are here in the public gallery today, she knows the impact of drought. South-East Queensland has endured some of the toughest water restrictions for more than three years before the worst drought on record was declared officially over when we saw those welcome relief rains in May.

It is clear from recent dry spells that the risk of drought is never too far away. This is why the Bligh government is committed to providing a secure water supply for South-East Queensland, the fastest growing metropolitan region in the country. This is why the government is committed to the Traveston Crossing Dam project as part of a diverse strategy to provide a secure water supply. The Traveston Crossing Dam is the best and cheapest additional water supply option. It is the last remaining high-yield dam site in South-East Queensland and will provide enough water for around 800,000 people each day.

While the Bligh government is united on providing water security, it is clear that the members opposite are not. It should come as no surprise that the opposition’s Climate Proof SEQ water policy, announced in May, is not even available online anymore. The account has been suspended. I will not waste the time of the Table Office by tabling that lack of information. The members opposite have said that they would abandon plans for the Traveston Crossing Dam and instead build a desalination plant.
Mr Lucas: Which he just said had killed loggerhead turtles in his electorate.
Mr HINCHLIFFE: I take that interjection from the Deputy Premier. I also want to ask the question: build a desalination plant where and for how much?
Mr Elmes: Stafford!
Mr HINCHLIFFE: I can assure the member that there is plenty of infrastructure happening in Stafford that is providing great jobs for the people of the north side.

Those opposite do not have any answers. It is just another opposition policy myth. They want to build a desalination plant without a water grid--a water grid they voted against. They cannot connect it up. They have previously voted against a desalination plant, water demand reduction strategies, water rebates and the Traveston Crossing Dam. With no water grid, no water reduction strategy, no water rebates and no Traveston Dam, all that remains is a disconnected desalination plant. What they are describing is desalination plants everywhere that are not connected to anything. A Traveston Crossing Dam would have filled 10 times since 2006, during South-East Queensland’s worst drought on record.

The people of Queensland deserve a government that can plan for the future. In stark contrast to the opposition’s thought bubbles and backflips, the Bligh government remains clear in its commitment to water security for Queensland.

Mrs STUCKEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Why is the minister pursuing his policy of a master vendor IT contract list for all Queensland government IT contractors when his own independent experts have found that 700 Queensland IT workers will have their jobs destroyed by the decision?

Mr SCHWARTEN: I thank the honourable member for the question. I will be most tolerant in my answer to the honourable member; we know her sensitivity. We have an excellent relationship with the industry in Queensland. We have an IT working group in Queensland. I am aware of the unhappiness that exists in relation to this system. This government is charged with ensuring that we spend the money that we are given by the taxpayers efficiently. To get our AAA rating back, one of the issues is to ensure we get value for taxpayers’ money. I know that it is a foreign concept to those who sit opposite. I see the member for Gympie laughing about it, but I can assure him it is not a laughing matter.

The IT industry is very aware of what we are trying to do here. It is no different from other contracts with government. We are ensuring that industry is factored in to what we are doing. The bottom line is that over a long period of time a system has evolved of using contractors in the IT industry at a very high rate of pay and a very large cost to government. We are saying to the IT industry that we cannot continue down that path. We do not do it in any other industry and we should not be doing it in IT.

The cornerstone of what we are establishing is a proper and mature relationship in engaging contractors in the IT industry. The IT industry in Queensland, and in the world, is quite immature when it comes down to it. I do not expect the honourable member to understand this; it is far too complicated. It is much easier to give a throwaway line on it than to sit down and work out what the economics of this is all about.
Mrs Stuckey: Two reports advised you against it.

Mr SCHWARTEN: The honourable member never takes an interjection when she is on her feet. When I respond to her she takes offence and pleads that I am doing all sorts of things. I would seek your guidance on it, Mr Speaker. It is most difficult. She never takes an interjection herself, but she refuses to allow me to answer the question with her persistent, inane, immature and childish interjections while I am trying to give a sensible answer to this question. The reality is that the system that we are enacting is one--

Mrs Stuckey:
Seven hundred jobs. Yes or no?

Mr SCHWARTEN: Mr Speaker, please. I cannot respond to this member because she accuses me of threatening her. It would be better if she did not interject so that I can actually answer the question. The bottom line is: we are in a value-for-money contracting system. We are going to continue to do that.

Mr SPEAKER: As a general ruling--and I have been asked for that by the minister--I would say this: anybody who interjects does so at their own peril. I have said that repeatedly. If an honourable member finds something that the minister says objectionable after provoking a disorder then you do so at your own peril. I have said that repeatedly.
Mr Lucas: Then she goes out and says to the media something else.
Ms Spence: Go out and cry.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr Lucas: She goes out and complains to the media.
Mr Schwarten: You can’t cop it back.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr Johnson: You can’t cop it.
Mr Lucas: You’ve copped too many. That’s your problem.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The House will come to order.
Mr Schwarten: You can see sunshine from one ear to the other in you.
Mr Lucas: You are the Mickey Rourke of Queensland parliament.

Mr SPEAKER: The honourable the Deputy Premier, I warn you under the new standing order provisions. I have warned you previously. I have called order twice. Under the same provisions that I warned the honourable member for Clayfield I now warn you as well.

Mr PITT: My question is to the Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs. Can the minister please advise the House how the government is increasing educational opportunities for children with autism across Queensland?
Mr SPEAKER: Minister, you have one minute.

Ms PALASZCZUK: I thank the member for Mulgrave for his question. As we are all aware, every year about 350 children are diagnosed with autism and we know that autism has an impact on children’s social interaction, communication and capacity for imaginative thinking. However, we know that if we can get in early and help these children it is going to benefit them in the long run. That is why early intervention is very important.

I was very pleased last week to actually visit the electorate of the member for Mulgrave and go to the Edmonton centre for autism. The Bligh government has committed $170,000 to this centre and, through the advocacy of the member for Mulgrave, we are now able to commit a further $46,000, which means that this centre will be completed on time by the end of the year. This is great news for Cairns. It also means that we will be able to outreach up into the cape and we will be able to double the capacity at this centre from 32 children to 64 children. This is great news for Far North Queensland. It means that we are getting on with the job of delivering for children with a disability.
Mr SPEAKER: The time for questions has expired.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Health & Other Leg. A’ment Bill; Health Practitioner Reg. National Law Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 28 October (see p. 2924), on motion of Mr Lucas--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bills be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr FOLEY (Maryborough--Ind) (11.31 am): I rise to participate briefly in the cognate debate today. Most members in this House would be aware of the ill effects of smoking, especially where smoking takes place around children. For the life of me I cannot understand how any parent could drive down the road with a car full of kids while smoking cigarettes. Smoking in cars is an absolute no-no. We have introduced far-reaching legislation that talks about where people can and cannot smoke that is designed to keep clouds of smoke away from people who do not wish to smell like a chimney. I for one have been critical of some of these rules. I believe that what we have done in shopping centres is to create small smoking ghettos far too close to the entrances so that the smoke drifts in anyway. I am in favour of moving those smoking areas further away. In my own electorate I find groups of kids--all smoking--hanging around very close to the entrance. They congregate together and their behaviour can be interpreted as threatening.

Obviously it is a no-brainer to put in place legislation that outlaws smoking in cars that contain kids. Dropping ash is a fire hazard if people wear nylon clothing. However, more than that, effectively entrapping children in a car full of smoke and undertaking, say, a four-hour drive is obviously going to be rather detrimental to their health.

Cutting red tape to allow professionals to work anywhere in Australia without requiring additional registration is a great idea as long as the process of vetting them in the first place is entirely thorough. If someone slips through the net vis-à-vis a Dr Patel--we have had many cases in Queensland where doctors of dubious skill level--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! There is an issue in relation to that matter which is before the courts. I ask you to be very careful what you say.

Mr FOLEY: Sorry about that. There have been a number of high-profile cases involving medical practitioners who are less than skilled for the jobs that they are undertaking. Heaven knows we need a regime with national transference. My point is this: the difficulty is that, if a person slips through the net in one state and then has an as-of-right registration in all other states, they have effectively been given carte blanche to move out of one area with less than desirable practising skills and move to another area where everyone would think they are fine because they have been checked out and have been given national accreditation. So long as that national accreditation is entirely robust, that provision is probably a good idea.

Cutting red tape is certainly a great idea. In my own area they have been able to source GPs. However, because the feds have not recognised it as an area of special need, they basically sit around twiddling their thumbs for months on end, unable to work or feed their families and the medical practices cannot afford to keep them on staff. We have had a number of cases like that in our public health system on the Fraser Coast as well.

Mandatory reporting of professional misconduct across all professions is a noble and worthwhile cause, although I would also sound some warning bells here. We do not want to see a culture of getting back or of dobbing. Every single member of this House would have had experience of people who make salacious complaints on very minor grounds. That can make the life of a health practitioner or any other person absolutely unbearable. This is a real problem. Let me give an example. Let us just say a doctor, or a nurse for that matter, has experienced a tragedy in their family and they are suffering from depression as a result, which is entirely treatable with modern drugs that are nonaddictive by nature, and they seek treatment for it. If I was a doctor, I would be very wary about to whom I went or to whom I disclosed any particular medical problems for fear that that doctor says, ‘In my opinion that person is unsuitable to practise.’ It does not matter whether they are or are not fit to practise; it is almost a regime where a person is guilty until proven innocent.
Mr Lucas: And what if they did and they injured a patient?

Mr FOLEY: That comes back to what I said before that as long as the process of selection in the first instance is entirely robust and they have that national accreditation. Let me clarify this. If there is any hint of professional misconduct, sexual impropriety or bad medical practices, I would 100 per cent support that provision. But taking a broadbrush approach whereby any person for any particular reason could be named and shamed without any proof can cause a great deal of distress. If that doctor is already suffering from depression and all of a sudden someone decides to be even more injurious in their application, that could spiral them significantly further downhill rather than helping them in their recovery. We all recognise that, because of the pressure that medical professionals work under, especially in the state system, they will succumb to all manner of health conditions that in someone’s opinion might make them unsuitable to work. We need to be very careful that that situation does not turn into a witch-hunt or a ‘get back quick’. As I said, the mandatory reporting of all of the other issues of sexual misconduct or inappropriate treatment is an absolute no-brainer. We have seen many instances of injury caused to patients and we could not come down too harshly with regard to that particular area.

The national scheme commencing on 1 July 2010 recognises 10 health professions. It is almost easier to say which ones are not covered by the list, because these days there are so many other categories such as music therapists. I notice there are an additional four professions included which are medical radiation, occupational therapists and also Chinese medicine practitioners, and I would ask the minister for a clarification: does that include acupuncture, or is it more herbal medicine?
Mr Lucas: I will check that, but part of it is having a degree of control under Chinese medicine as well to make sure that they are appropriately qualified people and not people who claim to be that.
Mr FOLEY: If the minister can let me know.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order!
Member for Maryborough, I will allow that to occur this time. Otherwise you should wait until the consideration in detail stage if you have requests for details like that.

Mr FOLEY: Okay. I note that there are Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health practitioners. I am not aware of what they are. I would like to at some stage be informed of that as well. Dental technicians and speech pathologists are currently registered in Queensland and have not yet been included in the national scheme but will continue to be registered on a state by state basis. I think this idea of registration and vetting is an excellent idea. I think it needs to be across all of the medical disciplines. My wife is a medical laboratory scientist, a pathology scientist, with some 30 years experience. That profession does not seem to be in that list. Also, there are a number of other professions like music therapists. Maybe a better way to go would be to look at the registration of all parahealth professionals and then weed out the ones that are not suitable.

The overall bill is a step in the right direction. As I said, there are only just those couple of things that do alarm me. As members we have all seen the ongoing usage of bodies like the CMC and so forth for complaints. It is the same in other portfolios. Every policeman has had complaints made against them because someone did not like getting a traffic ticket. We do not want to see a regime like that.
Debate, on motion of Mr Foley, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Criminal Organisation Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (11.41 am): I present a bill for an act to provide for the making of declarations and orders for the purpose of disrupting and restricting the activities of organisations involved in serious criminal activity, and of their members and associates, and to make related amendments to other acts. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Criminal Organisation Bill 2009, explanatory notes.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (11.41 am): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: The bill seeks to disrupt and restrict the activities of criminal organisations and their members and associates. Members of outlaw motorcycle gangs and other criminal organisations have been involved in activities such as attempted murder, extortion, drug manufacturing and distribution and pose a threat to Queensland. In response to outlaw motorcycle gang violence in southern states, other states and territories around Australia have passed legislation aimed at disrupting the activities of criminal organisations.

The extraordinary powers provided for in this bill are necessary to send a clear message that Queensland will not be seen to be or to have become a safe haven for criminal organisations who may be tempted to move their operations from other states and territories. In developing this bill it should be noted, however, that we have adopted a cautious approach in light of the experience in other jurisdictions, insisting on the inclusion of a range of safeguards to ensure an appropriate balance is achieved.

It should be noted that the Queensland Police Service already possesses extensive powers to attack crime, including those powers set out in the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000. The powers set out in this bill will augment, but not replace, those existing powers to combat serious organised criminal activity in Queensland. It is anticipated that the powers provided in this act will be used in the most serious cases as a further extraordinary tool in the law enforcement armoury.

The structure and methods of organised crime pose a challenge to the traditional processes of the criminal justice system which are designed to prosecute and punish proven criminal activity committed by individuals. The long-term disruption of ongoing criminal enterprises may require more than isolated prosecutions of individual members. Furthermore, successful prosecutions of members of organised criminal groups have previously been hindered by intimidation and violence towards witnesses and investigators.

The bill provides an additional method for combating organised criminal activity. First, the bill creates a mechanism for the Police Commissioner to make a civil application to the Supreme Court to obtain a declaration that an organisation is a ‘criminal organisation’--namely, one whose members associate for the purpose of engaging in or conspiring to engage in serious criminal activity, and where the organisation is an unacceptable risk to the safety, welfare or order of the community.

The Supreme Court declaration forms the basis on which the Police Commissioner can apply to the supreme court to obtain further civil orders, including orders against the organisation itself, members of the criminal organisation and associates of the criminal organisation. Once the declaration is in place the Police Commissioner can make civil applications to the Supreme Court for control orders against individuals. A declaration that an organisation is a criminal organisation may also assist in making public safety orders and fortification removal orders. The civil standard of proof applies to all of these applications.

A control order can prohibit a member of a declared organisation from engaging in certain behaviours which may facilitate serious criminal behaviour--for example, obtaining a weapons licence, obtaining employment in the gaming or liquor industry, associating with other members and associates of criminal organisations or recruiting new members into criminal organisations. The bill creates an offence of contravening a control order which carries a maximum penalty of three years imprisonment for a first offence and five years imprisonment for any subsequent offence.

A public safety order can prohibit an individual or group of persons from entering a premises, specified area or attending an event. The Supreme Court can make a public safety order if satisfied that the presence of the individual or group at a premises or area or event poses a serious risk to public safety or security and may be made for any period it considers necessary but no longer than six months.

In urgent circumstances, a public safety order made without notice to an individual or group of persons can only remain in force for a period of 24 hours unless the court directs otherwise. This will enable the commissioner to respond to serious threats to public safety or security even in circumstances where that threat emerges suddenly and outside of court business hours. An offence of contravening a public safety order is created under the act. The offence carries a maximum penalty of one year imprisonment.

Fortification removal orders can be sought by police from the Supreme Court to require an individual or organisation to modify or remove fortifications from particular premises. Fortifications pose a significant obstacle in the execution of search warrants on criminal organisations. The bill creates an offence of hindering the removal or modification of a fortification. The offence carries a maximum penalty of five years imprisonment.

A central feature of the scheme provided for in the bill is the use of criminal intelligence. In all civil applications under this bill, the commissioner may apply to the Supreme Court to have certain evidence declared to be criminal intelligence. Once the Supreme Court has declared the evidence to be criminal intelligence, it cannot be disclosed to any person including the respondent to an application or their legal representatives.

In order for the evidence to be declared criminal intelligence, the Police Commissioner must satisfy the Supreme Court that the evidence would prejudice criminal investigations, identify a confidential source of information, or endanger the safety of another person. This allows the court to hear important evidence against individuals, organisations and groups whilst maintaining the physical safety of informants and covert operatives and minimising the threat of prejudicing a criminal investigation. The bill creates an offence of unlawful disclosure of criminal intelligence which carries a maximum penalty of one year imprisonment.

The bill includes significant safeguards which provide a balance between any abrogation of democratic principles and procedural fairness and ensuring that the bill is effective in achieving its objectives whilst protecting the personal security and safety of covert police officers. At the core of the safeguards is the role of the Supreme Court in hearing and determining all applications.

Further, a Criminal Organisation Public Interest Monitor will monitor and report on all applications under the act involving criminal intelligence. Annual legislative reviews will be undertaken by the Criminal Organisation Public Interest Monitor and a retired judicial officer. The parliamentary Law, Justice and Safety Committee will monitor the role and review the performance of the Criminal Organisation Public Interest Monitor, will report to the Legislative Assembly on any matter about the COPIM, and will examine each of the annual reports tabled in the Legislative Assembly. The bill also contains a seven-year sunset clause.

The bill creates the roles and functions of the Criminal Organisation Public Interest Monitor, which is akin to the role of an amicus curiae or friend of the court. The COPIM will carry out a similar function to that undertaken by the current Public Interest Monitor for controlled operation and telecommunication interception warrants.

The involvement of the COPIM was considered essential given that one of the centrepieces of the new regime is the use of ‘criminal intelligence’ which is presented to a court in the absence of the respondent. The COPIM will be present at all hearings under the bill to assist the court in testing the appropriateness and validity of applications.

The bill provides for annual reports to be completed by both the COPIM and a retired Supreme Court judge. The bill provides for both reports to be tabled in the Legislative Assembly. As noted previously, the bill provides for this legislation to be reviewed by a retired Supreme Court judge five years after its commencement to determine whether it is operating effectively and meeting its objectives, and the bill also provides for a report of this review to be tabled in the Legislative Assembly.

The bill also amends a number of acts. A number of offences in the Criminal Code are amended by the insertion of new circumstances of aggravation. For example, the maximum penalty of seven years for the offence of retaliation against a judicial officer, juror or witness will increase to 10 years if the act is done in relation to a proceeding before a court under the proposed legislation. The amendments are necessary to deter tactics of intimidation and violence towards potential witnesses and law enforcement investigators.

In order to ensure the physical safety of criminal organisation informants, the bill amends the Criminal Code by the insertion of a new offence of obtaining or disclosing secret information about an informant’s identity. The offence carries a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment.

The objects of the bill provide that the parliament does not intend that the powers under the legislation will be exercised in a way that diminishes the freedom of persons to participate in advocacy, protest, dissent or industrial action. Organisations involved in serious criminal activity pose a threat to Queensland and challenge the criminal justice system, which is generally designed to prosecute and punish isolated crimes committed by individuals.
This bill provides an alternative method in combating organised criminal activity and will ensure Queensland does not become a safe haven for criminal organisations. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Springborg, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Health & Other Leg. A’ment Bill; Health Practitioner Reg. National Law Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from p. 3029, on motion of Mr Lucas--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bills be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr McLINDON (Beaudesert--LNP) (11.51 am): I rise to speak to the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2009 and the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill 2009, which are being treated as cognate bills. The bill proposes a number of changes which can be seen in the amendments to the various acts. This legislation brings in mandatory misconduct provisions. As the minister stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The new provisions differ from the lapsed bill and will allow Queensland’s new mandatory reporting requirements to be transitioned to the new national scheme once it is introduced.
XML.Hansard-Body: In effect, there will be a national scheme. However, the Medical Board of Queensland will be made responsible for the enforcement of this misconduct reporting process as the administrator. The minister stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Board will undertake a communication campaign to inform the medical profession of the new obligation ...
XML.Hansard-Body: It would be wise if the minister and his department considered the feedback from health professionals before they undertook that campaign. I suggest that, alongside the campaigns to make people aware of their obligations, the government includes its own key responsibility to address the system flaws still inherent in the reporting processes.

Clinicians can only work within the system they have, and the government cannot solely rely on crudely forcing clinicians to make these subjective judgements and then report. This will not solve the problem because it is not a silver bullet. We must remember the amount of surgical and clinical audits that clinicians already undertake to monitor patient care. At what point are we actually impeding a clinician from what they are there to do--that is, treat the patients and improve their quality of life?

I suggest the government goes back and looks at the current processes and refine them and look at addressing screening and reporting problems to make the system work more effectively in the first principle, rather than engage in the consequences of more duplication. Duplication is the last thing Queensland’s health system needs. The government cannot entertain information awareness campaigns until it is aware of all the issues involved itself. Simply making doctors report inadequacies within the system without further investigation or follow-up is not a true way forward.
In its submission to the Senate Community Affairs Committee on the exposure draft of the health practitioner regulation national law in July, the AMA said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The definition of reportable conduct requires further consultation with the health professions. In effect, the relevant provisions in the draft Bill represent new mandatory reporting requirements across the health professions, as well as for the medical profession who are subject to existing state/territory laws. The draft definition in the Bill has a very broad application and there are considerable risks that health professionals will over-report, or not know when to report. We support suggestions by other health profession groups for educative scenarios to be provided to registrants so they have some certainty of what would be considered in scope as reportable conduct, before case law is established.
The medical defence organisations will provide full and detailed submissions on the mandatory reporting requirements and we ask that these submissions be given full and careful consideration.
Spouses, treating doctors and other professionals ... such as the doctors’ advisory health service, should be included in the exemptions to the mandatory reporting requirements in clause 156.

Further, the draft Bill should expressly preclude medical practitioners who participate in quality assurance activities in accordance with the Commonwealth Health Insurance Act 1973 from any requirement to report reportable conduct identified during those activities.
XML.Hansard-Body: The government must ensure that these considerations have been taken into account. The government must remember that it, too, has a responsibility with its own reporting systems. I recently wrote to the Auditor-General on what is a clear contrast between the data coming out of the government’s health reports and the reality experienced by patients in the Beaudesert region. I know that the shadow health minister, Mark McArdle, has exposed the widespread instances of fraudulent approaches to reporting ED outcomes and has proposed measures for a universal, open and accountable reporting framework that better reflects the emergency departments and also the patients’ experiences in those departments. And of course we have heard from the Auditor-General’s report, which outlined the following: the lack of transparent links between the state and district service plans, no clear prioritisation of district needs, no clear link between service plans and funding allocation, and no monitoring, evaluation or reporting framework in place.

A recommendation of the Australian Council on Healthcare Standards suggests incidents like access block be reported by health services as part of key performance indicators for resources, and I suggest the government thinks long and hard about how the KPIs are employed in the Queensland health system. To place an unhealthy amount of emphasis on directors coming under budget is resulting in this government directly encouraging corners to be cut, and there is far too much emphasis placed on that. Studies in 2008 drew attention to the fact that there must be a direct nexus between financial accountability and clinical care to ensure clinical outcomes of financial decisions are clear and apparent.

The government should not simply demand medical directors come under a financial threshold by whatever means necessary and reward them through that mechanism. This is lazy policy and it is detrimental policy. It would pay the government to heed the words of Nobel recipient Lord Rutherford, who said in his laboratory to his colleagues, ‘We haven’t got the money so we’ve got to think.’ The government should not place unacceptable burdens on medical directors simply through budgetary KPIs but should actually divert that energy to refining health service reporting processes in a positive way whilst ensuring efficient front-line services.

There can be no other objective but setting and maintaining high standards of patient service and care, and this must remain the priority. It is important that the community has confidence not only in their doctors but also in the system that sets the foundation for this care. On this point, I cautiously welcome the increased responsibility of nurse practitioners. I am cautious and can only be suspicious of this, given the government’s record for subcontracting certain responsibilities in health care. As stated, nurse practitioners will often be the first point of contact for patients with work related injuries who present at primary healthcare facilities and emergency departments for initial diagnosis and treatment. However, I caution against even entertaining the idea of going down the road of diluting the role of a nurse and nurse practitioners to that of a bureaucrat on the one hand and lumping more responsibility on them with the other.
Mr Lucas interjected.
Mr Robertson interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! The member for Beaudesert is on his feet. I would ask all members to listen carefully.

Mr McLINDON: However, I caution against even entertaining the idea of going down the road of diluting the role of a nurse and nurse practitioners to that of a bureaucrat on the one hand and lumping more responsibility on them with the other. That is a recipe for disaster. I caution against the government simply turning existing nurses into nurse practitioners. This is not good policy because that simply results in fewer nurses. So I would suggest the government have a comprehensive strategy for dealing with this very complex issue.

Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (11.57 am): The Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is designed to amend a number of acts. It is imperative that we support any attempt to improve protection for patients and ensure Queenslanders receive the best possible health care. For too long, the underfunding of Queensland Health and the increasing levels of introduced bureaucracy have resulted in conditions where patient care has been compromised. While the LNP is supportive of the intent of the legislation, there are several amendments that we will move to ensure that confidence in doctors by all patients, including their colleagues, is not threatened by any requirement to break a patient’s confidentiality. While we do not want to see impaired doctors putting the safety and wellbeing of patients at risk, we do not want to see doctors avoid their own health problems for fear of being reported. We need to return to the absolute faith we previously had in the profession and trust that a doctor will not knowingly risk the life of a patient, not give one of his colleagues the ultimate responsibility to report.

Under the bill, it will be an offence for a person to smoke in a vehicle if someone under the age of 16 is present in the vehicle. This part protects the health and wellbeing of our minors. Making it illegal to smoke in a vehicle used for business purposes when another person is present is over the top. Adults are legally able to make their own choice and suffer the consequences. We are becoming a nanny state by eroding the rights of our citizens. Most companies have their own smoking policy which determines where and when employees can smoke. Most companies ban smoking in vehicles anyway. Why does the government have to add its draconian attempts to control the equation? Do our police officers have that much time on their hands that they can afford to police another ridiculous piece of legislation and determine whether the car is being used for business purposes, issue fines accordingly, and then spend hours completing the ridiculous amount of paperwork required?

Other amendments include provisions to allow nurse practitioners to issue medical certificates for minor injuries. This makes sense. Our doctors, especially in communities dominated by highly regulated industries such as the mining industry, are overwhelmed with requests for medical certificates. This will alleviate some of the pressure from the doctors and allow them to deal with sick patients and not satisfy the requirements of overregulated industries. In the case of Forsayth, years ago nurses were able to dispense medication that had been prescribed by doctors because of the unavailability of doctors and pharmacists in the area. This provision was outlawed, and we had a terribly frustrating and dangerous time during massive flooding when patients ran out of their medication and had no local avenue to provide it when the floods remained for three weeks. These changes will hopefully lead to greater recognition of the effort and professionalism of the health workers working in rural and remote areas where there is no available doctor.

The Health Practitioner Regulated National Law Bill 2009 will hopefully also lead to more equitable outcomes for those rural practices that rely on the work of locums. The right to private practice is one small incentive to encourage general practitioners to work in rural communities. Recently we had a ridiculous situation where a busy rural practice with the right to private practice had to wait until a provider number was provided. His public provider number was fast-tracked, which allowed the locum to see patients in an adjoining hospital, but he could not work in the practice without a number. All the paperwork was lodged within appropriate time limits, and the public provider number was fast-tracked. The private one, however, was not. Without this, he was unable to refer patients for X-rays and specialist appointments, and patients were unable to receive the Medicare rebate. Every time a locum changes location he requires a new provider number. This is bureaucratic overkill--
Mr Lucas: I am happy to look into it for you if you want. It is a federal issue, but has it been sorted out?
Mr KNUTH: Yes, we have worked on that, Minister.
Dr Douglas: There is one more in this morning’s paper.

Mr KNUTH: This is bureaucratic overkill and is completely unsustainable in rural communities where it is difficult to attract permanent doctors and where we rely on services from local doctors. While I acknowledge the announcement by the member for Mulgrave to make provision to call for tenders for a CT scanner for the Atherton Tablelands, and I appreciate the minister looking into an issue I raised in parliament in a question to him about six to eight weeks ago, I want to say that that CT scanner was pushed for more than five years ago and was promised in May this year. It is very important for the tablelands people as we have a thousand patients going up to Cairns. We have medical practitioners who have been threatening to resign if the scanner is not provided. Some of those medical surgeons will leave. They are in the process of leaving, and I encourage the minister to give us all the support we can get in looking for provisions for other medical surgeons to take over those surgeons’ places.

We need a CT scanner for the Atherton Tablelands. As I say, a thousand per year are going to Cairns to get access to these scanners. This is also putting pressure on the Cairns Base Hospital surgery. That would relieve that pressure off the Cairns Base Hospital and allow those people to stay in the Tablelands, which is very important and important for the health system in the Cairns Base Hospital.

The previous health minister knows that we have been pushing for a dementia unit based at the Eventide Aged Care Facility. It is a wonderful facility which was built in 1929. It is the biggest issue going besides this CT scanner. It is probably the most passionate issue that I have confronted. In an area with more than 13,000 people they are having to send their loved ones who have dementia on 1,000-kilometre round trips. We have 80-year-old ladies who see their loved ones being sent 1,000 kilometres away when we have this wonderful facility. We have a ward there--Pandanus--which is closed. It is sitting there laying idle--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! Member for Dalrymple, I would ask you to come back to the bill. I have given you quite a bit of latitude.
Mr KNUTH: I wanted to bring those things that I have mentioned to the attention of the House.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (12.04 pm): I rise today to contribute to the cognate debate on the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill and the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill. The Queensland health system has been in a dire state under this government. It has been characterised by neglect, mismanagement, a lack of forethought and inappropriate responses to crisis. The minister even publicly admits he cannot control soaring hospital waiting lists. This begs the question: is there anything the minister can control? These bills are another example of this government falling short of expectations. These bills do introduce some good initiatives, but in some areas the bills go too far and in others not far enough. That is despite feedback from the community.

The opposition will be moving some crucial amendments to these bills. The first of these proposes four necessary exceptions to the harsh mandatory reporting provisions. The second amendment we will be proposing will extend the ban on smoking in business vehicles to private vehicles as well. This will make these laws more easily enforced and further protect the health of Queenslanders.

The health amendment bill amends the Medical Practitioners Registration Act 2001, the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act 1999 and introduces a system of mandatory reporting of professional misconduct by doctors. This system of mandatory reporting is also a feature of the health practitioners bill. It is good to see the government finally trying to improve protection for patients and ensure Queenslanders receive the best possible care.

Mandatory reporting will increase protection of the public by enhancing the Medical Board’s ability to identify instances of serious misconduct for doctors. However, it still exhibits major flaws. Mandatory reporting legislation is already in operation in New South Wales as of late last year. In a short time the industry has already heard of instances where practitioners have raised concerns about discussing matters with other medical professionals due to fear of being expelled. AMA Queensland has argued that sick doctors would be driven underground, putting patients’ lives at risk. AMAQ President, Dr Mason Stevenson, has said that the bill removes a fundamental right of medical confidentiality and that it should not extend to doctors treating doctors.

It is concerning that doctors will be required to report doctors seeking medical treatment. It could lead to doctors not seeking medical assistance at an early stage due to a fear of being reported. That could mean that sick doctors will continue to work without telling anyone, putting patients’ lives at risk. These fears are shared by the AMAQ, the AMA, the Medical Board and the Doctors Health Advisory Service. Some of these concerns about mandatory reporting can be allayed by supporting the amendment the opposition will be moving to the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. This amendment will remove the requirement for registrants to give notice about reportable misconduct in four particular circumstances where it is undesirable to require them to do so. The first of these is where the first registrant is a spouse of the second registrant. This amendment will protect the marriage relationship. Spouses would, however, still be required to report the misconduct in instances of sexual misconduct. Other proposed exemptions to the mandatory reporting requirement include where the conduct has or is likely to have already been reported, where the first registrant becomes aware of the misconduct as a result of a protected confidence or while providing a professional service to the registrant.

The Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill amends the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 to ban smoking in cars with children under the age of 16. The opposition has been calling for this kind of measure for a number of years. It is good to see Labor finally supporting such a measure to save the lives of Queenslanders. This measure may be perceived as an intrusion into an individual’s private domain. It is similar to the prohibition of mobile phone use while driving. While enforcement in both cases has and would prove to be challenging, they are necessary measures for the public interest. Smoking in cars carrying children is currently banned in three states--South Australia, Tasmania and New South Wales. In Tasmania the age is 18. In New South Wales it is 16, which leads to the consistency of enforcement argument given the Coolangatta region shares a border with New South Wales.

In South Australia the ban commenced in 2007 and 110 people were booked within the first year. The penalty was $75. Under the proposed legislation, a maximum penalty of 20 penalty units, which represents a sum of $2,000, would apply. It has been proposed that police will enforce the ban by issuing $200 on-the-spot fines to those contravening the ban.

There is strong community support for banning smoking in cars carrying children. In October 2007 Queensland Health released a discussion paper on Queensland’s smoking legislation. Of the 588 submissions received from the general public, 89 per cent called for a ban on smoking in cars carrying children. This measure is consistent with the current legislation prohibiting smoking in enclosed spaces such as boats, trains and aircraft.

The minister told us in his second reading speech that each year more than 3,400 Queenslanders die from smoking, and passive smoking is an enormous part of this risk. In Queensland smoking related hospital admissions cost more than $217 million every year. The burden is unsustainable.

In general, the prevalence of people who smoke is reducing, particularly those who smoke in their cars. Some 87 per cent of car owners surveyed in 2005 reported that smoking does not occur in their car. Of smokers, only 31 per cent with children below 14 years of age reported they still smoke in their cars. In Queensland there are still 276,000 smokers with children under 16 years of age in their household.

Environmental tobacco smoke is a complex mixture of chemicals, containing over 4,000 chemical compounds including 60 known cancer causing chemicals. In children the risk from exposure to passive smoking includes bronchitis, pneumonia, asthma, ear infections and sudden infant death syndrome.

Proposed new section 26VC provides that a person must not smoke in a motor vehicle if the vehicle is on a road or road related areas and another person in the vehicle is under 16 years of age. The dangers of smoking are present in all vehicles to people of all ages. That is why the opposition will be moving an amendment to extend the restriction on smoking in a vehicle when others are present to include private vehicles as well as business vehicles and regardless of age. Many people use the same vehicle for both business and private purposes. This amendment will also assist in enforcement by police. There is no longer a need to determine whether a vehicle is for private or business use before investigating further as to the age of the occupants of the vehicle.

The Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill further protects Queenslanders from the danger of smoking by amending the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 and the Tobacco and Other Smoking Products Act 1998. The proposed amendments restrict the use of smoking related products for tobacco advertising and allow local governments to regulate smoking at public transport waiting points and pedestrian malls.

Again, the Queensland Health review demonstrated a level of community support for these measures. Some 78 per cent of people supported banning smoking in pedestrian malls. Some 81 per cent supported banning smoking at public transport waiting points. These measures further reduce Queensland’s exposure to smoking by allowing local government to prohibit it in areas where people are involuntarily crowded.

In conclusion, I urge the government to support the opposition’s amendment. These bills bring in so many good, strong measures to repair the long-damaged Queensland health system and generally improve the health of Queenslanders. I hope the government will soften its approach and see that these amendments make sense otherwise the other good initiatives proposed will come undone.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (12.12 pm): I rise to support the health bills that are being debated cognately. These bills amend, among other things, a number of acts to ensure better health outcomes for Queenslanders. In these times of unprecedented population growth, an increasingly ageing population and an explosion in chronic disease across the state, the nation and the world it is vital that governments look at all the ways they can ensure the optimum levels of good health in our community.

The Bligh government is a responsible government that puts the health of Queenslanders first. Extending the protection of non-smoking areas, particularly for young people, to outdoor public areas such as within 10 metres of playgrounds, within the patrolled and flagged areas on beaches, in front of all public buildings, indoor and outdoor eating places and large outdoor events, public buildings, major sport stadiums and in all vehicles where young children are present will provide a healthier environment for everyone in a wider variety of social situations in their lives.

It also provides a strong example for young people that smoking is not a social activity. These provisions will increase the enjoyment of public events for the vast majority of the population who will not be disturbed by smoke in confined outdoor areas such as at concerts or sports events where they cannot easily move away. That means that they will be less likely to be passively smoking and in danger of lung and other health issues later in life.

The bill also empowers local governments to enforce new measures in open air shopping malls and public transport waiting areas. The bill also ensures that smoking related products or brands can no longer be advertised ensuring that young people are not getting the suggestion that certain smoking related brands or indeed the act of smoking itself is cool. These provisions are about preventing the onset of health issues later in life meaning fewer people go over the cliff and instead are redirected to safer paths and thus healthier lifestyles.

The amendments to the health practitioner registration boards institute strong, mandatory reporting measures ensuring that patients get the best outcomes. In fact, medical practitioners who become aware of or reasonably suspect reportable misconduct may face disciplinary action under the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act. Health professionals are bound by a strict duty of confidentiality under the Health Services Act but this bill adds three exceptions to allow necessary disclosure in specific circumstances.

The first is an exception when the safety of a child is involved such as when a doctor suspects abuse due to the type of injuries a child is admitted with. These new disclosures are not about informing the department of child safety or the police as these provisions are already within the act but informing people who are willing and able to keep the child safe such as a family member.

The second exception will mean the director-general of Queensland Health can disclose patient information to lawyers representing a patient. The third exception is to ensure the safety of the community in controlling illness and to provide treatment for the sick. Each of those exceptions will provide a greater degree of protection for the patient involved and the community.

Another amendment in this bill that will improve outcomes for patients is the one that allows nurse practitioners to sign workers compensation certificates so people with work related injuries, who have been treated by a nurse practitioner in an emergency department, do not have to wait until a doctor can examine them and sign their workers compensation certificate. This means shorter stays in the ED and a better use of medical resources.

This Labor government is working hard to produce the best health system in the country and we are succeeding. Our health system has never been better and it is continuing to improve. The Redcliffe Hospital in my electorate has had huge upgrades in the last three years, not the least of which are the new specialist, allied health and emergency departments. The hospital had the first nurse practitioners working in ED departments. It is a best practice program that has made waiting times for category 4 and 5 patients much shorter. There will also be a children’s ED in the near future. In the last 18 months the government has upgrade the number of doctors and nurses in the hospital as it has done right across the state. The people of Redcliffe are proud of their hospital and the many proactive lifestyle programs it offers them. The amendments in this bill will increase the day-to-day efficiencies of our health system and will go a long way towards safeguarding the health of many Queenslanders so that they will have healthier lives and will not need to use hospital services as often in their lives.

I commend the minister for the amendments in this bill that will go a long way to preventing many lifestyle illnesses and will ensure many children can grow up safely. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP) (12.19 pm): I rise to lend my support to the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill and the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill. I would like to speak mainly to the amendments that the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill make to protect the health of our children and the wider community from the dangers of smoking. This bill contains an important amendment that will ban smoking in cars with children to protect the health of young children and babies. In Queensland, there are 276,000 smokers with children under 16 years of age in the household. The levels of tobacco smoke in a vehicle are very high. Young children involuntarily exposed to tobacco smoke in a very confined environment, such as a car, have significantly increased health risks including bronchitis, pneumonia, asthma, ear infections and sudden infant death syndrome. This ban is about setting a community standard of not smoking around children. As a parent of a young child myself, I am delighted to support it.

Comprehensive smoke-free laws are already helping to the protect children from exposure to tobacco smoke in public places. Queensland’s tobacco laws protect young people, with bans on smoking within 10 metres of children’s playgrounds; between the flags at patrolled beaches; in all public buildings; indoors and outdoors at all restaurants, cafes and eating places; at large outdoor events; within four metres of almost all building entrances; at major sports stadiums; and, with this amendment, in all vehicles where children are present.

The definition of ‘motor vehicle’ used in the bill captures any vehicle that is propelled by a motor that forms part of the vehicle. These amendments will also apply regardless of how many passengers may be seated in the vehicle. Examples include passenger cars, including convertibles or those with a sunroof, trucks, buses and utilities. The offence of smoking in a motor vehicle will not apply to an aircraft, boat or train. These types of vehicles or vessels are included as an enclosed place under part 2B of the Tobacco and Other Smoking Products Act. Therefore, smoking is prohibited within these types of vehicles.

The offence of smoking in a motor vehicle with a child present will apply on public roads including a busway, a toll road, a bridge, railway crossings, a tunnel, a dividing strip, a shoulder including a kerb or unsealed side of the road, and a footpath or nature strip adjacent to a road. The offence will also apply to a vehicle parked or moving in a public car park, including in a shopping centre car park. It was necessary to include in the legislation road related areas to deter drivers or smokers from pulling over and smoking in the car while it was parked before resuming their travel.

The statutory minimum age of criminal responsibility is 10 years. Therefore, any person over the age of 10 years is able to be issued with a fine for committing this offence. However, it is not intended to target young people for this offence. The purpose of this legislation is to reduce the exposure of young children to environmental tobacco smoke. The legislation aims to prevent or reduce the number of parents and carers, or older friends and siblings, who are smoking in motor vehicles with children present. The amendments create a defence for a person issued with a fine for this offence if the person can prove at the time of the offence that the person honestly and reasonably believed that no person in the vehicle was under 16 years of age.

These amendments will also enable the passengers of motors vehicles to be asked for their age or date of birth to assist police in determining whether a person is aged under 16 years.
