We are protecting and ensuring that health practitioners are suitably trained and qualified, cutting red tape, establishing a single national register and simple registration processes, and establishing nationally consistent standards--all of those things together obviously will ensure that we have the best doctors in Australia. I support a national register. Anyone who does not really does not understand that Queensland is a small state and we need to have the best qualified doctors. These bills go a long way towards addressing that.

My congratulations go to the minister and his staff for bringing these amendments forward. They go a long way to implementing prevention, protection and regulation for the public. I believe they will bring about much of the cultural change that we often need in the very important area of health. I commend the bills to the House.

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP) (3.29 pm): I rise to speak in this cognate debate on the health bills. The Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to amend a number of areas including mandatory reporting for doctors to report on other doctor’s misconduct and introduces laws in respect of banning smoking in vehicles which are carrying children under 16. It also covers sections in relation to the Health Quality and Complaints Commission Act and confidentiality of information.

A very important area in this legislation will enable nurse practitioners to issue a workers compensation medical certificate for minor injury at a patient’s initial attendance. In 2004 the Queensland government made a commitment to amend relevant legislation to allow for full implementation of the nurse practitioner role to enable nurse practitioners to function in stand-alone roles. The aim of this initiative was to reduce the demands on the health workforce by better utilising medical resources to improve health service delivery, particularly in rural and remote areas.

A nurse practitioner is a registered nurse who has extensive clinical experience and who has completed a post graduate masters degree. The masters program is to function autonomously and collaboratively in an advanced and expanded clinical role. In larger centres they work side by side with doctors and other health professionals in an interdisciplinary team in many different speciality areas.

To be eligible for nurse practitioner endorsement, registered nurses must meet the minimum professional and competency standards outlined in the Queensland Nursing Council’s Policy on the regulation of nurse practitioners in Queensland . The nurse practitioner role is innovative and integral to the health workforce reform agenda in Australia and critical to outback Queensland.

The nurse practitioner role includes assessment and management of clients using knowledge and skills which may include detailed health assessment and diagnosis. Each nurse practitioner’s scope of practice is highly individual and context specific. Health management protocols provide clinical guidelines for medication related practice.

Back in 2005 only two nurse practitioners were employed in Queensland Health. Today there are now 84 registered nurses authorised to practice as nurse practitioners in Queensland. Of these, 54 are employed within Queensland Health positions. It is predicted that nurse practitioner positions will continue to grow over the next three years due to the government’s investment in workforce development. Queensland Health annually allocates $160,000 in scholarships to enable registered nurses to complete master level qualifications. There are currently nine of these positions existing in the Mount Isa Health Service District.

Residents in my remote communities are very dependent on their local nurse. I know as resident of Dajarra for many, many years that our family was very dependent on the excellent skills of our local nurses, and I pay tribute to the many nurses who have served in that little town over the years past and present. With the increased training and responsibilities, the nurse practitioner role has certainly reduced travelling requirements for patients and in many instances--again from personal experience--there is a high degree of trust and patient satisfaction with services provided by nurse practitioners.

A further benefit for isolated patients were the amendments in 2004 of the Health (Drugs and Poisons) Regulation to enable nurse practitioners to prescribe controlled and restricted drugs under a protocol approved by the chief executives of Queensland Health. In 2005 amendments were also made to the Radiation Safety Regulation to enable nurse practitioners to request X-rays.

Nurse practitioners are often the first point of contact with patients with work related injuries, most certainly in our rural and remote communities. They see and treat patients on a daily basis, and treatments range from sprains, strains, fractures, wounds and lacerations. Although nurse practitioners are able to provide the necessary health care for these non-complex work related injuries and illnesses, referral of these patients to a medical officer is nevertheless often required for the sole purpose of obtaining a workers compensation medical certificate.

The referral of a patient to a doctor only to obtain a workers compensation medical certificate for an injury such as a sprain or laceration may mean a long drive to a bigger centre or being dependent on the next RFDS clinic, which in most instances are held on a fortnightly basis. The amendments to the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation Act will enable nurse practitioners to issue a workers compensation medical certificate at a patient’s initial attendance for minor injuries, if the certificate is issued under the workers compensation certificate protocol. The protocol will then set the conditions and any desirable restrictions on the issuing of such certificates.

Patients requiring subsequent or continuing workers compensation medical certificates would be referred to a medical officer, as would patients initially presenting with more serious workplace injuries or illnesses. I believe every aspect of these amendments can only further the betterment of health delivery across Queensland, particularly in rural and remote Queensland. I commend the bills to the House.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP) (3.35 pm): I am also pleased to speak in support of these two bills. They make a number of important changes to improve the health and safety of all Queenslanders. They introduce a requirement that doctors must report professional misconduct of their colleagues and that will undoubtedly improve the safety of medical treatment that Queenslanders receive. The bills also improve complaints mechanisms for users of the health system and they usher in an important reform which will involve the granting to nurse practitioners the power to issue a workers compensation medical certificate for a minor injury. As the member for Mount Isa just illustrated, that is a particularly important reform to ensure that we meet the growing demands for health services that we see in Queensland and to ensure that we use our highly qualified nurses to perform to the maximum of their ability.

There are two aspects of the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill that I would like to focus on in my remarks. The first is the amendments relating to smoking. As the House is aware, recently my title was changed to the Parliamentary Secretary for Healthy Living. That was a reflection of the government’s commitment to ensuring that Queenslanders live longer and healthier lives and to reducing the burden of lifestyle diseases on the health system. That is why we have a target in our Toward Q2 document to cut by one-third some of the primary causes of chronic diseases including obesity and overweightness, physical inactivity--
Mrs Keech interjected.
Mr WATT: It has just been pointed out to me that ‘overweightness’ may not be a word. It is a very overweight word, a long word.
Mr Lucas: Germans do that. They have these massive big nouns.

Mr WATT: The Minister for Health would not know anything about that topic--German sausages, I mean. One of the important dimensions of that target is to reduce by one-third the proportion of Queenslanders who are smokers.

Queensland has led the nation already in combating the harmful effects of smoking under the Bligh government and before it the Beattie government. In 1998 we introduced new laws which banned the supply of tobacco products to children under 18 years. In 2002 we increased the penalties for the supply of tobacco products to children and introduced new restrictions on advertising, display and promotion of tobacco products. In 2004 we introduced new laws restricting where smoking could occur--so now there is no smoking permitted inside pubs, clubs, restaurants and workplaces, outdoor eating or drinking areas, within 10 metres of children’s playground equipment, at major sports stadiums and within four metres of non-residential building entrances.

I have to say as a nonsmoker that it makes all of those places much more pleasant environments to be in but, more importantly, those measures are having a fantastic effect by driving down the percentage of Queenslanders who smoke--from 19.8 per cent in 2004 to 16 per cent in 2008-09. Unfortunately the statistics to do with risk factors for chronic disease are going the other way. We have more Queenslanders who are overweight or obese. We have more Queenslanders who are drinking to harmful levels. So it is really pleasing that at least in one area--that is, smoking--the percentages are going down.

Between 2004 and 2007 there was a reduction of more than 10 per cent in the number of Queensland women aged 20 to 29 who smoke. For young Queenslanders aged 14 to 19 years, there has been a 2.3 per cent reduction since 2004. That is obviously very important, because we want to make sure that young Queenslanders do not get hooked on this addictive substance at an early age, so I am very pleased to see that the proportion of young people smoking is also falling.

Despite this good news, there is definitely more to do. Each year, 3,400 Queenslanders die as a result of smoking. Smoking is responsible for about 80 per cent of all lung cancer deaths and 20 per cent of all cancer deaths in Queensland. Smoking is costing our health system $217 million annually through smoking related hospital admissions and other healthcare needs. That is why the Queensland government is seeking to further strengthen the state’s already tough antismoking regime. It will help us meet our Q2 target. It will save taxpayers’ money by reducing the burden on the health system. More than anything, it will to keep Queenslanders alive.

This bill represents the next step in the Bligh government’s strong moves to restrict smoking. It will ban smoking in vehicles carrying children under 16 years of age. It will grant local councils the power to regulate smoking in outdoor pedestrian malls and at public transport waiting points. It will add to the current restrictions on the promotion and display of cigarettes by restricting the promotion of smoking related products. These are all great steps that will reduce the number of Queenslanders who smoke, helping them to live longer and healthier lives and reducing the cost of smoking on the entire community.

The other aspect of this bill that I want to briefly touch on concerns health practitioner regulation. The bill will usher in a national scheme to regulate and register health professionals for the very first time. It will improve patient safety by ensuring that only health professionals who are suitably trained and qualified can practise in Queensland. Rather than each state having its own registration requirements--some of them set a high standard and some of them set a low standard--we will now have a uniform set of requirements to be registered as a health practitioner in each state of Australia.

I have received some representations from constituents on this aspect of the bill. I have raised these issues with the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health already, but I would appreciate it if he could address them in his remarks as well. The first set of constituents I have heard from are psychologists. They have two concerns. One is what they consider to be the absence of restrictions on who can conduct certain psychological tests. Currently, these tests can only be conducted by someone with psychological training, but my constituents argue that the bill will open the conduct of these tests to unqualified people.

They also argue that the bill will restrict the ranks of who may gain general registration as a psychologist. It will restrict the ability to those people who hold particular higher qualifications. My constituents are concerned that this will restrict psychologists who have practised for many years from performing a very wide range of psychological work. I would appreciate it if the Deputy Premier could respond to those issues in his remarks.

The other constituent I heard from is a speech pathologist. She has a concern, as does her association, that at the moment her profession will not be included in the national registration and accreditation scheme. I understand that is something that Queensland actually sought to achieve and it may still be on the agenda, but I would appreciate it if the Deputy Premier could provide my constituent with some advice about proposals to ensure that speech pathologists will be registered nationally.

With those words, I will sum up by commending the minister, his staff and his department for their good work on these bills. They will undoubtedly make a great contribution to improving the health and wellbeing of Queenslanders. I commend the bills to the House.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (3.42 pm): I rise to participate in the debate on the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill 2009. There are two issues that I wish to briefly touch on, as I know the minister is ready to respond to the matters that have already been raised.

I am very pleased that the government is going down the road of having a national registration and accreditation scheme for health professionals in Australia. No longer is Queensland isolated. Often we see teachers, nurses, doctors, staff and just people easily and frequently change their residence and employment from one state or territory to another. I think it is very important that so much of our legislation in Australia and Queensland today is built around a national focus. I believe the trend will be for more legislation to have a national focus so that it does not matter whether you are in Queensland or Western Australia because the same rules will apply. I congratulate the minister. It is a great move and I certainly support that.

The other issue I want to touch on, which I know other members have already raised, is the proposed amendments which will enable nurse practitioners to have a range of new roles, such as issuing workers compensation medical certificates and other duties. I believe this is a forward step and it is the way that other professions will go. We certainly need to be able to extend the powers of many of our very competent staff in our nursing profession, and I believe this is a great move. It will empower our nurses and give them a real opportunity to progress, but, more importantly, it will give them some responsibility which I know they are certainly capable of handling.

I commend the bill to the House. I know that other issues have been raised in detail by both government and opposition members. I look forward to this matter proceeding to the consideration in detail stage.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (3.44 pm), in reply: I thank members of the House for their contributions to the cognate debate on the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill and the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. The Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill represents an important step towards improving Australia’s health system through the national registration and accreditation of health practitioners.

The Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill will improve the consistency of the health practitioner registration acts and the Nursing Act with medical registration. Medical registration in Queensland was one of the templates used to develop the national law, and therefore these amendments will in the main improve the consistency of Queensland’s registration scheme with the national registration scheme and provide for smoother transition to the national scheme. We have learned from a number of experiences in this state that put us at the forefront of arguing for national legislation. We understand the problems when people go from jurisdiction to jurisdiction.

In addition, the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill contains a significant number of amendments in relation to smoking laws, duty of confidentiality, contact tracing for contagious conditions and consultation requirements for the development of health quality and complaints standards which further build on the government’s positive record of continuous reform of the health system.

The health and wellbeing of the public is of paramount concern to this government. I believe that national consistency in registration and accreditation arrangements for health practitioners will help to improve the accountability and flexibility of the provision of health services and also protect the public, by using the highest possible registration and accreditation standards nationwide, from potentially harmful health outcomes.

The national scheme for the health professions agreed to by COAG will promote consistency in decision making by moving from the current fragmented jurisdictional system to one national scheme. This scheme will deliver improved administrative efficiency in that health practitioners will need to be registered only once in order to practise in more than one Australian jurisdiction. Consequently, it will promote a more flexible, responsible and sustainable health workforce. A number of members have raised issues about the red tape that people have to go through from state to state and each level of government. This goes part of the way to eliminating that. I concede that we still have further to go.

The national scheme is also expected to provide improved safeguards for the public. National publicly accessible registers for health practitioners will go a long way to avoiding the unfortunate situations we have seen in the past where a board in one state or territory has registered a practitioner unaware that he or she has been the subject of an investigation in another jurisdiction. It is clearly not in the best interests of the people of Queensland for the current fragmented system of regulation to continue.

The practical reality is that our health workforce is already highly mobile and will become increasingly more so in the future. To be able to support and maintain the dynamic high-quality workforce required to meet the health needs of Queenslanders and Australians, it is clearly necessary for all jurisdictions to cooperate in developing a nationally consistent regulatory system. Rather than Queensland relinquishing its authority in relation to the registration and accreditation of health practitioners, this cooperative approach allows Queensland to play an active and leading role in shaping the integrated cross-jurisdictional scheme best able to provide positive health outcomes for Queenslanders.

Many of the comments from speakers in this debate have been about detailed matters. I will address most of those in detail in the committee stage if people raise those issues there, but I would like to address some of the more significant issues raised. The member for Caloundra has expressed concern about parliamentary scrutiny of the scheme in this legislation. The national scheme for health professions cannot become fully operational in all states and territories until all of the parliaments have had an opportunity to debate legislation that proposes to adopt and apply the national law as a law of each participating jurisdiction--that is, bill C.

Introducing a national law in one parliament for adoption by other states is a standard approach for achieving national scheme legislation in areas where the constitutional powers lie with states and territories. Nothing any minister is doing can bind their parliament. Each parliament, including ours, will decide for itself when debating its jurisdiction’s legislation whether to adopt and apply the national law as a law of its jurisdiction. We need to remember, though, that we cannot have everything we want, because not every state can always get everything it wants. I would rather have speech pathologists as part of national registration--I will continue to pursue that--but clearly we need to make some compromises when we have a national scheme.

I and my ministerial council colleagues have a clear and unwavering commitment to consultation. This has been demonstrated in the consultation that has happened in the legislation before us today. If there are significant changes proposed in the future, members of the House, the public and the professions can feel confident that there will be national consultation prior to them being put forward for agreement. I note that both sides of the House acknowledge there have been changes as consultation has taken place.

For the information of the member for Moggill, I confirm that the scheme will operate from 1 July 2010, and that is a tight time frame. A number of other parliaments have also introduced their adopting legislation, I think in both Victoria and New South Wales at this stage. Looking at progress to date, I anticipate all preparatory work will be completed and the timetable can be met. Governments have contributed $19.8 million to the cost of transition to the national scheme as well as an additional provision above that level in order to fully cover all IT costs to 30 June 2010. That will assist the national agency and boards and other key features of the scheme to commence well in advance of the 1 July 2010 commencement date and ensure that a smooth transition occurs.

In order to retain the vast body of knowledge in current state and territory boards and their staff, ministers have agreed to both a staffing strategy to transition as many existing staff to the national agency as appropriate and to provide for the transition of many current board members from state and territory boards to the national boards where they will exist. I am sure I speak on behalf of the ministerial council when I say that I welcome the opportunity to be part of implementing a national scheme that will provide for the protection of the public by ensuring that only those health practitioners who are suitably trained and qualified to practise are registered. This underpins the safety and quality of our health scheme.

The development of the national scheme has enabled ministers to adopt the strongest elements of all jurisdictions which will come together for the first time ever in a consistent set of national standards and processes for registration and accreditation for health professionals. The national scheme will also help reduce red tape for registrants, especially when they work across or move between different states and territories--another important reform to improve workforce development and mobility.

I turn now to other contributions from members. The mandatory reporting provisions will apply to all registered medical practitioners in Queensland. Medical practitioners in Queensland have an ethical obligation to report professional misconduct. The amendments for medical practitioners entrench these obligations into legislation. We will talk about that more in the consideration in detail stage, as we similarly will the smoking issues. I note that the member for Caloundra is proposing amendments that will seek to extend that further. I am confused about that because the member for Dalrymple said he believed these were essentially interferences and impossible to enforce. It will be interesting to see how he votes on it. Presumably he will oppose the opposition’s amendment and then seek to divide on the government’s clause, but we will see about that.

I turn to the Health Quality and Complaints Commission issues. In November 2007 the select committee appointed by this House delivered its report on the review of the commission after its first year of operation. The select committee made 37 recommendations for improving the commission’s operation, all of which were accepted by the government either in principle or without reservation. The bill delivers on recommendations 20 and 36 by requiring the HQCC in developing or amending standards to properly consult with affected parties and the public through an impact assessment process. Developing and maintaining those standards is an important part of the work of the commission, enabling it to promote continuous quality improvement in public and private health facilities. However, this process is not as it should be as it is not done in a practical, consultative fashion. This amendment seeks to get the balance right, but, as I say, we will have a look at that in the course of time and if we need to further finetune that we will.

As our population ages and our rates of chronic disease increase, pressures on our health system will continue. In the June quarter this year, over 378,000 people were treated in emergency departments throughout Queensland--an increase of almost 6,000 compared to the same period last year. More than 220,000 were admitted to hospital--an increase of over 11,000--and over 851,000 received outpatient services--an increase of almost 10,000. That is why the government continues to aggressively grow the health workforce as part of our $10 billion Health Action Plan, employing more doctors, nurses and allied health professionals.

I want to make this clear, because it was raised by a number of people. Since June 2005 we have employed an additional 2,109 doctors--an increase of 46 per cent. Over the same period we have employed an additional 7,733 nurses--an increase of 35 per cent--and 2,802 allied health professionals--an increase of 40 per cent. This bill makes a number of amendments to better support our health workforce and enable the valuable skills of our doctors, nurses and allied health professionals to be used as effectively as possible. It amends 13 health practitioner registration acts in essentially the same way with two exceptions.

The bill includes amendments to the Health Services Act in relation to the exceptions to the duty of confidentiality. The members for Glass House and Burleigh touched on the need for flexibility in the protection of patient records to ensure the appropriate support and care can be given to family members outside the health system. I indicated before that these amendments are about doing that. I intend to take this further, though. On a number of occasions when I have spoken to health professionals, families and mental health professionals they have said, ‘How does it help someone if you do not appropriately share information with their families or doctors or care givers? They go out into the community, get sick, people are not aware of their issues and they end up back in an institution.’ That is not in anyone’s interests. Sometimes I think people in the public sector get a bit obsessed about who the balance of privacy is for the benefit of. We will make sure we continue to look at that issue. I thank the honourable members for that.

I propose to amend the provisions in clause 61 of the bill for mandatory reporting for doctors to ensure that the reporting obligation under the bill is as far as possible consistent with the reporting obligations for health professionals in the national bill. What is in the national bill I will be amending the state bill to do. It is ridiculous to have a six-month period where it is different. I should say this to the honourable member, too. He wants to move an amendment, but he will not be seeking to amend the national bill. Maybe he will seek to do that. That is a bit different if he does. We do need some uniformity in relation to that.

The member for Caloundra sought clarification about clause 2(1), which provides for retrospective application of the amendments being made to the research provisions of the Public Health Act. The amendments were put forward in light of advice provided by crown law in relation to operational issues identified by the department following the commencement of the research provisions on 16 January 2006. In particular, it was identified during rollout of new provisions that confusion surrounded which provisions should be used to release information, as the release of confidential information is covered in various health portfolio acts. Clause 163 inserts new provision 280A to clarify that research provisions under the Public Health Act do not prevent health information.

It is very important to encourage research into these things. We saw a little while ago that the Cancer Council Queensland had a number of issues that the government needed to address with respect to information we possessed in Queensland Health and its ability to access it so it could perform appropriate health research. That is a very important issue that confronts us.

Clause 165(2) amends section 284 to clarify that, when making a decision about whether a person should be granted access to information for research purposes, the chief executive is not required to consult with an individual to whom the information relates before granting an application. Crown law advice suggests that a decision to grant access for research purposes to potentially identifying health information held by Queensland Health is subject to the requirements of natural justice, and this would require the chief executive to notify each person to whom the information relates and to give them an opportunity to respond. That would not be in the best interests of medical research. The reason that people are getting better is that we have better treatments. The reason we have better treatments is that people undertake medical research. It is critical.

There was some discussion by the member for Gaven about mandatory reporting and his concerns with respect to it. There are matters that I cannot talk about in this chamber because they are before the courts, but I would have thought they would be absolutely adequate rolled gold examples of where mandatory reporting is important. Indeed, the suggestion was made by that member and I think the member for Burnett that in a number of instances people made reports to people who were in management, and clearly those people did not act on them. A commission of inquiry found that. This will make that mandatory reporting to the national board. Indeed, entities that do not pass on their concerns about that issue are then subject to sanction as well, and the member for Moggill raised an issue with that.

The member for Currumbin shared with the member for Burnett in giving probably the most disgraceful performance in the debate. There are members on both sides of the House who make really good contributions and others who do not. There have been some excellent contributions from both sides of the House. The member for Burnett demonstrated why he went off the front bench, and the member for Currumbin demonstrates why she will go off the front bench in due course, because there are certainly people on her own back bench who performed in this debate substantially better than she did. But it is good to see good contributions from members of both sides. To suggest, as she did, that there is not a real role for nurse practitioners is quite disappointing and takes away the fact that the backbone of our health system is our nurses. They are our major employees. They are doing a wonderful job, as all of our health professionals are.

The member for Glass House gave what I thought was a very good contribution. He spoke about other allied health professions and the issue of speech pathologists. The member for Bulimba, a speech pathologist herself, also raised that issue, as did the member for Everton. One of my colleagues said to me while the member for Bulimba was making her contribution that we do not seem to see as many people these days with really bad stammers. I suspect the reason is that we have people like speech pathologists and speech therapists who are providing support to young kids. It is a very important thing. The reason we have national registration is to protect people. A parent or someone who has had a stroke wants to know that the health professional, for example the speech pathologist, who is treating them has professional standing and competency behind them. That is why we would like to see that national registration. What we will need to do for speech pathologists and dental technicians is work out an alternative. My concern is that I do not want to have a big separate bureaucracy for them because that will then impact on their cost to practise. We will need to have a look at what models are potentially available for them that do not throw the baby out with the bath water.

The member for Kawana, in another very ordinary contribution, raised issues such as mandatory misconduct reporting. He related a tragic case of someone committing suicide because he indicated that that person was concerned about reporting. The first thing that anyone should learn when they come into this House is that anecdotal, unidentified arguments are impossible to rebut. They are the result of someone who is not very good at being a parliamentarian. Having said that, the case referred to in that anecdote happened under a different system. We need to be serious about this. There is a choice we have here. Sure, there are concerns about mandatory reporting, but the alternative is that people slip through the cracks and patients get injured or killed. That is why we have mandatory reporting.
The aviation industry, which I knew a little bit about years ago, took seriously--
Mr Stevens: A DC-10.

Mr LUCAS: I do know what a DC-10 is. Many years ago the aviation industry adopted what it calls crew resource management. What crew resource management means in aeroplanes is that everybody who is part of the team has an equal say and role. So if a flight attendant looks out the window and sees something wrong with the flap, the wing or the engine, that person can go up to the captain and say, ‘I have a concern about this,’ and they will not get abused and treated as a fool. It is fair to say that other professions, in particular the medical profession, have taken a while to actually come to the realisation that that is a clear aspect of safety. We all know the stories about the bad old days where other allied health staff and nurses were subject to ‘How dare you ever question me?’ and that sort of thing. I am delighted to say that that is not what I have observed at all in our Queensland Health facilities. We have people who are very enlightened on all parts of the profession. Let us be realistic about it, because we need to be able to deal with these issues.

The member for Maryborough asked about ATSI health practitioners. One of the critical issues we have with chronic health problems with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is not so much the issue of their medical treatment by doctors or nurses or the like but that the people who are providing ongoing support and education in the community are predominantly people from their own communities. They are much better off when they have someone from their own community doing that. When I was in Palm Island a little while ago I was delighted to see Dr Ray. Dr Ray is a Palm Island boy through and through. He was born on Palm Island and is now a doctor. It makes me so proud when I see him working alongside our other doctors.
The member for Beaudesert misunderstood the role of nurse practitioners. He said that nurses will not want to--
A government member: He always does!

Mr LUCAS: He exists on a different plane. And I know about planes, as I said before, but he is on a different plane. He said that he was concerned about nurse practitioners because they will take nurses away from working on the shop floor, so to speak, of hospitals. That is exactly what nurse practitioners are for. He did not understand or listen both in question time this morning or during this debate. The problem in the past for nurses was that if they wanted to go up the career structure they had to become an administrator. This allows nurses to be clinicians at more and more senior levels for not only their own professional development but also the benefit of society. It is very sad that he does not understand that.

The member for Dalrymple, as I said before, mentioned the nanny state when it comes to the tobacco amendments. I am looking forward to seeing how he is going to vote on that. He talked about the difficulty of getting doctors and nurses in rural places. Nurse practitioners are part of doing that, and a substantial increase in training numbers in our medical schools and universities so that we have more and more doctors, nurses and allied health professional is also an important part of that.

The member for Burnett failed to understand that the complaints process in the national law provides for complaints to an independent national body. He also, when he talked about funding, neglected to point out that under the Howard government the federal share of hospital funding went from 50 per cent to 34 per cent. That is a disgrace. It did not match the growth in state funding for health. He never said anything about that. I suppose the problem is that when one has no capacity to construct a contribution to a debate one reads slabs of text from royal commissions rather than contribute to the meaningful debate. Just about everybody else in this place--some views I agreed with and some views I did not agree with--at least had the capacity to discuss the issues.

The member for Gregory, in another very good contribution, talked about doctors from overseas countries. This is one of the issues that people like the member for Currumbin would never agree takes place. I do not accept that leaving who decides who becomes registered as a professional is something that only a professional organisation should have a say in. We have known the issues.

The member for Waterford, in an excellent contribution, talked about the old days of restrictive work practices in some areas industrially. We need to constantly be on guard to make sure that some people just do not want to protect their turf. Multiskilling, whether that be on the shop floor of a factory or in the health system, is the way of the future. We will continue to work to encourage that.

Doctors from overseas countries are a case in point. I remember many years ago I had a constituent who was a physiotherapy graduate from the university of Leiden--one of the great European continental universities. She lectured in physiotherapy in a British hospital and she could not get automatic registration in Queensland. Apparently we are so good that we are better than everyone in Europe. That is ridiculous. We have to be serious in looking at how we accept qualifications from comparable overseas countries.

The member for Gregory spoke about red tape, as did the member for Moggill. As I said, that is an important issue that we will need to continue to address. The member for Gregory spoke about Blackwater and the growth in services there and in other communities such as Alpha which will grow with the Galilee Basin and the like.

We need to be very clear about what we do in health in rural and regional Queensland. We need to take the opportunity to adjust what we are doing to take into account population growth, and indeed some places will decline. We need to frankly address what we are doing so we can have sustainability. The greatest problem that we have had in the past is when governments have said that they will stick a service into somewhere with one practitioner and that practitioner leaves or goes and does something else and we have a whole bureaucracy set up and everyone is inconvenienced because we have not got a person there to support that service when the other person leaves.

In the future I think more and more we will try to have practitioners in groups. Surely it is better to have two doctors who can relieve and support each other in a community with a larger area of coverage than one or two individual nodes where they cannot support each other all of the time and they burn out. Doctors in regional Queensland have said to me the issue is not so much what they are paid. Doctors in Queensland are pretty well paid compared to those in other states; in remote and regional areas they get paid more. If we said that we would give them another $20,000 a year to be specialist X but they will be the only one there and they will never get any relief, they would say, ‘Great! Send that $20,000 to the family solicitor to pay for my divorce, because my partner will leave me because I will have burned out.’ That is a critical issue.
An opposition member interjected.

Mr LUCAS: My shadow colleague is a legal practitioner, as I am. One of the real problems as a legal practitioner is those who work in sole practice. I think the ability not to have someone working with you is a real problem when you want a sounding board or some support. The medical profession is no different.

The member for Gregory talked about obstetrics. We want to roll out and improve the midwife model of care at more and more locations, and I know the member for Beaudesert has raised that issue as well. However, we also need to understand that one of the reasons that we have the third longest life expectancy on earth and one of the reasons we have better outcomes from our hospitals and our health system is that we are frankly assessing what we can do appropriately and safely in communities.

We need to have a hub-and-spoke model in Queensland. The hub and spoke does not just apply in South-East Queensland; we have to have base hospitals as well. If Townsville, Cairns, Rockhampton, Toowoomba and Mount Isa are appropriate hubs for their spokes, they can then work with each other. They are hubs and spokes for various different wheels.

The member for Toowoomba South spoke about speech pathology as well, businesses cases, funding and the like. It is important to do business cases. I think the member for Burnett spoke about budgets and how there is some heresy if health practitioners or administrators are held to account for budgets. Of course they should be held accountable for their budgets, because if you have a system and you do not keep to your budget you are taking money off the people who are doing the right thing. It is not unreasonable to expect accountability from people and for them to work within the budget that they are given. Sure, we can have arguments about what those budgets might be, but it is very important that we say, ‘Okay, here is a budget. We will work within that framework.’

The member for Toowoomba North spoke about smoking, and I will just give members this anecdote. Last week I was on holidays in Victoria. Melbourne is a lovely place. It has a light rail system. Obviously, according to the Leader of the Opposition, that has ruined Melbourne. Having said that, do members want to know what I found absolutely abhorrent about Melbourne? When you go to Lygon Street in Carlton people are smoking like chimneys at restaurants out in the open. It really struck me that a city that portrays itself as being world class--and it is in so many areas--is light years behind us in terms of smoking in public. Melbourne has a light rail system that we would like to have on the Gold Coast, but in terms of smoking it has yet to come to grips with the fact that it needs to take the issue of smoking in public places seriously. It is a long, long way behind. People in Queensland would never put up with the sort of smoking that is happening in places like Melbourne. I commend the bills to the House.
Question put--That the bills be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bills read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 1, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 2--

Mr McARDLE (4.12 pm): I am aware that the minister in his reply dealt with clause 2 in terms of the impact of the retrospective nature of the commencement dates. For clarification purposes, could the minister elaborate on what transpired that required that to occur?

Mr LUCAS: The advice from my department is as I indicated before. For example, there are certain provisions under the Public Health Act that allow research to take place and then there are privacy implications in relation to those provisions. Then there is a question as to how they then interact with the provisions of the other health acts. It was important to clarify that. The date of January 2006 was selected only because that was when those provisions were originally enacted. That is what I am advised.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 2, as read, agreed to.
Clause 3, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 4--

Mr McARDLE (4.13 pm): This clause is replicated throughout the bill. It inserts ‘12 months’ in lieu of ‘6 months’ for registration purposes. Could the minister outline why the change has occurred? Is there a particular set of circumstances that warrants that change? I understand from the briefing we had some time ago that it may relate to James Cook University or some sort of qualification process within a university.

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member. I am advised that some universities do not hold graduation ceremonies until June or July in the year after a student finishes the course. If a student gains provisional registration in December, the six-month period expires before the university can confer or provide its degree certificate. That means that the provisional registrant will have to reapply and pay the required fee again. This amendment will overcome that problem. That is what I am advised. The provision of the governing act will be repealed upon commencement of the national scheme. So it is operating only for the interim period.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 4, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 5 to 30, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 31--

Mr McARDLE (4.14 pm): This clause relates to the alteration of the term ‘within 14 days of’ to the phrase ‘as soon as practicable after’. My concern about this clause is that section 55 as it stood--this clause amends that section--had a definitive time line in relation to the expiration of the issue dealt with by the relevant body. When you open up the wording, you then potentially leave open how long a body can deal with a matter. I seek clarification at this point as to why ‘within 14 days of’ has been changed to what appears in clause 31, because it tends to raise some concern about when the matter can be determined.

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. First of all, in terms of why there has been a change from the period of 14 days, section 55 of the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act requires that when a board rejects a complaint it must give written notice of its decision and its reasons to the relevant parties within 14 days after making the decision.

The practice of the Queensland health practitioners board is that when a decision to reject a complaint is made by the board at its meeting the decision and reasons are recorded in draft minutes of the meeting which are then ratified by the board at its next meeting. That ensures the written notice of the decision will accurately reflect the board’s decision.

While the Medical Board meets fortnightly, the majority of other boards meet only monthly. That means that the boards that meet monthly or less frequently cannot comply with the 14-day time frame for giving notice of decisions under section 55. By allowing boards to give notice of their decision as soon as practicable after it is made, the amendment recognises that the boards’ recording of decisions affects the time frames within which boards are able to give notice of their decisions. I am confident that the boards will act responsibly.

I am told that under the national law--and this clause refers to rejecting complaints--there is no time limit for providing the notification. It is ‘as soon as practicable’. Not everything that is in our legislation is the same as the national legislation because, frankly, it is not worth changing some of it. But in the process of changing it, it is trying to make it uniform. This provision is uniform. I think there are some other provisions that are not. Again, frankly, this provision will apply only for the next seven months.

Mr McARDLE: I thank the minister for that. I take the point that he raised. I know that the national law has wording similar to what is contained in this amendment. My concern is that the use of the phrase is open-ended. We are both legal practitioners and we know how that can at times lead to difficulties and concerns. Is there some method whereby the time can be linked to, if not the date of the next board meeting, some point in time of 14 days after the decision is made as opposed to ‘as soon as practicable’? That can be any length of time. I am concerned about the confusion that can arise in people’s minds.

Mr LUCAS: The honourable member raises reasonable concerns. We probably come from a background where we like the certainty of time limits and time frames. Having said that, I would not propose to change Queensland law at this point, but I am more than happy to at least address the issue of procedures that might take place at those boards with my national colleagues through the appropriate workings. I will feed the member’s concerns about that into the system. You do not want to have a situation where people get more obsessed with their internal activities and mechanisms than, frankly, their right to be notified as to whether they are successful or unsuccessful. So I will feed the member’s concern into the national system. I cannot undertake to change it, but in terms of what they are doing they need to have appropriate procedures. The member for Moggill talked about time limits and red tape before. It is not an unreasonable point.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 31, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 32 to 41, as read, agreed to.
Clause 42--
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LUCAS (4.19 pm): I move the following amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent2: Page 34, lines 15 to 19--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: ‘(c) if the disclosure is to the Queensland Nursing Council and the disclosure is necessary for the Queensland Nursing Council to perform its functions under the Nursing Act 1992 ; or’.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: I table for the information of the House the explanatory notes for these amendments.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Explanatory notes to amendments to be moved to the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill by the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health during consideration in detail.
XML.Hansard-Body: Amendment No. 1 amends clause 42 of the bill which amends section 392 of the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act to allow confidential information obtained under that act to be disclosed to the Queensland Nursing Council and the Nursing Tribunal if the disclosure is necessary to allow those bodies to perform their functions under Nursing Act. However, with effect from 1 December 2009 the Nursing Tribunal will be replaced by the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal, created under the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act, QCAT. Therefore, there is no need to authorise disclosure of confidential information to the Nursing Tribunal from that time as QCAT will be a disciplinary body.

In relation to matters arising under both the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act and the Nursing Act, confidential information may be disclosed under the existing exemption in section 392(3) (b) of the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act without the need for a separate authorisation for disclosure. The next amendment is a consequential amendment, so I will not speak on that but I will still have to move it.
Amendment agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 42, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 43--
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LUCAS (4.21 pm): I move the following amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: Page 34, lines 26 to 28--
‘ Queensland Nursing Council means the council established under the Nursing Act 1992 , section 6.’.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Amendment agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 43, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 44 and 45, as read, agreed to.
Clause 46--
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr McARDLE
(4.22 pm): This clause relates to the amendment allowing standards to be made and an amendment to those standards to occur as a consequence of the HQCC Select Committee inquiry. The amendment to clause 46 provides a significant range of matters that must be dealt with before the standard can become operative, including consultation, publication on the website et cetera. A couple of points arise.

First of all, when one considers the terms of clause 46 it would appear that it does not define who the consultation is to be with. It does not indicate whether it is to be with a college or an education facility. Who decides who the consultation will be with? It also would appear that the commission must publish on its website for at least 14 days a copy of the impact assessment statement and a notice inviting anyone to comment upon the content of the document. That would imply that the consultation follows the proposal being garnered by the governmental body.

At proposed subsection (8) it states that failure to comply with the section does not affect the validity of the standard or amendment. When one takes into account the importance of the standards and the processes put in place within the terms of clause 46, one gets the idea that we are going to achieve, by way of consultation--one way or another--publication et cetera, a standard or an amendment that will achieve something. We then find that, even if that is not undertaken under proposed subsection (8), the standard or the amendment is still valid. If we are going to have a process put in place that allows consultation, input and scrutiny by various organisations and bodies, why, then, does the minister say that one can not do all of that but still have a valid document, a valid standard or a valid amendment?

Mr LUCAS: The honourable member would well know the difference between mandatory and directory provisions. Having directory provisions in legislation is not uncommon. These are those. I would also point out that it is my understanding that these standards are, in fact, not binding. They are guidelines for what good and appropriate practice is. The fact that they are still validly made standards is not in that sense the be-all and end-all.

In terms of the time involved in these sorts of things, the HQCC has advised that new or amended standards only occur through a full review. The first full review of the HQCC’s seven healthcare standards, introduced on 1 July 2007, commenced on 1 August 2009. It is an 18-month process, due for completion in 2010. The review involves consultation through an open submission process and the advice of clinical expert reference groups. These groups are made up of stakeholders from professional colleges and representatives from public and private healthcare facilities. Group members are selected through an expression-of-interest process and are credible, influential and valued members. Following the full review of the standards and development of an impact assessment statement, the HQCC will undertake a communication and education campaign. I could go on a bit longer about that.

The honourable member asked: what is the point of consulting after one has the standard? That is not uncommon. I think there are a number of state planning policies that are a bit like that, where one goes through a whole lot of processes. First of all they formulate that they might want to have a standard and then say, ‘We are thinking of having a standard. What do you think about what we should do in it?’ Then they say, ‘Okay, we will have a big think about it. This is what we think it should be. What do you think about it?’ Then one is adopted in the end.

Provisions are becoming more complex because they have to outline everything--for example, ‘Before you go to work you put the key in the ignition of the car, turn it to the right, close the door, put the seatbelt on,’ rather than say, ‘Look, you just drive to work,’ and assume that people do what they should do along the way. I suppose we could be more prescriptive in relation to these standards. The Health Quality and Complaints Commission does an excellent job, but I want to look at whether there might be some things that we can streamline.

I know that we have had concerns that when reports have been provided, due to the confidential nature of them, there have been difficulties about providing information to the public about their outcomes in other areas. That does not relate to this. I am keen to look more broadly at the HQCC process so that we can get the best of both worlds. I will look at this further. I can give the member the sorts of standards that we have. They have indicated to me that they do undertake quite an extensive process when it comes to that.

Mr McARDLE: I take on board the comments that the minister has made. It would appear, though, that when one makes a comparison about this with the national law bill there is a distinction between the two. In the national law bill there does seem to be more of an emphasis on full and frank consultation prior to anything being prepared. It just seems to me that there is an inconsistency in the two pieces of legislation. We will come to the second one down the track.

My concern is that if we are going to have a standard and if there is going to be consultation, the consultation needs to be in a manner that is with the appropriate bodies. I think that is compulsory in the theme of getting a health system across the nation that deals with the concerns of all Queenslanders and all Australians on the ground. I have great difficulty in understanding how we can have a process in place but then say that a body that in six to eight months time will be part of the national scheme can avoid that process now. If we are going to do it, do it right now because the national law will require that we do it in a different manner.

Mr LUCAS: The honourable member has extended the issue of the national scheme a little bit further. It will work with the national law, but it will be stand-alone. The HQCC will be recognised in the national law, but it will continue to exist in Queensland law. It is not like the medical boards and things like that, which will be national bodies under different legislation. National standards can result in prosecution and/or cancellation or suspension. HQCC standards result in referral to an investigative body. So they have a different role.

As I said to the member--not because it relates to the national scheme so much. The HQCC is looking more at institutional issues. If a doctor, nurse or whoever has undertaken an act that is dangerous or wrong, that is a matter for the professional board. If there is a concern about how a private or public hospital has operated in relation to a matter more generally, that is more a HQCC thing.

As I said before, in the context of working with the HQCC, I am happy to have a look at where we need to go in the future and those sorts of things to take the honourable member’s point, which was a point legitimately and validly made, on board.

Mr McARDLE: Can the minister agree that subclause (8) means simply that, if desired, subclauses (1) to (7) included as are relevant to the consultation period and the processes involved can be ignored, given the wording of subclause (8) states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Failure to comply with this section does not affect the validity of the standard or amendment.
XML.Hansard-Body: Does that give the authority to the HQCC--whether that is or is not irrelevant--to ignore the balance of the contents of clause 46 in the process?
Mr Lucas: I’ve already answered it.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That clause 46 stand part of the bill.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: AYES, 49--Bligh, Boyle, Choi, Croft, Cunningham, Dick, Finn, Foley, Fraser, Grace, Hinchliffe, Hoolihan, Jarratt, Johnstone, Jones, Kiernan, Kilburn, Lucas, Male, Miller, Moorhead, Nelson-Carr, Nolan, O’Brien, O’Neill, Palaszczuk, Pitt, Reeves, Roberts, Robertson, Ryan, Schwarten, Scott, Shine, Smith, Spence, Stone, Struthers, Sullivan, van Litsenburg, Wallace, Watt, Wellington, Wells, Wendt, Wettenhall, Wilson. Tellers: Keech, Darling

NOES, 32--Bates, Bleijie, Crandon, Cripps, Davis, Dempsey, Dickson, Douglas, Dowling, Elmes, Emerson, Flegg, Gibson, Hobbs, Hopper, Johnson, Knuth, Langbroek, McArdle, McLindon, Malone, Nicholls, Powell, Rickuss, Seeney, Simpson, Sorensen, Springborg, Stevens, Stuckey. Tellers: Horan, Messenger
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 46, as read, agreed to.
Clause 47, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 48--

Mr McARDLE (4.39 pm): This particular clause comes as a result of the report into the very sad death of that young girl from Bribie Island. A number of concerns were raised within the report, in particular, whether a number of matters have been referred to the health department relating to concerns involving young children, their parents and mental illnesses. Proposed new section 62IA states that disclosure can be to a person. The minister and I both know that can be other people as well, not just one person. The report specifically deals with a report being made to a health organisation or a support group--and I want to make this very clear here. The use of the term ‘person’ in what will be the section is not going to be confined to a parent or a grandparent. If there is say, for example, a support group assisting a child and the parent has a mental illness, that support group can be contacted although they are not relatives. There are certainly circumstances in today’s society where that does happen. I want to make it absolutely clear that we are not going to limit ourselves as to who can be contacted under that particular provision. The minister and I would both agree that we do not want this to happen again. If there is something we can do now to put in place those mechanisms, let us do it straight away as opposed to waiting for the next event to occur.

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member. The advice from my advisers is that it is not just natural persons. I take the member’s point. You advise practitioners, for example, when you are talking about health and other practitioners. I am told that it will encompass organisations. However, I will also look at that in the context of a broader examination of the issue of how we deal with privacy. This relates to children; it does not relate to people more generally.

The member for Burleigh has raised the issue before that when an adult with no children has been in an institution and they are released into the community, there is a need to tell the people who are caring for them, frankly, what their condition is, how they might identify them and those sorts of issues.

There is a question about whether privacy obligations would have been a problem there in any case. I know that as we get more and more issues about protecting privacy people then tend to throw the baby out with the bathwater. I intend to look at this issue more broadly, not just in relation to children, because we are fundamentally concerned with having patients in an appropriate area, getting appropriate support from people who can give them that support with appropriate knowledge. I am told that it would relate to other persons as is appropriate, but I will look at that again in a more ongoing sense.

Mr McARDLE: I think the minister made the comment that he would now look at broadening the whole aspect of the privacy matter to deal with assisting people who have a mental illness. So that may well go further into looking at privacy issues in the adult area as well. I think that would be an excellent idea. There are so many people in our society who are in need of that help and assistance. Whatever we can do to facilitate their moving back into mainstream society would be of enormous benefit to them and to us and also to the health dollar.

Mr LUCAS: Yes. The point being that the member might have a cousin who is an adult who is released from a secure facility and they will say, ‘Mr McArdle, this is the health condition that your cousin has. You have to make sure that he takes three pills a day. If he manifests this behaviour, please ring us straightaway.’ I think we should address those issues. I am not raising this because the member has raised it with me in this bill. I have indicated for some time now that I want to deal with this issue. I have said it in a number of public places. I want to do it not because this is in the bill but because I am concerned that we adequately support people in the community. That then means in certain circumstances making sure that their family and other people who might be supporting them are adequately advised of their mental condition so that they can support them and know what is going wrong.

XML.Hansard-Body: Amendment 3 formally recognises a registration arrangement that the Medical Board of Queensland has in place for retired doctors. The amendment inserts a new section 150AD in the Medical Practitioners Registration Act which serves two purposes. Firstly, the provision provides protection for patients and the public by providing clear guidance on what retired doctors may and may not do.

Under the Medical Practitioners (Registration) Regulation, the Medical Board may waive the fee for a retired doctor to register either as a general or specialist registrant on the condition the doctor does not draw any income from practising the profession. Retired doctors traditionally only provide repeat prescriptions and referrals and may occasionally volunteer to assist in basic procedures during times of stress in the health system--such times may include during a pandemic or natural disaster or in remote areas during absences of the local medical practitioner.

It is necessary for protecting patients to restrict the practices which retired doctors may engage in. Retired doctors who are not providing regular health services and who are not engaging in ongoing professional development are at risk of losing competency and having outdated knowledge which may place patients at risk. Formally limiting the scope of practice that a retired doctor may engage in ensures that any risk from the potential loss of skill and knowledge will be minimal.

The second purpose of this provision--and this is important--is to provide formal recognition of this arrangement to ensure that retired doctors in Queensland appropriately transition to the national scheme. If we did not do this, the national scheme would not allow retired doctors in Queensland because there is not a statutory basis for them. In my discussions with the AMA, they indicated that this was an issue that they had some concern with for doctors.

I am very sympathetic to the role of retired doctors. I think they do wonderful things in our community and to give them a pat on the back and to say thank you and acknowledge that is not an inappropriate thing to do. There will be a grandfathering clause to permit any retired registrant with a specified limited scope of practice to transition to the national scheme, but there will be no new admittees. I would have preferred to have it a bit broader but that is what we were able to deal with at a national level. My department consulted with the AMA in relation to this. This is seeking to make sure that when we go to the national scheme retired doctors who are currently allowed to practice as retired doctors are continued to be recognised.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Amendment agreed to.

XML.Hansard-Body: I table the explanatory notes in relation to the amendments I will be moving today.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Explanatory notes to amendments to be moved to the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill by the member for Caloundra.
XML.Hansard-Body: This amendment deals with the reportable conduct provision. The history in this state, and undoubtedly elsewhere across the nation, shows that this sort of legislation had to occur. The bill before the House provides for the misconduct to have occurred under three or four different sets of circumstances and also requires that if the first registrant becomes aware that the second registrant has engaged in reportable misconduct that person must then be reported to the relevant authority. The bill is very black and white. The amendment that we are moving here this afternoon provides some exceptions. I am acutely aware of the minister’s amendment that he will move subsequent to this.

The opposition has proposed in the amendment that we exclude three sets of circumstances. The first is where a spouse is the first registrant operating in a clinical arena with the second registrant. The second is where there is a medical practitioner seeking the assistance of a medical practitioner to overcome problems. The third set of circumstances is in relation to the insurance industry, which both the opposition and the government agree on.

In relation to the scenario of the spouse, as I said in my speech in the second reading debate it certainly has not been easy to come to the determination that a spouse should not be required to lodge a misconduct complaint with the board. However, I believe the marital relationship is a cornerstone of our society. It is one of the most important fabrics that dictates who we are and what we are. The spousal relationship is defined within the terms of the bill to include heterosexual, homosexual and other relationships as well, so it covers myriad scenarios. The importance of the spousal relationship in my opinion cannot be underestimated, and we believe it is important to protect that relationship. In relation to sexual misconduct, that relationship would not in my opinion sustain such an allegation, but under the set of circumstances we believe that the exemption should apply to protect that relationship.

The other point where the government and the opposition differ is in relation to a doctor treating a practitioner for a medical condition or impairment of some sort. It has been the practice for a long time for medical practitioners to seek assistance when they face difficulties that could impact upon their capacity to deliver a safe and efficient service to their clients. The concern is that, if we impose upon another practitioner the obligation to report a reportable misconduct, we risk practitioners not seeking the assistance they normally would have sought--thus driving them underground.

What we do not want is a scenario where practitioners do not seek help because they are concerned they will be reported to the relevant board. What we do want is practitioners who are able to seek assistance knowing that they will receive the treatment and the guidance they need to return to the medical practice and continue on with their good work. There is an obligation on practitioners to provide a safe and harm-free service to their clients, and I believe there is a very strong ethical and moral obligation on medical practitioners to ensure that other doctors in fact do the same.

At the end of the day, we are saying that reporting as a concept is fine. It may have solved many problems in this state and elsewhere if it had been in place some time ago. We are concerned about the issue of spouses being required to make a report on their spouse, and we are concerned that doctors may fail to seek treatment from another doctor.
The issue of the insurance industry is self-explanatory. When we discuss that particular portion of the government’s amendment, there is one point I will raise in relation to terminology.

Mr LUCAS: The government will be opposing the amendment moved by the member for Caloundra. I am not going to go into the reason why we should have mandatory reporting. The member accepts that we should have a mandatory reporting scheme. It is merely about the extent to which it applies.

I will make a couple of observations. First of all, this bill that we are debating at the moment is the state bill, which is the law in relation to Queensland up until the time that the national law is adopted from next year. If we did nothing or if we do something that is inconsistent with the national regime--whilst we can do that because we are the master of our own destiny in this parliament here--it would be a bit peculiar. So the amendments I foreshadow I will move will make sure that the Queensland provisions are identical to the provisions in the national scheme. It is really quite silly to do anything other than that, although I do acknowledge the sovereign right of the parliament to do that.

I have to take issue with the opposition in relation to spouse reporting. The honourable member referred to the past protections in the Criminal Code. They are about compellability; they are not about the same thing as spouse reporting. I do not want people to think that I do not understand the difference between whether someone is a compellable witness or someone has an obligation to report. Having said that, we have taken a view that those issues are anachronistic, bearing in mind the modern circumstances.

Whilst the family unit is very important--and the honourable member acknowledged that--I frankly do not think in relation to the professional obligations of a practitioner that it overrides the importance of their duty to report someone. This will only apply to spouses if, for example, they are in practice together--not if a spouse is not in a medical practice position or a professional practice position vis-a-vis their partner. But if you are a GP and you referred someone to a specialist who happens to be your spouse or you are in partnership with a specialist who happens to be your spouse, then you have misconducted yourself and I think that absolutely needs to be reported. At that point, the member for Caloundra and I part company on the issue.

The other issue that the member for Caloundra identified is the issue of doctors seeking treatment from other doctors. Whilst I acknowledge that is a far stronger point than the point in relation to spouses, it still is a matter of balancing what is the most important protection. Is the most important protection the important issue of someone getting appropriate support and advice, or is the most important protection protecting the patient, because ultimately it is the patient who will get injured? Everyone can make their arguments about driving things underground all the time, but ultimately that is always the argument when you have mandatory reporting regimes. That is always the argument when you make people report things like that--that you will do it underground. It is a hoary old argument and it is one that deserves to be rejected.

Mr McARDLE: I have a couple of points. The minister commented about this particular law only being in place until 1 July 2010. Of course that may not happen. We do not know what is going to happen in the other jurisdictions at this time. Therefore, we have to work on the basis that this legislation will be the law in Queensland until such time. We have to accept that as a fait accompli.

The other point is, if you run the argument that the overwhelming protection lies with the patient, why exempt the insurance industry? Why say that the spouse must report and the doctor must report but the insurance industry is not required to report? Why does the government say that the spouse and the doctor have a higher threshold of obligation than the insurance industry, which receives exactly the same information, details and evidence as the doctor or the spouse? It is inconsistent to say two are not exempt but one is exempt if the overriding principle is that the health of the patient is paramount.

Mr LUCAS: I do not think the AMA would like it if the member advocated that we remove the exemption from the insurance industry. The simple point is this: the insurance industry is a voluntary, private industry that can elect to insure or not insure people depending upon how they perceive the nature of the risk. We cannot make them insure people. I suppose there could be a compulsory third party sort of scheme, but I have never heard of that applying to this.

Frankly, if they do not ultimately support the scheme, they will not insure people, and how will that affect the patients? It will mean that any patient who sees a doctor will not have the benefit of them having a professional negligence scheme, and that is not a very good idea.

Mr McARDLE: Minister, what you are doing though is putting in place a position at the end by saying that you need to insure the doctor after the injury has occurred. Again, it is inconsistent to say that two of the three should not be exempt but the third one should be. It just does not follow on a logical sequence if you say that the patient’s health is paramount. If the patient’s health is paramount, it should be paramount in all sets of circumstances. If you are going to make an exception or an exemption for one--
Mr Lucas: No, and lawyers and their legal advisers.

Mr McARDLE: We will come to that when we come to your particular amendment. In fact, you have raised that point now. If I may very quickly, your amendment refers to ‘a registrant is a lawyer’. Does that mean that a lawyer under this particular clause is also a registrant?
Mr Lucas: We will talk about it during the division we are just about to have.

Mr McARDLE: I thought you were going to cave in. I thought you were going to give me an exemption. The position is this: two situations do not warrant the exemption; the third one does. It is inconsistent if the principle is the health of the individual, the health of the client, the health of the patient.
