XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 61 of the bill amends the Medical Practitioners Registration Act 2001 to require doctors to notify the Medical Board if they become aware or reasonably suspect that another doctor has engaged in a reportable misconduct. The provisions in this clause were drafted as far as possible to be consistent with the national approach to mandatory reporting for health professionals endorsed by the Australian health ministers on 5 March 2009 as part of the implementation of the national scheme. The national scheme is to be fully implemented by 1 July 2010.

On 6 October 2009 I introduced the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill 2009--the second stage. The national law bill includes mandatory reporting provisions for health professionals. It provides certain exemptions from the reporting obligation. It only requires reporting of serious misconduct that involves a significant departure from accepted professional standards. It is important that the reporting obligation for Queensland doctors that will be introduced in the bill is as far as possible consistent with the reporting obligations for health professionals in the national law bill. This will assist with the transition to the national scheme.

Amendment No. 4 exempts doctors from the reporting obligations where they know or reasonably believe that the reportable misconduct has already been reported to the Medical Board. This will avoid multiple reporting of the same matter. The proposed amendment also specifies the circumstances in which a doctor is not taken to have become aware or reasonably suspect that a fellow doctor has engaged in reportable misconduct and therefore has no reporting obligation arising from these circumstances.

The circumstances set out in the amendment are as follows: if the doctor is employed or otherwise engaged by a professional indemnity insurer and suspects or becomes aware of the other doctor’s misconduct as a result of a disclosure made during legal proceedings, or in the provision of legal advice arising from the insurance policy, or where the doctor suspects or becomes aware of the other doctor’s misconduct when providing advice about the misconduct for the purposes of legal proceedings or the preparation of legal advice, or where the doctor is also a lawyer and suspects or becomes aware of the other doctor’s misconduct when providing legal services to the other doctor in relation to legal proceedings or the preparation of legal advice in which the reportable conduct was an issue.

The exemptions ensure that the reporting obligation does not apply where doctors come into possession of information about reportable misconduct pursuant to legal proceedings or the provision of legal advice including the information that may be subject to legal professional privilege. The proposed amendment also inserts a replacement definition of the term ‘harm’ which is used in the definition of ‘reportable misconduct’. The new definition varies from the definition in this bill to the extent that a detrimental effect on a person’s physical or psychological wellbeing does not need to be of a significant nature to constitute harm. I ask the House to support the amendment.

Just to make it clear, this actually goes closer to what the AMA wants than what was in the original bill. The original bill was the Queensland legislation. We have indicated that we want to make it consistent with the national law that will start from 1 July next year. So that is an appropriate way to proceed.
Amendment agreed to.

XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 175--

Mr McARDLE
(5.13 pm): This particular clause relates to what is termed a ‘smoking related product’ and leaves to a regulation what is to be defined under that terminology. The explanatory notes state in essence that it is expected that certain things will be and it is expected that certain things will not be. We know that there are many people in this state who derive part of their income from selling what may well become a smoking related product. What I am concerned about is that when we put into legislation what will be a prescriptive provision--that is, it will have a criminal sanction or quasi-criminal sanction by way of failing to comply with the terms of the bill and it will also have a form of negative commercial or economic impact upon a person who now sells those items legally--we should include the detail in the bill. The Legislation Alert has made it quite clear on many occasions that when we put in place prescriptive provisions they should definitely be contained in the bill. It raises the question whether a regulation is the appropriate method of putting those through the parliament when the potential for debate, and in-depth debate, is exceptionally limited. I ask the Deputy Premier this: what are the circumstances that warrant, in this case, a regulation which may come at some time in the future putting in place a regime that is prescriptive? Why could it not be put into a bill now so that people know from day one exactly what is going to occur and also give the parliament fuller and, in my opinion, franker capacity to deal with the issues as opposed to waiting for them to come through by way of regulation?

Mr LUCAS: This provision is not intended to penalise retailers. It is because there are some smoking related products that potentially are inadvertently prohibited from sale because they have the same brand name as the smoking product--for example, a Zig-Zag cigarette roller. When it is a smoking related product one can sell it as a smoking related product. If it is not a smoking related product but it is seen to have things about smoking on it, one cannot sell it. In terms of actually wanting to clarify things, the opposite is the case in terms of what the member is concerned about.

I do not accept that it is not inappropriate to have it dealt with by regulation so we can quickly respond to those issues to stop problems arising for retailers and others so they can have certainty. I do not think a class of smoking related product is a really big class when it comes to how this act applies to it and in terms of giving people certainty. I think it is very simple to debate in a disallowance motion whether it is or it is not.

XML.Hansard-Body: This is the lengthy clause that deals with smoking in motor vehicles. The terms of the bill actually provide two offences--one in relation to a business vehicle and one in relation to what may well be termed a private vehicle. In terms of a business vehicle, the bill does not permit smoking if there is any person in the vehicle. In terms of a private vehicle, the bill does not permit smoking if there is person under the age of 16 years in the vehicle.

I will take the Deputy Premier to the document Queenslanders tackling chronic disease: becoming Australia’s healthiest state published in November 2008. It is an excellent publication that I am certain the Deputy Premier is aware of. The committee was chaired by Professor Peter Andrews. He makes this comment on page III--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Today in Queensland:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • Nearly one in five men and one in seven women smoke daily.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It has been estimated that 15 percent of the population, most of them with chronic conditions, generate about 60 percent of all healthcare expenditure. In Queensland the total cost of obesity alone is estimated to be almost $12 billion.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is a significant sum of money. At page 14 it addresses the issue of smoking and makes this comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Smoking is the greatest cause of preventable deaths in Australia, and increases the risk of lung cancer, cardiovascular disease, chronic lung conditions and osteoporosis.
In 2007, 18.9 percent of Queensland men (third highest in the nation) and 15.4 percent of Queensland women (fourth highest in the nation) over the age of 14 years smoked daily.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: At page 19 he makes this statement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The total annual estimated cost of tobacco smoking in Australia in 2004-05 was $31.5 billion.
Reducing smoking rates, promoting healthy eating and physical activity in Queensland can save almost 3,500 deaths per year.
Reducing the proportion of Queenslanders who smoke to 15 percent would save around 4,750 lives and $112.9M in treatment costs for cancer.
XML.Hansard-Body: And he goes on. As I said, this bill provides two different offences. There may well be circumstances that the minister will outline to me as to why the government wants to take this line. My argument is that if smoking is a killer then it is a killer whether it is in a business vehicle or in a private vehicle. If we want to deter people from smoking and if we want to assist in ensuring that people live longer and healthier lives and at the same time save significant costs to the Health budget in relation to chronic disease, we should put in place uniformity in relation to those matters that we feel should be dealt with to save those dollars.

If it is safe and if it is advisable to ensure that the business vehicle is smoke free--and there may well be other reasons as to why that should occur--then, in my opinion, for those health reasons we should also apply this law to a private vehicle. Why can I not smoke if my 17-year-old son is my passenger in a business vehicle yet I can smoke if that same son is sitting next to me in my private vehicle? If we are trying to send a message not only through this bill but also in relation to the issue of chronic disease prevention and treatment, it should be consistent. At the end of the day, if we save one person from the agonising death of cancer via direct or passive smoking then that is one person to whom we have given an exceptionally long life, to whom we have given fulfilment in relation to having a family--a future they may not have had.

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member. The opposition’s amendment is about as silly as you can get. Not smoking in work cars is already the law in Queensland. So we are not seeking to ban smoking in work cars. The reason it is mentioned in the legislation is that we are moving it from one part of the legislation to another. I just want to make it clear that that was put into law a little while ago.

There is a world of difference when it comes to smoking in cars as opposed to smoking in public vehicles that are used for work purposes. There are certain obligations under occupational health and safety laws that apply in relation to work cars. It is quite a different issue.

In relation to children, we agree that there should not be smoking, because they are not of the appropriate age when they can make a decision. If they are in the car with their parents, they cannot ask to get out. We need to protect them. Also, of course, in many instances children have not yet made the decision to smoke or not to smoke. What the member is doing is not only exposing them to passive smoking but also increasing their exposure to the likelihood of wanting to smoke in the first place.

To then take it to the nth degree by saying, ‘We are going to ban smoking in cars when adults are there,’ is like saying, ‘If you are a husband and wife and one of you smokes at home but you do not mind when the other one smokes at home, you cannot hop in the car together while one of you smokes.’ But worse still--and more ludicrous--this amendment will mean that if you have a husband and wife who both smoke and who both smoke together at home, they cannot smoke together in their car unless they pull into the garage at home or they cannot smoke in the car unless they pull up by the side of the road and one of them hops out and goes down the road and has a ciggie while the other one stays in the car and then that one hops out and goes down the road and has a cigarette.

That is ridiculous. If the member wants to have consistency then he should be seeking to amend the law to ban smoking altogether, including in homes. That means prohibition and then we will have organised crime move in. We know about total prohibition. This amendment strikes a sensible balance. For the opposition to suggest--
An honourable member interjected.

Mr LUCAS: Yes, you can talk on a mobile phone in a car hands free. That is correct. You can sit next to someone using a mobile phone in a car because they can talk on a mobile phone in a car without interfering with your driving. This is a totally different issue.

It is ludicrous to suggest that two adults, both of whom smoke, cannot smoke together in a car. It is politically correct, ridiculous nonsense. It shows that the opposition is not capable of sensible policy formulation. I am not going to waste any more time of the House on this amendment.
Mr McARDLE: It is always amazing that when the minister does not like something he reverts to--
Mr Messenger: Personal attacks, personal abuse,

Mr McARDLE: That is right: personal attacks. If he does not like what he is hearing, he turns it into a personal issue. But what amazes me is that the minister can sit there and, from what he is saying, condone smoking.
Mr Lucas: Move an amendment and ban it in houses. Be consistent.

Mr McARDLE: With respect, I ask the minister to be consistent in relation to what he is putting before the House. The minister made a ludicrous statement about workplace health and safety: ‘It is all right there, but it is not all right over here.’ Give us a break!

Smoking is a killer. The minister knows it and I know it. If the minister wants to stop people from smoking, we are going to have to make the hard yards because, unfortunately, that is the way our society is. If the minister does not like the idea, he should resign from the portfolio and give it to someone else who is prepared to do it.

Cancer is derived from cigarette smoke. That is an undeniable fact. The minister and I both know that. If it is fine to ban smoking in work vehicles because of workplace health and safety or occupational issues because of the dangers involved, the same must apply in relation to people in private vehicles. There is no difference. Cigarette smoke does not differentiate between a business vehicle and a private vehicle. It does not do that.
Mr Lucas: The law differentiates between business places and homes.

Mr McARDLE: With all due respect, if the minister wants to make a comment, could he please do so after I finish? Smoke does not differentiate between whether it is a public or a private vehicle. It will kill you just as quickly in either vehicle. It will cause the cancer, it will cause the suffering, just as quickly. If we are serious about tackling chronic disease and if we are serious about battling the impacts of chronic disease then we should get serious. We stand here today in the House deciding that we are going to make some tough decisions. Let us make some tough decisions. The minister should not vacillate between what he thinks is tough and what he thinks is too easy. The minister should make the hard choices. If he wants to save lives, if he wants to save the Health budget, he should approve the amendment.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I rise to oppose the amendment for this reason. In my contribution to the second reading debate I talked about the fact that smokers feel very put upon. I agree with the opposition member: smoking does kill. We have all acknowledged that. But banning smoking in work vehicles is different from banning smoking in private vehicles. Banning smoking in private vehicles where there are minors is different from banning smoking en masse.

Many adults smoke. It is an addiction. We have to acknowledge that. We are asking adults to be responsible. We are asking adults to accept that, after this bill passes, it is going to be an offence to smoke with a child in the car. I do not have any problem supporting that, because children do not have a great deal of power to ask their parents to stop smoking while they are in the car.

However, if the opposition’s amendment passes, you would potentially have an adult on their own in a vehicle travelling from their home to town to shop who would not be able to light up a cigarette. These people have an addiction. These people see smoking as an acceptable pastime. On that basis, I would find it very difficult to support the reduction of that civil liberty of people to be able to smoke on their own in a vehicle.

I acknowledge that smoking kills. I lost my dad to cigarette smoke. He began smoking because the Army gave him cigarettes to cope with World War II. He died directly as a result of cigarette smoking. Mum and I are the only two people in our family who do not smoke. The others all light up like three-funnel steamers. I know that banning smoking in their vehicles when they are on their own will be counterproductive. They will have three cigarettes before they leave home, they will jump in the car and run into town in 10 minutes and have a couple more when they jump out. It will not help them with their addiction. It will probably exacerbate it.

I agree with the preclusion of smoking with minors in the vehicle. As an asthmatic I do not enjoy getting into a vehicle where there has been smokers and the odour is still in there. It is very upsetting. But I cannot support legislation that precludes an adult who is a smoker driving in a vehicle that they own having a smoke; not because smoking does not kill, because it does, but because somewhere we have to draw a line in the sand and say that people have to be responsible for their own actions.

Mr MESSENGER: I rise to support the shadow minister. I urge all members to vote for this amendment. While listening to the debate here today a couple of other reasons have crossed my mind as to why this amendment should be supported. First of all, the minister is not acknowledging the fact that there are accidents that have been caused by people smoking cigarettes whilst driving. It is a bit like driving along talking on a mobile phone. There must be plenty of accidents that have been caused by the act of physically smoking a cigarette. It is not too long a bow to draw.

The minister tries to use the comparison of consenting adults smoking in a car and smoking at home. There is a large difference between smoking in a car and smoking at home. If two adults are in a house and one is smoking, the other adult can leave the room. A person cannot exactly leave a car. The other thing I would like the House and the minister to consider was brought up by the member for Coomera and that is the issue of fire. If all smoking in cars was banned then there would be less chance of bushfires.
Mr Lucas: Ha, ha!

Mr MESSENGER: I cannot believe that the minister actually laughed then. Does he not think that bushfires are created by people driving along in cars and throwing cigarette butts out the window? Obviously his reaction means that he does not believe that bushfires are created by smokers who throw cigarette butts out of the car. Let us get real.
Mr Nicholls interjected.

Mr MESSENGER: I take the interjection from the member for Clayfield that maybe he should speak to the emergency services minister and the people who have been fighting bushfires in the northern part of our state around North Burnett and Rockhampton. They could tell the minister just how many fires have been created by people who have been smoking in cars. For those reasons I think that our shadow minister should be wholeheartedly congratulated and supported.

Mr LUCAS: Let us deconstruct all of this. First of all, the opposition amendment does not ban smoking in cars full stop. The member for Burnett said we should ban smoking in cars because it causes bushfires. The opposition legislation does not ban smoking in cars; it bans smoking in cars if someone else is present. That is what it bans. I will read the amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A person must not smoke in a motor vehicle if--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) the vehicle is on a road or road-related area; and
(b) another person is in the vehicle.
XML.Hansard-Body: The problem in terms of what the member has just said is that he has contradicted himself with his own legislation. In any case, as it is what does he think is going to happen? The way those opposite have drafted the law if there are two people in the car and one wants to smoke they are going to have to hop out of the car. If a person is smoking in a car and instead of putting it in the ashtray throws the cigarette butt out of the window it can start a fire. But if a person is standing out in the middle of the bush because they have had to get out of the car to smoke, where are they going to put the cigarette butt then unless they take an ashtray with them? How ludicrous can one get.

I will respond to the member for Caloundra when he said if it is good enough to ban smoking in business cars then it is good enough to ban it in private cars. If it is good enough to ban smoking in businesses it is good enough to ban smoking in houses, but those opposite are not doing that. In terms of the arguments advanced by the member for Burnett, he is not suggesting we ban them in the loungeroom but not the dining room. This is really ridiculous. It shows that those opposite do not understand questions of degree. The member for Gladstone understands it. Most normal people understand it. It is totally ridiculous.

Mr McARDLE: If I could address the comment made by the member for Gladstone, the amendment does not say that if I am alone in the car I cannot smoke. I can smoke in those circumstances. If I have somebody else the car I cannot smoke.
Mr Wilson: Even if that person smokes.

Mr McARDLE: The interjection from the man who believes he is running the education department should be considered in the context of it being nonsensical, ludicrous and of no value, as usual. He cannot even interject from his right seat. Let us get down to tin tacks here. If it is right to ban smoking because of workplace health and safety issues in a work vehicle, why do you do that? You do it because you do not want people consuming cigarette tobacco, I would have thought. Logically, if we are saving a life in that vehicle, we should save a life in a private vehicle as well. One can smoke in the vehicle to their heart’s content if one is on their own. What we are simply saying is a person cannot smoke if there is somebody else in the vehicle with them. It gives uniformity in relation to the law. It does not differentiate between different classes of people or different classes of vehicles.

The minister made the point why not just ban smoking altogether. We know that the Cancer Council would love to have that happen. We know that at some point in time, by the gradual degree of increasing taxes and putting prohibitions in place, there will come a time when it will drop down to about 7 or 8 per cent. We accept that that is about the lowest we are going to get without taking a definitive step to ban smoking entirely. But everything that we do to try to eliminate the risk of someone dying from lung cancer and chronic disease has to be a positive step and for the betterment of everybody in our society.

Banning smoking will not happen in my lifetime, nor anybody else’s in this chamber, but if we do not start taking the decisions and putting in place the methods of assisting people to live a healthy lifestyle, we are simply and straightforwardly not up to the game of being a member of parliament. Just be tough.
Mr Lucas: You are not up to the game, is that right? You are not up to the game, if that is the case? Is that your assertion?
Mr McARDLE: Oh dear.
Mr Lucas: I am just asking. I want you to repeat it.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ryan): Deputy Premier.
Mr McARDLE: I think you still have one reply left so wait your turn, son.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ryan): Order! I remind all members to direct their comments through the chair.
Mr McARDLE: Let us put in place a very simple solution that addresses in part, albeit a small part, saving Queenslanders’ lives.

Mr LUCAS: I rise one final time, although I think we dealt with the issues earlier. There was one thing I did neglect. I think it is important, given the honourable member said that if I am not up to taking this on and taking the bit between my teeth I should not be in the business of politics and I should not be here. I might refer to someone who had some other views on this. That person stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Under the bill, it will be an offence for a person to smoke in a vehicle if someone under the age of 16 is present in the vehicle. This part protects the health and wellbeing of our minors.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: So he agrees with that. He goes on--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Making it illegal to smoke in a vehicle used for business purposes when another person is present is over the top. Adults are legally able to make their own choice and suffer the consequences. We are becoming a nanny state by eroding the rights of our citizens.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Who said that? The member for Dalrymple before lunch.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That Mr McArdle’s amendment be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: AYES, 31--Bates, Bleijie, Crandon, Cripps, Davis, Dempsey, Dickson, Douglas, Dowling, Elmes, Emerson, Flegg, Gibson, Hobbs, Hopper, Johnson, Knuth, Langbroek, McArdle, McLindon, Malone, Nicholls, Powell, Rickuss, Seeney, Simpson, Sorensen, Springborg, Stevens. Tellers: Horan, Messenger

NOES, 47--Bligh, Boyle, Croft, Cunningham, Darling, Dick, Farmer, Finn, Fraser, Grace, Hinchliffe, Hoolihan, Jarratt, Johnstone, Jones, Kilburn, Lucas, Male, Miller, Moorhead, Nelson-Carr, Nolan, O’Brien, O’Neill, Palaszczuk, Pitt, Reeves, Roberts, Robertson, Schwarten, Scott, Shine, Smith, Spence, Stone, Struthers, Sullivan, van Litsenburg, Wallace, Watt, Wellington, Wells, Wendt, Wettenhall, Wilson. Tellers: Keech, Kiernan
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Resolved in the negative.
Non-government amendment (Mr McArdle) negatived.
XML.Hansard-Body: Interruption.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Order of Business
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (5.46 pm): I advise honourable members that the House can continue to meet past 6.30 pm this day. The House can break for dinner at 6.30 pm and resume its sitting at 7.30 pm. The order of the business shall be government business followed by a 30-minute adjournment debate.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Health & Other Leg. A’ment Bill; Health Practitioner Reg. National Law Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from p. 3073.
Resumed on clause 180--
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 180, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 181 to 184, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 185--

Mr McARDLE (5.47 pm): This is the clause that relates to the nurse practitioner amendment. I am not going to go through a debate about the issue of nurse practitioners. During the second reading debate--
Mr Lucas interjected.

Mr McARDLE: I think the minister and I share a similar point of view there anyway. The nurse practitioners will continue to fulfil, in my opinion, an increasingly important role in the medical profession in Queensland. I know they have been rolled out, if I can use that term, over the past few years in Queensland and there are plans to utilise 30 more over the next two or three years, if I recall the budget correctly.

There is also the issue of physicians’ assistants, which is on trial here in Queensland. I think there are three now in the state. I am not strictly speaking in terms of the clause, but I am eager to understand how the minister sees that particular position utilised in Queensland and whether you see a greater expansion of their services outside of the ED and into the rural areas as well to assist in relation to medical shortages across Queensland?
Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for his question. So you are not talking about physicians’ assistants; you are talking about nurse practitioners?
Mr McArdle: My apologies, yes.

Mr LUCAS: A lot of nurse practitioners--not all of them--have gone into our emergency departments. The honourable member recognises the role that they are performing there, so I will not go into detail. Clearly we will want to have more of them, particularly helping triage and treating category 4 and 5 patients. The member for Mount Isa spoke about that herself as well. For example, we would see them rolling out more in areas such as acute illnesses like renal issues and those sorts of areas. They are highly qualified people. They have masters degrees as well as their extensive undergraduate and practical experience.

I should draw to the attention of the honourable member one issue that I have raised with the Commonwealth government to which I think it needs to give more serious thought. It said that it will allow Medicare billing for nurse practitioners in private practice. The problem with that is that if we are talking about that as a solution in remote areas, it is not likely that a nurse practitioner will have a viable private practice in a tiny area, any more than a single doctor would have a viable private practice. Just as the medical superintendent is partially paid by us with a right to private practice, the federal government has to allow Medicare billing for nurse practitioners in remote locations who have dual public sector practice and a right to private practice. It is its decision to do that. I have told the federal government that if it really wants to get serious about rolling out nurse practitioners in remote locations that is what it will need to do. That is one aspect. The other aspect is that with an increase in acute illnesses--renal and those sorts of things--nurse practitioners work in those areas as well. When I was a lawyer--and the member opposite would probably recall this, too--police prosecutors often did not have the same legal training as a solicitor, but they had incredible experience in a very narrow area of the law. So they were pretty good at it. Indeed, they were better than many solicitors would have been because they practised more in that area.

The honourable member agrees with me on the philosophy of nurse practitioners. I think the ability to extend them further will be an important aspect of assisting us in dealing with patient processing all over Queensland. I am particularly keen to see what we can do to help further roll out services in rural and remote Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 185, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 186 and 187, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ryan): Order! There are 12 clauses and a schedule to the bill. In accordance with the motion agreed to by the House, the schedule to the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill may be considered clause by clause and schedule by schedule, with speaking rights and time limits for each clause and schedule as if they were clauses and schedules in the bill.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 6, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 7--

Mr McARDLE (5.52 pm): Clause 7 exempts a number of Queensland statutes from the operation of the bill. In relation to the exemptions, if we look in schedule 1, towards the rear, we find the adoption of Commonwealth legislation where it is appropriate. Can the minister clarify whether the protections that Queenslanders now enjoy under Queensland legislation are replicated under Commonwealth legislation? Is there a distinction, for example, in the FOI legislation and the Right to Information Act between Queensland and the Commonwealth that would adversely impact upon the rights that Queenslanders have now?

Mr LUCAS: Regrettably, I cannot give the member that undertaking. They have to be subject to some legislation. As far as I am aware, at the present time the Queensland FOI legislation--I am not here to give the House legal advice--is actually broader than the Commonwealth legislation. But they are talking about doing other things. No, I cannot give that undertaking because it has to have some law applying to it. If Commonwealth FOI laws apply to it, they will apply to it in accordance with their terms. That is one of the trade-offs that one has with national legislation.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 7, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 8--
Mr McARDLE (5.54 pm): Clause 8 refers to the Commissioner of Police being able to give criminal history information to various bodies. I note the word ‘may’. The clause states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The police commissioner may give criminal history information ...
XML.Hansard-Body: If we look in schedule 1 we see that the application is made by the relevant board in checking registration et cetera. Just to clarify, the word ‘may’ in normal legal parlance provides a discretion.
Mr Lucas: They may not, too.

Mr McARDLE: They may not as well. I am concerned that the Police Commissioner will in fact be obligated to provide the information, so should the word be ‘must’? I know the word ‘may’ in certain circumstances can mean ‘must’. But to ensure that there is no argument, should the word ‘may’ be ‘must’ in these circumstances given the thread that runs through the national law?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I seek the indulgence of the House to turn to the relevant page in the national law, which is very large. At present in Queensland there is not necessarily mandatory criminal history checking, although many boards do observe it in most, if not all, instances. So this is a significant improvement on that. With government employees, we do that as a matter of course in any case.

My understanding is that the reason this clause was put in the bill itself--not clause 79 in the national law but the provision in our own law--was merely that the Queensland police wanted further Queensland legislative support for their ability to provide the information. So it was merely a procedural provision, not something that would give them the power to refuse. All police commissioners have a similar discretionary provision. I do not know whether they have a similar provision to that. That is my advice.

Mr McARDLE: I understand the minister’s comment that all commissioners have that discretion. I know it is very unlikely that it is going to occur. I understand that very clearly. But if the national law is based in part upon application for registration that a criminal history check is done, it is very important that a criminal history, which not only covers offences but also covers what I term spent offences and also charges, actually be supplied. We do not want a circumstance arising down the track where a commissioner, for whatever reason, hypothetically may determine to not provide the information. Again I accept that that would be most unusual. I am concerned that that discretion continues to exist as opposed to a compulsion, given that it is a national scheme for medical practitioners to provide service to their patients.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 8, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 9 to 11, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 12--

Mr McARDLE (5.59 pm): Clause 12 deals with the capacity of the ministerial council to provide directions to the national agency and the national board in relation to the policies to be applied by those entities when exercising their functions under the national law. There has been a concern from day one about the power of the ministerial council. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, the ministerial council is not an elected body in the sense that the practitioners covered by the national bill will dictate who will lead them. It is an organisation that shifts with a change in either the government or the ministers across the states, territories and federally.

Part 7 to be inserted, however, provides what has been termed a reserve power or a right within the national ministerial council to actually provide policies as to how the board and the agency will operate. The concern is that the ministerial council, by being able to issue these various documents, can actually direct the relevant boards and the relevant agencies. As I understand clause 12 and the national bill itself, these directions are binding upon the relevant board and the relevant agency. Many people have raised the question of whether this is potentially a de facto power stream that the councils can use in relation to how these boards and the agency operate, to the effect that the intergovernmental agreement as it stood in 2008 will in fact continue to enshrine the ultimate power in the ministerial council.

Mr LUCAS: I would have thought as a matter of statutory interpretation that, where there are specific provisions in relation to the law that put some limits on the power of the ministerial council, they will apply to the exclusion of general provisions such as this. With respect, the policy issue is really just amending the existing act to reflect the bill’s provisions, but I am happy to deal with it here anyway. For example, the one that people have raised issues about is the power of the ministerial council to provide reserve power directions when it comes to the workforce and qualifications and the like. There is a specific way in which it must do that and what they must do to do that. The ability to issue a general policy cannot override the specific requirements on them by way of procedure.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 12, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 1 to 3 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 4 of schedule--

Mr McARDLE (6.02 pm): This relates to the fact that an entity has to perform its functions in accordance with the objectives and the guiding principles of the national scheme. We know that there are a number of entities here--the ministerial council, up to 14 boards, the agency, the state board or territory board, other panels et cetera--which can be appointed under the terms of this legislation. The bill says that the entity has to perform the function in accordance with the objectives and principles of the legislation. Is there a mechanism in place to ensure that that in fact does occur? That is, who oversees and who supervises the relevant subsections that fall from the ministerial council? Is the ministerial council charged with ensuring that the actions of the agency and the boards are performed in accordance with the functions and objectives of the national law, or is there some external body that takes on the role? For example, the Auditor-General and the Ombudsman in Queensland have certain powers. Who fulfils that role under this hierarchical structure?

Mr LUCAS: I do not think it is any different to any other objection principles clause. A direction is for those who administer the relevant provisions of the act to administer them with those in mind, for those who then make judicial interpretations of the act to administer them with those in mind, for those who then audit them--if it is a financial matter, such as the Auditor-General--to check whether people have done them in accordance with those principles. As the honourable member knows, these sorts of provisions in acts--that is, the objects clauses--are standard things. They do assist in interpretation; they do assist with a footprint. In many instances, they are not really of themselves justiciable because they talk about broad principles. You and I might both support a particular principle but think that it means a totally different thing, but we do not head off to court about it. It is more how that might aid a court or others in interpreting how the legislation might be provided. I do not think I can take it any further than that.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 4 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 5 to 10 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 11 of schedule--

Mr McARDLE (6.06 pm): This is the issue with regard to the council having the capacity to issue policy directions to both the agency and the various boards. Subclause 11(3) indicates that the council can issue those in relation to an administrative process, a procedure or even an accreditation standard. As we know, an accreditation standard, under the terms of the national law, is the methodology and the course that a student must go through to achieve a qualification. The ministerial council is in fact retaining a reserve power, and it has a very wide reserve power because there is no limit to what it can or cannot do. In fact, subclause (3) states that it ‘may relate to’ the points that then follow.

What is of concern is that the council again still holds a significant power; it still holds enormous sway particularly in relation to the boards because of their authority and their purpose under the act. There is a real concern that, if the ministerial council does not operate in an open and consultative manner, there could be problems down the track. Can the minister confirm that a process that involves the issuing of a policy to either the boards or the agency will entail consultation with the boards, or if not with the boards then with some other organisation qualified to do so? It may well be the advisory council which offers the advice to the council on an ongoing basis.

Mr LUCAS: First of all, the honourable member might be interested to know that the minister in Queensland already has a power in relation to this without the second qualification on it that we are seeking to put into the national law. In fact, what we are doing is actually tightening up the powers that I technically have at the present time. Whilst I acknowledge the medical profession’s concerns about these powers, I actually have them at the moment in terms of our state regulations and I do not have the requirement to consider first ‘the potential impact of the council’s direction on the quality and safety of health care’. We have actually put that in there in response to the committee and the medical colleges. I expect that the ministerial council would very clearly take into account the various views in relation to this.

One of the problems is this. We have talked about nurse practitioners before. Not all of the health professions have a common view on these things. Some of them have a different view amongst themselves. I have said this to the nursing profession before. Some of them get antsy when the doctors do not want the nurses to have more powers, but the nurses sometimes get antsy when other people want to have more powers. Some of them do not like physician’s assistants. It is important, particularly in a state like Queensland, to make sure that we continue the supply of appropriate practitioners. We have seen in the past the ACCC look at the conduct of some specialist medical colleges which have restricted access to their professions. They are a lot better than that these days. I do not see them doing that particularly. But we do need to have reserve powers in government. As long as you can justify that they are there in very minor and appropriate circumstances, I think the community would expect us to be able to have that power.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 11 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 12 to 15 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 16 of schedule--
Mr McARDLE (6.10 pm): Clause 16, in essence, concerns how the council exercises its functions. Is that determination by unanimous consent?
Mr LUCAS: By consensus--like cabinet, by consensus.
Mr McARDLE: I might ask you to define ‘consensus’. Is it unanimous? Consensus is determined by?

Mr LUCAS: Consensus is essentially that, if you cannot agree on something, it does not change. This is a federal issue that is being revisited all the time, because there are different federal models--for electricity or whatever--where some have two-thirds, some have a simple list, but at this point in time the provision is consensus.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 16 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 17 and 18 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 19 of schedule--

Mr McARDLE (6.12 pm): I want to combine 19 and 20 together. They really do flow on. They relate to the issue of advice by the advisory council to the ministerial council. In particular, the advisory council gives advice to the council which is considered by the council. The council is then required to publish the advice, unless the advisory council says, for various reasons, that part or all of the advice should not be published.

In relation to advice, as you and I know, when we get advice from council, council sets out all the facts, all the considerations and then gives what is called an opinion at the end. The education minister would know that as well. Is the publication just the end or is it the whole document that is published? That is, is it the consideration by the advisory council and potentially facts, or is it just the gist of a document that is the advice itself? Because there could well be factors that others may take issue with.
Mr LUCAS: Are you asking whether it can be published, for example, in part, or if there were certain parts of it that--

Mr McARDLE: No, what I am saying is that the publication occurs either for the full advice, or if the advisory council says that part or all of the advice should not be published then the council can determine not to publish all or part of the advice. What I am saying is, if the advice is published and there is no requirement that consideration be given to limiting what is published, if you look at an opinion from a barrister you get the facts, you get the law and then you get the opinion. Is it the whole document that is published from the advisory council, because it would relate back to the council the facts and the consideration and then it would come to the conclusion. Is it just the conclusion that is published or the whole document?
Mr LUCAS: My advice is that it would depend on the circumstances. It might be in whole, it might be in part, it might be not at all.
Mr McARDLE: Minister, with respect, that is not how clause 20 works. Clause 20 says that the advice must be published unless--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! We are on clause 19.

Mr McARDLE: Yes. The advice must be published, which means in total, unless the advisory council recommends that it not be published at all or only in part. If it is to be published in total, there appears to be no discretion in the council to make a determination whether it will or will not publish the document; it must do so. What I am simply asking is: is it the whole document that is published or just, as you and I would understand, the base opinion at the end which you and I would refer to as the advice?
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 19 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 20 to 25 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 26 of schedule--

Mr McARDLE (6.16 pm): Clause 26 refers to health profession agreements, which is a function of the national agency. Later on in the bill it deals with three things--the fact of collecting the fees, the fact of payment of the fees and then the investment of moneys through the national agency. In relation to the fees for each of the boards, they all go into the agency. It appears that the agency develops, in consultation with the boards, a budget and allocates them money. If I have 2,000 members who are doctors and 1,000 members who are chiropractors, do all the fees from the doctors go back to the doctors board, or is there a pro rata adjustment? Or is it just an equal distribution of the moneys that go to the relevant boards? As of today the AMAQ would keep all its fees. Is that how it is going to work under this scenario, or does the agency have some overriding jurisdiction?

Mr LUCAS: My understanding, with the exception of a situation in New South Wales for doctors that we will not bother going into here, is that they are meant to be self-contained organisations. There is not supposed to be a cross-subsidy from one profession to the other. Having said that, the agency also provides services to particular boards, and I would expect that those services would be charged for by the agency or budgeted for--for want of a better word--in accordance with the demands of the agency of that particular board depending upon its size, the nature of investigations and those sorts of things.

Mr McARDLE: The national agency also has the capacity to invest funds in what they call Australian currency. That appears later in the bill, but I think it is relevant now to deal with it here. It would imply that the agency will retain at least a portion of all fees collected to provide a budget and funding to the relevant boards. There will also be a capacity for the national agency to invest funds in Australian currency, as it appears later--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! There is too much audible conversation. Your shadow minister is on his feet.

Mr McARDLE: There will be the capacity for the national agency to invest funds. The term that is used is ‘in Australian currency’. I am assuming that it cannot be shares, it cannot be investments in properties; it must be government secured or government guaranteed or at least very secure investments?

Mr LUCAS: With respect, that is not in this particular clause. In what clause is that referred to? Go on to the next thing, if you are happy to do that, because this is not the relevant clause and I will get that information in the meantime.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 26 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 27 to 35 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 36 of schedule--

Mr McARDLE
(6.20 pm): This refers to the state and territory boards that can be appointed by the national board. I note at (3) that the members of the relevant state or territory boards are in fact appointed by the state minister. Why would the national board that has a representative in each of the states--although of course only the one body--not have the right to appoint the state or territory boards as opposed to a relevant minister?

Mr LUCAS: I have to say that I was a bit more relaxed about having the national board appoint state board people than some of my ministerial colleagues were. To be honest, I appoint the state boards now. Frankly, if state ministers go off appointing state boards however they like, the national board will say that we are not going to have state boards. It is not my power to decide whether or not we have a state board; it is their power. I do think it is important that there is a bit of state input there because sometimes our Commonwealth and interstate colleagues--those south of border--tend to think that all brilliance stops at the Tweed River or indeed all brilliance stops north of Noosa. I happen to disagree with both.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 36 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 37 to 87 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 88 of schedule--

Mr McARDLE (6.22 pm): Clause 88 refers to when the national board asks an education provider for details of those students who have registered in a relevant course and the provider fails to provide that. We know that once the national board, in normal circumstances, receives that information they then contact the student and have that student complete a form and provide certain details. In circumstances where the education provider does not provide that detail, is there a mechanism whereby the national board has some recourse to those students? It is very difficult. Is there any impact upon the student down the track if their details have not been given to the education provider? It is very important that as students go through the relevant training, clinical placements et cetera the national board has the right, as is enshrined in the law, to look at suspension, reporting et cetera.

Mr LUCAS: I should say that student registration at this level is new to Queensland. We do not have it. New South Wales might do it for medical students. South Australia does it more broadly. It will be a new thing. I think it is totally appropriate because in, say, law students do not have any physical contact with clients until they have attained their degree. That is not the case in the health profession. They perform hands-on roles along the way.

I would expect that universities would comply with these requirements. I would not expect that students would be penalised as a result of a provider failing to comply with this. I am more than happy to take up that issue--we have another bill to come--in terms of the further drafting in circumstances where universities do not comply. Having said that, universities are substantially dependent upon governments for funding. Whilst it is not an offence for them to not supply this information, I think the money supply would dry up pretty quickly and they might come to the party when it came to a whole lot of students getting very antsy about them not supplying the list.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 88 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 89 to 141 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 142 of schedule--

Mr McARDLE (6.25 pm): This relates to employers being required to make a notification in certain circumstances. The member for Moggill raised the issue in his second reading contribution yesterday that when we have a very large corporation that employs a multitude of medical practitioners who is it that will be liable if the report is not made? Will it be the CEO or the board of directors? That can create certain difficulties. I think it is a very valid point raised by the member. I would ask the minister to clarify that.

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. The honourable member for Moggill yesterday raised the issue of the fact that, in general practice in particular, there are a lot of people who are actually employed by corporate structures. It certainly is the case far more extensively than I thought before I was health minister. This provision relates to employers. My view of the liability provisions would be that they fall back through the general corporate law liability provisions on general officers. But again, I am happy to take that up in the context of our further discussions at a national level. I would have thought it would be the general requirement when duties are placed on companies in that regard.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 142 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 143 to 162 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 163 of schedule--

Mr McARDLE
(6.28 pm): Clause 163 involves the appointment of investigators. The clause does not deal with the procedures that have to be gone through to appoint the investigators. It does not deal with criminal checks and background knowledge. They are appointed, I assume, to a particular board. We would want them having some sort of knowledge, even though it may only be peripheral. What will the procedure be to appoint investigators, these very important people in relation to investigations?

Mr LUCAS: I would merely expect that they will make sure they appoint suitable people. I do not think we need to prescribe every particular aspect of these things. What we normally say is that they should be people who are suitably experienced. We do not say that they will have 3.4 years of this, that or the other thing. One of the things about investigators is that they might be totally different for the different complaints that might arise, whether it is a financial thing or a physical thing. It is really something that one would expect to undertake in accordance with usual standards of employment and probity checks.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clause 163 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 164 to 305 of schedule, as read, agreed to.
Schedules 1 to 7 of schedule, as read, agreed to.

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the Health and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, as amended, and the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Bill, as read, be agreed to.

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the long titles of the bills be agreed to.

XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: South-East Queensland (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) and Natural Resources Provisions Bill
XML.LegAssembly: SEQ (Distribution & Retail Restructuring) & Natural Resources Provisions Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 6 October (see p. 2512), on motion of Mr Robertson--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (7.30 pm): The South-East Queensland (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) and Natural Resources Provisions Bill before the House has had a couple of names during its passage to reach this point. I express the hope that the government has given more thought to the bill than was indicated by the somewhat unusual way in which it will change its title.

The bill seeks to put in place the last piece of the SEQ water reform process. The SEQ water process had its genesis in the water crisis that gripped South-East Queensland during 2005-06. It was a water crisis that was the result of 10 years of inaction by Labor governments. It was a water crisis that can be traced back directly to the decision not to build the Wolffdene Dam by the Goss government when it came to power. It is interesting to look at the people who were central to that--what has turned out to be--disastrous decision. Not only was Wayne Goss directly involved; at the time one of his chief advisers by the name of Kevin Rudd was also very much involved in that decision. It is a decision that already has cost South-East Queensland dearly. As we will see in the information that we will look at tonight in the consideration of this bill, that decision will cost South-East Queenslanders dearly for many, many years to come.

That decision is a good example of what happens when governments make decisions based on political, short-term fixes rather than on factual information. That decision is a good example of what happens when governments govern using spin and media headlines rather than responsible administration. When the Labor government of Wayne Goss decided not to build the Wolffdene Dam, it put in place the foundations of a water crisis that rocked South-East Queensland for a number of years. During that water crisis, the then Beattie government set up an organisation called the Water Commission. The Water Commission had a very chequered history, to say the least. But in May 2007 the Water Commission delivered its final report which outlined the government’s plan for the reform of the water business in South-East Queensland. That plan involved the separation of the different components of the industry. That plan involved the formation of bulk supply authorities, a bulk transport authority and a Water Grid Manager. The proposal was also for a distribution entity and three retail entities.

At the time there was an enormous amount of debate about the unsuitability of the model, especially with regard to the distribution entity and the retail entities and how the councils, which had traditionally managed the water business for so many years, could get value for money for the assets that they had built up on behalf of their ratepayers over those years. The legislation that we have in the House tonight puts in place a somewhat different model from that last stage of the water reform process. The bulk supply entities have been established, the bulk transport entities have been established and the Water Grid Manager is in place. This legislation that we are debating tonight puts in place the last stage. It is different from the model that was put forward by the Water Commission in 2007--and so it should be. Tonight the opposition supports that difference. We support that difference because it is a different model that has been developed by the councils involved in South-East Queensland. It is not a perfect model by any means--it is not something that the councillors involved are totally happy with--but it is certainly a better model than the one that the government adopted from the Water Commission report in 2007.

The legislation puts in place three combined distribution retail entities that will own the water and sewage distribution infrastructure and sell water and sewage disposal services to customers. The distribution infrastructure includes the reticulation, the pipes, the reservoirs, the pumps and all non-bulk transport assets and the sewage treatment plants. The entities will own that vast suite of assets that has been built up by the councils over a long period. They will sell and deliver water to the customers. They will collect sewage and deliver it to the treatment plants and they will treat and dispose of the sewage and purchase treated water from the Water Grid Manager. These entities will be established by 1 July 2010 and the three entities will cover three separate council groups. The first one will cover the Brisbane, Scenic Rim, Ipswich, Somerset and Lockyer Valley local government areas. The second one will cover the Gold Coast, Logan and Redlands council areas. The third one will cover the Sunshine Coast and Moreton Bay areas. They will be the retail entities that will retail water to retail customers, so they will be the ones that will be in most direct contact with the customers.

I think it needs to be recognised at the very beginning that the enormous increases in the price of water that the people of South-East Queensland are facing in the years directly ahead of us will not be the responsibility of those retail entities. The big danger that I see for those retail entities, and for the councils that own them, is that they will get the blame. They will be left with the responsibility for the increases in the price of water that South-East Queenslanders are facing as an inevitable consequence of the government’s mismanagement of the water business. As I indicated, that mismanagement began with the refusal of the Goss government to construct the Wolffdene Dam. But that mismanagement has continued and the increases in the cost of water have been made worse by the government’s response to the water crisis. The government built the infamous water grid. I say the ‘infamous’ water grid because, while as a political concept it served the purpose of the Premier and the government of the day, as an engineering reality it has left South-East Queensland with a high-production cost water system and an incredibly high transport cost.

It is simply grossly inefficient to desalinate water at the southern end of the Gold Coast and pump it back to Brisbane. Pumping water is an expensive business at the best of times. Pumping desalinated water, the most expensive form of water, over those sorts of distances to try to solve the immediate problem in Brisbane is always going to result in high costs for that water. The government was left with no choice. Because of the time frames in which it had to operate, it simply had to find a political solution to a problem that was of its own making.

I do not believe that the retail entities that are being formed tonight will not have a very strong pricing power. They will be forced to buy their bulk water from the entities that have already been set up as part of the SEQ water reform. If one looks at the price paths anticipated by the Queensland Water Commission, and made very public on the Queensland Water Commission’s website, it is obvious that the water consumers in South-East Queensland will be slugged with massive water price increases in the years ahead, just as they have been slugged with massive electricity price increases for primarily the same reason--that is, the government’s mismanagement of the system.

Every time there is a rise in electricity prices the government tries to sheet the responsibility for those price rises home to somebody else. I have no doubt that responsibility for the water prices that are now built into the system because of the government’s mismanagement, failure to plan and knee-jerk reaction will be sheeted home to some other entity. They are and they will be the responsibility of the Beattie Labor government and the Bligh Labor government. They are the ones who will be responsible. They are the ones who put South-East Queensland into the water crisis and then sought to solve that crisis by the sort of panicked response that we saw in the construction of the desalination plant, the western corridor pipeline and the waste water plants.

Members who were in this House will remember that at the height of the water crisis we dealt with an emergency water regulation that required those entities to report on a monthly basis to the parliament. Those reports are still being made by those entities. They do not get the public attention they deserve. The report that relates to the Western Corridor Recycled Water Project is particularly instructive. It shows that the government has so far spent $2,493 million on the desalination plants at Gibson Island and Luggage Point, plus the western corridor pipeline. It is almost $2.5 billion. It is an incredible amount of money.

The report also requires them to report their outcomes. One of the outcomes that the government has achieved from that $2,493 million was reported in August 2009 as 17.26 megalitres of water per day being supplied to Swanbank. It also includes 24 megalitres a day being supplied to Tarong. Tarong can get its water from Boondooma Dam. Boondooma Dam supplies Tarong so it does not need to take the water. It only takes the water because it has to. It is forced by ministerial intervention to take the water. Even if we are generous and include the water that Tarong takes, it is something like 40 megalitres of water per day at a capital cost, not counting the operational costs, of $2.5 billion.

This is a financial legacy that will cripple the water users of South-East Queensland for generations to come, because that $2.5 billion worth of capital has to be repaid. As the government is finding out, when those sorts of sums of money are borrowed they have to be repaid. Not only do they have to be repaid, but interest has to be paid on them. The operational costs of this infrastructure have to be repaid.

It did not have to be that way. We raised in this House over a period of time the absurd practices that were part of the panicked response when the government built that water grid. I remember raising in here the concept of ‘do it and charge’, as the contractors used to call it. ‘Do it and charge’; tender by invoice. That just meant that the contractor did the job and put in his invoice. That was the tender. It did not matter how much it cost. It was just ‘do it and charge the government’. We ended up with a $2.5 billion white elephant that is now a financial millstone around the necks of water consumers in South-East Queensland, and so it will be for generations to come.

I believe that the legislation that we consider tonight will allow the government to distance itself from that financial millstone that it has placed around the necks of South-East Queensland water consumers. The impact of that financial millstone will be reflected in the price that the retail authorities will have to charge the householders and the industrial users in South-East Queensland. The Water Commission’s website has a table, which I will table in the House tonight for the benefit of members, that sets out an expected price path for bulk water prices from 2008-09 through to 2017-18.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Table titled ‘Bulk Water Prices 2008/2009--2017/2018.
Tabled paper: Table titled ‘Expected Retail Bill increases due to Bulk Charges (for 250 KL/year)’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Any projections that far ahead have to be conservative at best. Given this government’s ability to project its financial situation, any projections out to 2017-18 would have to be grossly conservative. Let us look at the projections for the next couple of years. In 2007-08 the bulk water price in Brisbane was $628 a megalitre. In 2008-09 it was $902 a megalitre--a 30 per cent increase. When we go to 2009-10 it is $1,162 a megalitre--another 30 per cent increase. In 2010-11 it is $1,409 a megalitre--a 25 per cent increase following the previous two 30 per cent increases. In 2012-13 it is $1,864 a megalitre--three times the price it was in 2007-08. In 2012-13 the bulk water cost for consumers in South-East Queensland is projected by the Water Commission to be three times what it was in 2007-08.

That bulk water cost will be borne by the retail entities that this legislation is setting up tonight. Those retail entities will have no choice but to pass that cost on to Queensland consumers. Indeed, they will be compelled to do that because of the pricing mechanisms included in this legislation that give the Queensland Competition Authority the responsibility of setting the price, just as it does with the electricity industry.

Water consumers need to be prepared for those incredible increases in water prices, but they also need to be prepared to sheet the responsibility for them home to the Bligh Labor government because it is the government’s responsibility. It will not be the responsibility of the council owned entities that we set up tonight. I fully expect that in the days ahead we will stand in this House and debate just whose responsibility it is. I know full well that when that time arrives members of the government will try to blame the equivalent of the global financial crisis, which is the excuse that it tried to use when it increased the electricity price for the member for Brisbane Central’s constituents by 40 per cent in three years. It blamed the global financial crisis. The member for Brisbane Central did not stand up and complain on behalf of her constituents. Like the rest of the mindless backbenchers in this government, she just accepted the explanations of the current government that somehow or other it was everybody else’s fault. It is the mums and dads who live in the electorate of Brisbane Central who will feel the full effect of this government’s mismanagement. They will do that when they pay their water bills, just as they do now when they pay their electricity bills.

The government and the people of Queensland can be assured that we on this side of politics will never let the Labor Party forget that they were the ones that spent $2.5 billion on a waste water pipeline that is producing effectively nothing but that has to be paid for by the mums and dads in South-East Queensland. We will never let them forget the debacle of the desalination plant at the bottom end of the Gold Coast that has to pump desalinated water all the way to Brisbane with all of those associated costs.
Ms Grace interjected.
Mr Shine interjected.

Mr SEENEY: We will never let them forget that that mismanagement has built into the water business in South-East Queensland a financial cost that is the direct responsibility of people like the member for Brisbane Central and the member for Toowoomba North and all of the other members who sat in their Labor Party forums and did nothing. For 10 years the Labor Party did nothing. It decided not to build the Wolffdene Dam and it decided not to build anything at all. It was not just a decision not to build the dam that was wrong; it was the fact that it did nothing else. It was paralysed by indecision until such time as Brisbane faced a water crisis that it then had to react to in a panic-stricken way that put layer upon layer of financial impost onto water consumers in South-East Queensland.

While we will support the formation of these retail entities that will be set up by this bill tonight, we do so with a word of caution to the government that it will not be allowed to shift the responsibility for its 15 years of mismanagement onto these council owned entities. When Brisbane consumers come to fully realise the impact of that financial mismanagement on their water prices, we will ensure that it is the government that is held to account, that it is the government that is seen to be responsible--not the retail entities that will be set up tonight and not the local governments that own them. Be very clear: the bill before the House tonight will not be allowed to be a blame-shifting exercise. It will not be allowed to be an exercise that allows the Bligh Labor government to shift responsibility for those financial imposts--those enormous water pricing increases that are coming--onto the local governments that will own these retail entities.

Let us look at what the entities involve. As I said at the beginning of this contribution, what we consider tonight is a model that was put forward by the councils themselves. It was put forward by the councils themselves because they realised and they pointed out to the government that the model that the government was pursuing was going to add another layer of financial madness onto the water pricing system in South-East Queensland. The councils could see and understand the cost of the government’s proposal. The councils came up with a proposal of their own to try to make the best of a bad situation that had come about since the water reform process was put in place in 2007. The councils proposed a model that consisted of three separate, commercially focused, vertically integrated businesses incorporating both the retail and distribution responsibilities.

That is the big difference. That is the difference between what the councils have proposed and what is included in the bill tonight and what the government proposed and what would have cost Queensland water users a heck of a lot more. The entities that this bill sets up tonight will have both a retail function and a distribution function. They will own the distribution network and they will retail the end product--the water--to the water consumers. Retail functions would be separated within the entities, but the entities would have responsibility for both the retail and the distribution.

The entities will be established and will assume operational responsibility for water and wastewater services by 1 July 2011 at the latest. The entities would be constituted by the water businesses from the councils of Brisbane, Lockyer, Somerset and Scenic Rim in the first instance; Moreton and Sunshine Coast in the second instance; and the Gold Coast, Redlands and the Logan councils in the third instance. At this time Ipswich council is considering its position in the proposed model. The entities are to be managed by a board comprising a minimum of three members appointed by the owners. They will also comprise an independent chair with a majority of independent members, with councils having the option to appoint councillors or council officials. Appointment procedures will be determined by the owners having regard to the number of owners and the size of the interest held by each. Council sought to have a reserve power similar to the power that shareholding ministers have over government owned corporations. The entities will be required to report regularly to their own councils in accordance with the establishment documents.

I believe it is important--and I know there is some resistance from the government to the concept of councils being able to appoint a councillor to the board--that these councils are able to appoint a council representative to the board. We all know that the government will appoint plenty of its own to the boards. It will appoint plenty of Labor Party hacks to these boards. It is important that the councils that are the owners of these entities and will have the eventual responsibility for their operation are able to appoint a council representative. It will be interesting to see the economic regulation that will be applied and how it will work in relation to the retail entities. It is proposed that the water entities will set prices from 1 July 2010, with a price monitoring function being filled by the QCA by a submission from each entity demonstrating that prices align with the costs associated with meeting the entity’s asset management plan and customer service standards.

There can be no doubt that the biggest impact on the prices that these entities must charge will be the bulk water prices that I have already referred to--those bulk water prices that are already grossly inflated and will be further grossly inflated as the full effects of the government’s mismanagement flow through the system. That bulk water price will, in the main, determine the price that these retail entities can charge Brisbane consumers. Responsibility for that bulk water price rests squarely and firmly with the Bligh Labor government and the actions that it took and that were taken by its predecessor in the Beattie Labor government.

The state and the councils have agreed to a transition framework to deal with establishment costs with the state to fund any shortfall resulting from the smoothing of establishment costs during transition in order to avoid price shocks to customers. However, it would be fair to say that sunk costs incurred in the establishment of the distribution entity should be paid by the state.

There is a very important role for local governments in the planning and development process. The water assets arrangements under IPA and IDAS recognise the need for the owner of the water assets to have a primary control over infrastructure planning and development assessment decisions. The model before us tonight is one that the local governments have drawn up and decided gives them the best option of exercising that control.

The bill before the House tonight is only the first in a series of pieces of legislation that will be necessary to complete the water reform process to ensure that this model of council owned entities that have responsibility for the distribution and retail activities can properly operate. We will consider in this House a number of other pieces of legislation which will fill out the detail. This legislation tonight simply allows the entities to be set up for the process to begin. In that respect, we will lend our support to its passage through the House.

The bill also deals with the Aurukun and Mornington shire leases and extends those leases until 2059. These leases currently only run to 2029. The federal government’s funding from the National Partnership Agreement on Remote Indigenous Housing is only available if 40-year subleases are available to Indigenous housing applicants. The LNP welcomes the move in the bill tonight but strongly urges the Labor state government not to allow this extension of time to delay moves towards freehold in these communities. It is our contention, it is our policy, it is our belief that these people need a system of freehold that allows them to invest in their own homes and establish those homes as their main asset, just as every other Queenslander has the right to do. We have always believed that freehold is preferable to leasehold. It is a major difference in political philosophy. We will continue to ensure that all Queenslanders, wherever possible, can enjoy the benefits of freehold title.
