The bill also allows for water supply investigation costs to be retrospectively recovered. This part of the bill has been instigated by the need to retrospectively recover the cost of the fluoride investigation at the North Pine water treatment facility. The retrospective claiming of the cost of that investigation is, I believe, questionable at best. However, it is reasonable to argue that there should be an avenue for the government to recover investigation costs. It is, though, disappointing and very questionable that the bill before the House should do that retrospectively. We have always expressed a deal of caution about legislation that acts retrospectively. In this case it was the government that should have taken responsibility for the fluoride bungle in the North Pine water treatment facility that caused so much angst and concern to so many Queenslanders. It was a clear failure of the state government, and the government should have been the one to take responsibility. While we support the part of the legislation that allows the reasonable recovery of costs, we put on the record tonight that we do not support the retrospective recovery of those costs in a situation where the government should have taken responsibility.

The bill also deals with land valuations and extends land valuations to 31 August 2010. I have some doubts about the rationale given by the minister in his second reading speech as a justification for this. The government is always keen to ensure that the unimproved valuation of land is kept as high as possible because for them that maximises the income they receive from land tax. It is often confused with the role that local governments have of levying rates based on the unimproved capital values. I think, without exception, local governments adjust their rate in the dollar to take account for rises in unimproved capital value and therefore very seldom receive any net increase in the amount of money they receive when unimproved capital values rise. It is the opposite with the state government. It never adjust its rate in the dollar. It takes every opportunity to increase its rate in the dollar. It takes every opportunity to ensure that there is bracket creep within the land tax system and that increases in unimproved capital value result in higher land tax receipts for the government, and it takes no proactive action to keep those receipts constant in the way that councils do.

The explanation that is given in this case is that the government is concerned that if a valuation was done it would result in higher valuations for people who are not in a position to pay. I have listened to the explanation that was given by the minister and by the bureaucrats at the briefing we received. I understand the proposition that is being put that somehow or other in the particular areas that this applies to there have not been enough sales since the market plateaued or began to fall to adequately provide a fair valuation that would reflect today’s values rather than the high values that were characteristic of land sales before the global financial crisis.

While I express concern about this particular part of the legislation, I am not going to oppose it tonight. I will watch with interest and wait to see the government implement some valuations that properly reflect the changes in land values not just in these areas but right across the state, because I think there has been a marked change in property values. Those property values should be reflected in the unimproved capital value, even if that results in a falling state revenue from the land tax regime.

The bill also allows for renewable energy projects to be built on state leasehold land. Of course, we would welcome the provisions in this bill that allow leaseholders to apply to extend the terms of their crown lease to allow renewable energy projects to be built on the land. It is a situation not dissimilar to the Aurukun and Mornington Island leases I spoke about earlier. Leaseholders are going to need a secure land title if they are going to be able to finance those types of projects. Wherever those projects become viable, they should not be constrained and their construction should not be constrained by land title issues. So we would welcome that part of the bill that allows for the leases to be extended and the renewable energy projects to be established on leasehold land.

As I said, the bill before the House is only the first in a series of bills that will deal with this process of finalising the water reform process that was begun some years ago in response to the water crisis that was a direct responsibility of the mismanagement of successive Labor governments. We will not oppose the passage of the bill before the House, but we will also never let this government use the passage of such legislation to absolve itself of the responsibility it has for the crippling price rises that are coming for water consumers right across South-East Queensland.

I know that people in local government in South-East Queensland who will be the owners of these retail entities are very aware of the danger of being put in a position where they are left to shoulder the blame for the Labor government’s failure. We will assist them to ensure that never happens. The government will take responsibility for water price increases. The government will take responsibility--the minister, the Premier, the Treasurer and every member of the government will take responsibility--for the 300 per cent water price increases that the people of South-East Queensland will pay, just as the government should take responsibility for the increases in the power prices that have impacted on people across South-East Queensland in the last three years and that are also set to continue. That is the rider that we put on supporting this legislation through the House tonight. We will support the legislation, but we will also never let the government forget that it is the one that is responsible for the financial impost that the people of South-East Queensland will have to bear for generations to come.

Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (8.07 pm): This legislation addresses a number of issues. I intend to focus mainly on the proposed restructure of water distribution and retailing. This bill is designed to deliver the second stage of the government’s South-East Queensland water reform program. Stage 1 of the program led to the creation of the South-East Queensland water grid. It saw the establishment of three authorities to manage the supply, transport and treatment of bulk water. The government claims that the restructure of water was essential because water was not being managed efficiently by the 17 retail entities that were responsible for it across South-East Queensland. There was also of course the fact that the government had not planned adequately and Brisbane was in the grip of a drought.

The government’s view of how water was being managed did not take into account how effective were the various water managers. On the Sunshine Coast, AquaGen--the water authority jointly owned by Maroochy and Caloundra councils--was extremely efficient. Those councils, unlike the state government, had planned for future water needs and invested in infrastructure. As a result, the region AquaGen served had highly efficient, well-managed and cost-effective water supplies.

We are now considering this legislation that will cover stage 2 of the government’s so-called reform process that will see the establishment of three water distributor-retailer entities. It will allow for the transfer of property, assets, liabilities and employees from local governments to the new entities. Those new authorities will also play a role in planning and development assessment processes and trade waste approval processes previously handled by local government. The restructure provides for three new vertically integrated authorities broadly based around Brisbane, the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast. This will give South-East Queensland a total of seven authorities managing water. The other four, established under stage 1 of the government’s reform program, are horizontally based--that is, they are responsible for bulk water supply, bulk transport, manufactured water and the water grid respectively. While this might appear on the surface to be a reduction in the number of authorities, when you consider the implications it is in fact extremely complex.

Previously, a local authority like Aquagen was responsible for all aspects of water delivery in its region. Now we shall have one authority responsible for distribution and retailing but four others playing a role in either bulk water or treated water. Where is the increased efficiency in this model? As a former board member of Aquagen, I can vouch for its innovation and efficiency as a water manager. I challenge the government to show how the creation of these separate entities--whole new bureaucracies--will improve on the performance of Aquagen.

In undertaking this massive restructure, why did the government not consider a fully vertically integrated model? This would have provided for regional authorities with responsibility for all aspects of water--including bulk supply, treatment and so on--in that region. The only additional authority that would be required would be the one managing the water grid. Such a model would have been much easier to implement and no doubt considerably cheaper. It would have required less regulation. It would have ensured those responsible for water management in each region controlled all aspects of supply and distribution. This would have gone a lot further to promoting water conservation and innovation.
Mr Robertson: Do you want to know why? The councils objected to it.
Mr DICKSON: The council did a great job.
Mr Robertson: The very council that you were a part of.

Mr DICKSON: You put a gun to their head. In asking the question, ‘Why is this particular model being adopted by the government?’ the answer that comes to mind is so that the water entities can be easily sold off to private enterprise. This government has already shown it is prepared to flog off the state’s assets in order to solve the economic difficulties it has created--and why should water be any different? I would be very interested to know what costs are involved in setting up the government’s new structure. I would be even more interested to know who will bear those costs. No doubt it will be the long-suffering Queensland community. I do not think most people mind having to pay more for water. It is a precious resource and needs to be priced accordingly. What people do mind is paying for more bureaucracy and regulation.

Under the current system, water rates are managed by local governments as part of their overall rates process. Once the new distributor-retailer authorities are fully established, they will be responsible for collecting rates and dealing with customer inquiries and complaints. These functions require staff, call centres, management and accounting systems. This will duplicate existing council systems, which will still need to be maintained. It is unlikely that sufficient staff can be transferred from council to water authorities to cover the requirements, to say nothing of costs like computer systems.

Local authorities will be transferring their water and wastewater assets to the new water entities. Given that in this year’s budget the government withdrew the subsidies it used to provide to local government for water sewerage infrastructure, what are the cost implications for the new authorities? The new authorities will also be able to undertake ‘complementary functions’ like consultancy on a commercial basis. I am concerned about commercial ventures taking over from the core functions of these authorities, which should be the provision of water and wastewater services to the community. There is also the issue of the cost of providing such commercial services. Will they have to be accommodated within the existing staffing and resources, or will the authority be able to set up expensive consultancy services that may or may not be profitable?

Local governments will be entitled to share in the profits of the water authorities in return for handing over their water assets. I would like to know what sort of return to local government is anticipated, given the investment made in those assets was paid for by ratepayers. What size ‘share’ of the profit will be distributed, bearing in mind that each entity has more than one council shareholder?

Water and sewerage used to be basic services provided to residents by local government. The margins earned by governments from water rates went towards providing further services and infrastructure. Now councils will have to rely on unspecified profits from water authorities they used to own but no longer control. These new entities will have full power over water in their regions. This includes, under clause 12, the power to ‘fix charges and other terms for services’. We all know what has happened under the privatisation of electricity retailing in Queensland--an increase in costs to consumers. Will the costs of setting up these new authorities mean increases in charges to customers? I am sure it will.

I think we are entitled to be cynical about this government’s real motive for this restructure. If the motive is not to set up water authorities for a quick fire sale, why the rush to implement it? Local governments have been given only until the end of April next year to reach participation agreements with the new distributor-retailers. That is a ridiculously short time frame, especially considering that the new entities do not even exist yet.

Transfer schemes are required under the bill for the transfer of assets, liabilities, instruments and employees from local governments to the new water authorities. This will require a great deal of work by local councils to ensure they complete the due diligence and comply with the provisions of the act. It will also impose significant costs on councils which are required to complete the transfer scheme by September 2010 at the very latest. The transfer process gives considerable powers to the minister. Worse still, there is no provision for transfer decisions to be appealed, reviewed or challenged. That is typical of the government. The explanatory notes claim that this is because of the tight time frames and to ensure ongoing provision of water and sewerage services to the community. Again, why is there such urgency, unless the government has another agenda? Why is the minister so hell-bent on transferring assets from local government to these authorities unless the plan is to sell them off? Who will benefit from this complex and expensive new structure? Certainly not the ratepayers of South-East Queensland and their elected councils.

The role of the new entities in the planning and development assessment process will be included in further legislation. Clause 77 of this bill provides for the transfer of development infrastructure from local councils to the distributor-retailers. I note that existing changes and agreements will be retained by local government, but we need to know exactly what role these new bodies will play in planning. It is hard to see a benefit in introducing yet another agency into the assessment and approvals process.

This bill will also provide for amendments to the Land Act 1994. Those amendments will allow the government to approve access to state land for renewable energy projects such as wind farms. These are important projects when we are looking for alternatives to traditional energy sources. Currently, the act does not allow for secondary activities where land is leased for grazing and agricultural purposes. Clearly, a wind farm could work very well using grazing land or similar, and these changes are sensible.

The amendments to the Valuation of Land Act 1944 extend the time frame for valuations under pre-amalgamation local government boundaries. This may not be the benefit to landowners that the government claims. The impact of the global financial crisis and adverse weather may in fact mean that land valuations have dropped in the past year. This means that landholders will be paying higher taxes, including land tax--and we all know how much that has gone up over the last few years--than they would otherwise have done.

The proposed amendments to the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act 2008 demonstrate this government’s lack of proper planning and management of water. We should not require retrospective legislation to clean up the mess after the responsible entity fails, as occurred in April this year. The fluoride overdose itself was bad enough. What if this ‘mistake’ had occurred in the treatment of recycled water? The health of Queenslanders could have been seriously at risk. I hope the minister takes that on board.

Now the government belatedly realises that its legislation has failed to provide for information sharing that will allow for proper investigation of such incidents. It also wants to recover costs from the responsible authority for noncompliance with the act. I would have thought a bigger issue was the fact that such a serious incident could occur in the first place and what it says about the way water is now being managed in this state. It is quite extraordinary that only now is there a requirement under clause 136 of the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act 2008 for a customer education and risk awareness program about recycled water. We all knew what was coming there.

This should have been self-evident to the government. It just shows how badly the government has handled such an important issue. The new clause in the act that allows for cost recovery including retrospective recovery of costs associated with the fluoride overdose incident is a classic example of shutting the stable doors after the horse has bolted. When it comes to public health, cost is not the issue. Government has an obligation to the community to ensure its policies do not endanger the health of Queenslanders.

I have no issue with the use of fluoride in our water, but when these decisions are made they need to be implemented properly and not be rushed through. This particularly applies to recycled water. That is why I am concerned about the proposed restructure of water distribution and retail. It is being rushed through, which makes it liable to mistakes like the ones we have seen in the water supply bill. Local governments are losing control of an important revenue source and assets built up over many years. The liabilities are also being removed, but will they be better off? There is a lot of doubt about that. They are retaining ownership but not effective control.

I want to return to my earlier comments. This model and the time frames being imposed suggest the government has more on its agenda than water reform. It is looking to sell yet another asset owned by the people of Queensland. There is nothing wrong with a restructure that will benefit all stakeholders. This bill needs a lot more scrutiny to ensure that it can achieve that aim.

I think we need to get straight to the point of why this bill is being put together tonight. I think most people in this room are thinking what I am thinking and probably what most people in Queensland are thinking. This asset is going to get flogged off. I think the government should look very closely at what it put forward recently--after the election, not prior to the election. I make that point very strongly. It made decisions after the election that should have been talked about prior to the election, and that was the selling of core assets like ports, plantations, rail and roads. Is water the next thing that will be sold in Queensland? What price is going to be put on that?

I want to talk about the price of water. This is bulk water and it is not figuring in the normal inflation rate. In 2008-09 a million litres cost $902. In 2009-10 they will cost $1,162. In 2010-11 they will be $1,409. In 2011-12 they will be $1,643. In 2012-13 they will be $1,864. If you break that down, that is $1.86 per kilolitre just for the purchase of bulk water in 20012-13. That is not the retail cost; that is just the bulk cost of water. How much is the real figure going to be when you factor in inflation? Is it going to be $2.50? Is it going to be $3? Is it going to be $4? I do not know the answer to that, but the government should come clean and articulate these prices to the people of Queensland. It appears as though the government does not understand it. It is putting documents out like this one here, which talks about these figures that are demonstrated very clearly in the footnote of this document--figures excluding normal inflation. Why can’t the government add up? Why can’t it factor in the cost of normal inflation? Is it two per cent or three per cent? It is not a big number. I think the government can work that out.

I think the government has a real problem with adding up and numbers, because we have a debt of I think $85 billion. Had that money been spent on proper infrastructure throughout Queensland over the last 10 years, we would not have had a problem with water. Local authorities were doing a very good job, but this government was sitting on its hands when it should have been using its head and thinking about the problems of the future.

There are a couple of quotes I could pull out of the bible. There was a story about seven good years and seven bad years. We had seven bad years and the government never planned. We had seven good years and the government still has not planned. When is the government going to start planning for the future? We need to be proactive, not reactive, when it comes to water. There are a lot of things in this bill that are very reactive. When we talk about the implementation of fluoride into the system, which I touched on earlier in my speech, that only killed a couple of budgies, knocked a few goldfish around and killed some daisies in somebody’s backyard. If the same thing happens with recycled water, what will the implication be? How many hundred thousand people could get sick? I know the minister has changed portfolios recently, but the next portfolio he will be looking after will be Health, because they will have to save a lot of people’s lives. What sorts of diseases will be passed on unless this law is implemented correctly? Fluoride was something that just slipped through the system. As I said, it only killed budgies, goldfish and a few plants. Let us talk about the people who could be killed or made very ill through the implementation of recycled water.

It is not really recycled water, is it; it is treated sewage? It is the stuff that goes down the toilet in hospitals. It is the stuff that goes down the toilet in everybody’s households. They could be taking God knows what sort of medication. This will all go into the same catchment pit, go through the sewage treatment plants and then turn into this you beaut fluid that is called recycled water. What if the same mistake that was made with fluoride is made with recycled water? I know the bill is talking about how they are going to stop that, but it is retrospective. Let us remember that word--‘retrospective’. Hindsight is really good, but if you get it wrong just once what is it going to do to the people of Queensland?

I also remember a minister in this government by the name of Henry Palaszczuk. I was a councillor with the old Maroochy Shire Council on the Aquagen water board. I was castigated in the newspaper when Henry said, ‘We will never build a pipeline to the Sunshine Coast. We will never take your water.’ I do not know what you call that. You are not allowed to say the word in this parliament. I would say it was a very poor investment in the truth. That is probably what we could call it. I really do not know what we are going to use as a replacement for that word any longer. Maybe from now on we will call it a poor investment in the truth.

We were misled at that time. I think we are being misled in this bill. I think we really need to look at this government’s form--its form before the election and its form after the election. If the government were a racehorse it would not win a race because it has bad form. It has form that you would not put in a race. You would not trust that form. When it gets down to this water grid and its implementation, I say very sincerely to the people of queensland and the members of this House: I would like a commitment from the government if you are going to sell the water or not. Minister, I hope in your speech tonight--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Please direct your comments through the chair.

Mr DICKSON: Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would pose a question to the minister and I would hope that he could answer that with a great degree of honesty tonight. Will the government be selling the assets in the future or not? Let us not speculate. Let us not skirt around the outside of the issue. Let us talk about the plain, simple truth. You could not do it before the election. You made decisions after the election. Now you have an opportunity to be honest and truthful to the people of Queensland. Will you be selling these assets or not? You had an opportunity to create four components of this water grid, but you have seven, which leaves me to believe it will be a saleable asset very shortly.

I know there are many companies out there like Avendi waiting with bated breath to chew up our water supply. I can tell you one thing from my perspective: I will never support the selling of water regardless of whoever puts it up, so take that on notice. And the people of Queensland can take that on notice.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (8.27 pm): I rise to contribute to the South-East Queensland (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) and Natural Resources Provisions Bill 2009. The purpose of this legislation is to restructure the downstream water and waste water distribution and retail functions in South-East Queensland. It establishes three council owned distributor-retailer entities to take over the provision of water and waste water services. It also allows the recovery of reasonable costs of investigation into the water supply including retrospectively the cost of the fluoride investigation at the North Pine water treatment facility. It also allows the establishment of renewable energy projects on state leasehold land.

In September 2007 the Queensland government approved a range of institutional reforms to be implemented across the South-East Queensland urban water sector. These reforms supposedly addressed a number of critical shortfalls in the urban water supply arrangement. South-East Queensland councils were asked by the government to recommend a model for these reforms. While the majority of this reform is acceptable to the councils, the South East Queensland Council of Mayors has expressed strong concern that councils are unable to appoint even one director despite the entities being council owned.

The government claims that this is to avoid a burden on landowners already affected by the global financial crisis and extreme weather. However, in fact it may be that the previous valuations may be higher than the post GFC valuations. This will particularly impact on people’s land tax valuations in a time when residents are already struggling. The retrospective claiming of costs of the investigation of the fluoride bungle was questionable at best, as was the government’s pledge for a referendum before adding fluoride to our water and making us drink recycled sewage.

The South-East Queensland water reform program was to be delivered in a two-stage process. Stage 1 focused on bulk water reform, in particular the establishment of these three statutory authorities to own the bulk supply, bulk transport and manufactured water infrastructure respectively and also the construction of the South-East Queensland water grid which connected the South-East Queensland region’s major water sources, water treatment plants and bulk water transport networks. The SEQ Water Grid Manager was also established to operate the South-East Queensland water grid and to be the single purchaser of bulk water services and the single seller of bulk water in South-East Queensland. Stage 1 became operational on 1 July 2008.

Stage 2, which is to be operational from 1 July 2010, focuses on downstream water reform. The core of the stage 2 reform program is the separation of the retail and distribution functions from South-East Queensland local governments and the establishment of these three separate vertically integrated distribution retail businesses. The Liberal National Party believes that councils should retain ownership and control over their water supply and wastewater infrastructure.

On 1 July 2008 South-East Queensland’s bulk water supply and water transport assets were transferred to the state government. On the Gold Coast the transition included the Hinze Dam, the Little Nerang Dam and the Molendinar and Mudgeeraba water treatment plants--three of which are in my electorate. Hinze Dam is about 15 kilometres south-west of Nerang. The Hinze Dam, completed in 1976, was upgraded in 1989 to a storage capacity of 161,070 million litres covering a surface area of 972 hectares. Based on our average rainfall and our weather patterns in that area, it can provide on average 191 million litres of water per day. The Hinze Dam is currently being upgraded for flood mitigation and increased storage.

The 207-square kilometre catchment area for Hinze Dam includes the Numinbah Valley and Springbrook Plateau--both of which are in my electorate--with about 77 per cent covered by native bushland within state forests and national parks. The Gold Coast City Council owns more than 5,000 hectares of land surrounding the Hinze Dam and the Little Nerang Dam. About 15 per cent of the catchment has been developed into pasture land, mostly in the Numinbah Valley where dairy and beef cattle properties operate.

Currently, the stage 3 upgrade of the Hinze Dam is in progress. The upgrade will raise the dam wall from 93.5 metres to 108.5 metres. This is designed to increase the water supply from Hinze Dam to 225 million litres per day and reduce flooding in the lower Nerang River catchment area and ensure the dam complies with current safety standards and guidelines.

The Liberal National Party policy was to abolish the Water Commission and for the ownership and control of local water infrastructure and service delivery to be in the hands of local councils. This bill keeps ownership in the hands of local councils, but the control is still debatable.

The residents of the Gold Coast are sick and tired of being treated like second-class citizens. Whilst we were on water restrictions for years, residents in Brisbane were hosing their driveways. We have a desalination plant that is falling apart and now this government, because of its inability to plan for the future, is taking our water for Brisbane.

I well remember an article in the Gold Coast Bulletin regarding the former member for Mudgeeraba’s comments on how our Brisbane neighbours helped us poor Gold Coasters during the drought by giving us water from Logan. I table a copy of that article.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Article from the Gold Coast Bulletin titled ‘Really Ms Reilly, get the story right’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Unfortunately, as noted by Sue Lappeman in the Gold Coast Bulletin in November 2007, the member got it all wrong when she spoke in parliament, much like this government does with everything it touches, when she said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Hinze Dam, the Gold Coast’s major bulk water supply asset, lies smack bang in the middle of my beautiful electorate. Over the past seven years I have watched it hit its lowest point, when the old stop signs and street signs were visible sticking up above the level of the water, and I have also watched the water go over the spillway when we have had good rain in good times. I have been relieved to know that, when the water level in the Hinze Dam was below 30 per cent, water security for my area was guaranteed by the supply of water coming from Wivenhoe Dam when it was full via a pipeline from Brisbane.
XML.Hansard-Body: One has to worry about this government taking control of our water resources when one of its own members was so confused she did not know whether there was a pipeline in her electorate. This is just another example of this government’s propensity to be loose with the truth.

Only this week the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy joined with the Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability in perpetuating the myth that members of the Liberal National Party have no environmental credentials. I remind both ministers that it was the Liberal National Party that resoundingly won the booth on Springbrook Mountain and it has been the Liberal National Party member for Mudgeeraba who has to date been unable to extract the truth from the petulant minister about this government’s intentions for the future of my area.

For the minister to continually assert that it has the environment at heart is preposterous. It was the Liberal National Party member for Mudgeeraba who also won the booth at Reedy Creek and led the charge to underground powerlines in the area, and I quote the minister from Hansard --
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The good people of Mudgeeraba need to know that when push came to shove in terms of protecting the precious environment, their member was nowhere to be seen.
XML.Hansard-Body: The good people of Mudgeeraba already know that it was this Labor government that tried to foist overhead powerlines on them in Reedy Creek, took our water and bought up our land. It was the good people of Mudgeeraba who voted the Labor Party out for its hypocrisy on its stand on the environment and on water management on the Gold Coast. Gold Coasters will remember.

Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP) (8.36 pm): I rise to participate in the debate on the South-East Queensland (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) and Natural Resources Provisions Bill. At the outset, can I thank the minister for proposing this bill to the House and for his extensive consultation with all of the mayors in South-East Queensland. I would like to address the amendment to the Land Act 1994 which will make it possible for renewable energy projects to be established on state land that is presently being used for grazing or other purposes.

The Land Act is the framework for the administration and management of leasehold land. Leasehold land makes up 70 per cent of all the land in Queensland, of which the majority is assigned to grazing and other agricultural leases. Under current Land Act provisions, a lease must be used for the purpose for which it was issued. The minister administering the act can approve an additional purpose for a lease but only if the additional purpose is complementary to and does not interfere with the purpose for which the lease was originally issued. A lease for grazing and agricultural purposes could have an additional purpose such as low-key tourism included in the lease. This purpose would be deemed to be complementary to the original purpose and would be of sufficiently small scale to ensure that the additional purpose does not become the dominant or principal activity.

However, this approach has served us well, but we are now facing new climate change challenges. Equally, we are learning very quickly about both the damage we are doing through our carbon emissions and the ways we can improve upon our situation. This is the impetus for the clean and renewable energy revolution. Queensland needs to be a part of it.

The Queensland government has signed up to the national renewable energy target of 20 per cent of Australia’s electricity supply to come from renewable sources by 2020. This is documented in our Toward Q2: Tomorrow’s Queensland green vision for protecting our lifestyle and environment. Our future challenges are mapped out in ClimateQ which positions Queensland at the forefront of Australia’s climate change response.

The Queensland Renewable Energy Plan is our policy platform to expand the renewables sector. Queensland is rich in renewable energy sources--solar, geothermal, biomass, wind and hydro. The Queensland government is committed to accelerating the state’s economy towards a clean energy future.

Renewable energy projects such as wind farms require vast amounts of land to be successful. Renewables such as wind farms can quite easily coexist with leases which are currently being used for grazing and agricultural purposes. Currently as the Land Act exists, a lease must only be used for the purpose it was issued. Additionally, the minister can approve an additional purpose for a lease but only if the additional purpose is complementary, as I said before, to the original lease and does not interfere with the purpose for which the lease was originally issued.

An additional purpose, such as for wind farms, would become in most instances the more dominant use of the lease and would currently not be allowed. The proposed change to the legislation will allow for an additional purpose, such as a wind farm, even though it would not be complementary to the original purpose, but only for situations where a green energy project is to be established on the leased land. This amendment will allow for proponents of renewable energy projects access to state land which was previously unavailable to them. We need to be leaders, at the front of the pack, showing renewable industries the world over that Queensland is the place to do business and that Queensland is the site for their future renewable energy projects. Given Queensland’s size and the abundance of our renewable energy sources, it is important that we support this legislation and give Queenslanders a chance to have a green and clean future. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP) (8.40 pm): I rise to add my contribution to the debate on the South-East Queensland (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) and Natural Resources Provisions Bill 2009. At the beginning I would like to highlight how this state Labor government has mismanaged the water supply in Queensland. It is a reactive government--not a proactive one--and an effective, efficient and clean water supply is a service that the taxpayers of Queensland deserve. That should happen without a hit-and-miss approach. It is the government’s duty to ensure a sustainable and affordable water supply to all of Queensland.

The genesis of this legislation, which the opposition will be supporting in a responsible manner, is the failure of this government to properly plan for the water supply in Queensland which started back in 1989 when I was a councillor on the Albert shire council. With a wonderful little stroke of brilliance during an election campaign, Wayne Goss and Fred James came out and promised to do away with the Wolffdene Dam if they got elected. This was a dam that was planned to cater for the fantastic growth in the south-east corner. It was obvious that the water planners for Queensland knew the growth rates. Albert shire was the fastest growing local authority in Australia.

This politically motivated election promise, which was made to get Wayne Goss elected, has resulted in a lack of an appropriate water supply for the fastest growing area in Queensland, and even in Australia--South-East Queensland. Because we have had no Wolffdene Dam, we have had to make this knee-jerk reaction to catch up all these years later. It was in 1989 when the Wolffdene Dam was cancelled. Here we are, 20 years later, debating legislation to pass the buck--the blame for this massive increase in the cost of water to South-East Queenslanders--to the poor local councils. We all know that this legislation will bring higher charges. Yet again, Queenslanders will be paying for this incompetent Bligh Labor government.

Does the ambulance levy spring to mind? Beattie made an unfunded promise to the pensioners of Queensland of a free ambulance service. That was a great idea--a free service--but it was unfunded. So what were we left to do? We were left to pick up the tab. Now we have an annual charge on our electricity bills. Originally, the Beattie government tried to pass on that charge to local councils so they would cop the blame. But the councils said, ‘No way. We will identify this as a state charge.’ This is what will happen to increases in the price of water. That blame for that will be passed on to the councils.

We have seen the price of electricity go up. We have seen the price of gas go up. The cost of car registration has gone up. Fuel prices have gone up. Now we are seeing the price of water go up. The poor old Queenslanders are stuck with Beattie-Bligh Labor governments inflicting more costs on them every day. When I was a member of the Gold Coast City Council advising the mayor, I heard that the government was going to take over the wholesaling of water to councils. I said, ‘Watch out. That’s the biggest bear trap.’ At that stage the council was getting an $80 million profit out of its water operations. The only way you can make a profit on your retail price is dependent on the wholesale price. Of course, when this government is in charge of the wholesale price for water for Queenslanders, you can guarantee that it will be going up 30 per cent a year. That is exactly what will happen.

I would like to be there when the good Labor members over there go along to their respective union bosses--the ETU, the CFMEU, the AWU, whatever they are over there--and say, ‘We have to sell these assets, “Big” Bill,’ or whoever else is running their union, ‘because we didn’t plan properly for Queensland. We’ve overspent. We’ve got ourselves into financial trouble. We put in all of this water infrastructure, such as that lemon down at the Gold Coast for $1.2 billion, which has not been needed, and now we have to sell your public assets, Bill. I am sorry about that, but we have been incompetent.’ I would like to be at that meeting. That will be a fascinating meeting.
Mr Messenger: ‘Big’ Bill rolled over, though.

Mr STEVENS: He might have, but there are a few ETU members who have not rolled over. The members opposite have no idea how to manage infrastructure development, let alone the services that go with it.

The objectives of this bill are to restructure the water and waste water distribution and retail management functions to improve water security planning and service delivery, enhance customer service delivery and accountability. These objectives will be achieved by establishing three distributor-retailer entities. They are based on location and neighbouring councils. Queensland Urban Utilities will be the largest and will encompass the local councils of Brisbane, Ipswich, Somerset, Scenic Rim and Lockyer--the wonderful Lockyer.
Mr Rickuss: Yes.

Mr STEVENS: The second entity will include the councils of the Sunshine Coast and Moreton Bay. The third entity will cover my beloved Gold Coast, Logan, a former part of the old Albert shire and the Redland council--the great Redlands with its wonderful natural water supply. Now, the wonderful people of the Redlands will have a very dear water supply because of this government’s failure to plan properly and passing on these high costs to them.

The second and third retail entities will have to be in place by 2010, and each of the three entities will retain joint local government ownership but will each have their own board of directors. Queensland Urban Utilities will operate the water retail and water distribution unit of the Brisbane City Council and will supply water to more than 1.3 million people across Brisbane, Ipswich, the Lockyer Valley and the Scenic Rim and Somerset regions.

The responsibilities of Queensland Urban Utilities, which in July 2010 will become a statutory authority, are to purchase water from the state government South-East Queensland water grid manager--at an exorbitant price, no doubt--and deliver it to residents; to manage and treat sewage and operate sewage pumping stations; to manage and maintain $4.4 billion of infrastructure and assets, including water supply mains and sewer networks; to issue accounts for all water consumers whether residential or commercial users; and to provide a specialised recycled water service to businesses that require it. The other two water utilities will have similar responsibilities.

The South-East Queensland (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) and Natural Resources Provisions Bill also seeks to amend the Land Act 1994, the Local Government (Aboriginal Lands) Act 1978, the Valuation of Land Act 1944, and the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act 2008. The amendments to the Land Act 1994 will allow for preferential access arrangements for renewable energy projects on state government land. That, to me, seems reasonable, as the Liberal National Party supports any initiative that focuses on encouraging alternative methods and environmentally friendly methods of generating power and will adjust those leases that are currently for rural-only purposes to encompass generating power and renewable energy projects.

The Local Government (Aboriginal Lands) Act 1978 will be amended to change and extend each lease for Aurukun and Mornington shire for a period of 31 years from the day that the lease would have expired. This occurs at clause 117 of the bill, where a new section 3A is inserted. This extension will allow for these communities to continue to apply for Australian federal government funding under the National Partnership Agreement on Remote Indigenous Housing, as stated in the explanatory notes, and gain the ability to offer 40-year subleases to secure housing assets as required under the agreement. We support anything to help our good friends in these remote areas.

I also want to discuss the amendments to the Valuation of Land Act 1944. Clause 127 of the bill seeks to amend the VLA to extend the date that the act can apply to pre-amalgamation local government boundaries from 31 August 2009 to 31 August 2010. This extension of one year is absurd and the amendment is a complete con. This corrupt, dishonest government will not make any effort to re-evaluate land because its land taxes will plummet. It is all about the financial aspects with this bankrupt government. It knows land prices have plummeted. What it is deliberately doing is keeping them at the old values and extorting more money out of those people. Everyone knows there was to be a valuation done every year. The government was happy to grab the money while the land prices were going up. Now that the prices are going down, it does not want a little hole in the budget. That is all this is about. The height of arrogance of the whole matter is the fact that it is still charging local governments a fee for the valuation every year. I am reminded that the Gold Coast City Council’s bill for its valuation was $600,000 per annum. It is still claiming that fee despite the fact that it is not doing a valuation. The ratepayers are paying for this government not to do a re-evaluation. Tell me the logic in ratepayers paying for this government to not do a valuation? Is that not that sensible? Their land valuations will stay higher rather than come back to the market situation which has obviously diminished.

I am amazed how far this government will go to corruptly manage this state. With an enormous debt of $85 billion, it will do anything to keep its head afloat and save going down to that AA- credit rating, which is not far round the corner unless it commits more to those asset sales. It is having a lot of difficulty. I can smell in the wind that there is a change coming shortly in relation to those asset sales. That has put the hammer on this government. The polls are turning badly for it. I do not think Anna Bligh will be hanging around for too long if she does not change the public perception of those asset sales. It does not matter about facts and myths. People do not want a bar of the untruths that they were told.
Mr ROBERTSON: I rise to a point of order. I question the relevance of the member’s contribution. He seems obsessed with the issue of asset sales. This is a water bill, not an asset sales bill.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): I ask the honourable member to refer to the bill at hand.

Mr STEVENS: I am happy to move on. Obviously it is a very sensitive point. The Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act 2008 will be amended to improve the recycled water and drinking water regulatory framework as a result of the fluoride incident at the North Pine water treatment facility. The member for Buderim has already detailed quite a few aspects of this absolutely disgusting episode when the fluoride was 20 times more than the recommended amount. It was added to the water supply of 300,000 litres of water and distributed to 4,000 homes, and I feel very sorry for the little budgies and goldfish that the member for Buderim said died as a result of that poisoning of the water. What an absolute debacle this incident was. It shows us the way the government manages water and fiddles with our water supply. It is a matter way out of its control and which is often to the detriment of Queensland taxpayers.

The introduction of this bill reinforces the lack of management ability of this state Labor government. What is completely ironic is that when the state government decided to take over the control of water infrastructure and distribution it realised it could not manage it. Therefore, it wants to give it back to the councils that, as we know, are the ones that know how to manage and distribute water. The Bligh Labor government has botched the management of the water grid which blew out the budget and will result in the high cost of water that Queenslanders will now pay. Thank you very much, Bligh Labor government, for putting up water prices!

The desalination plant on the Gold Coast worth $1.2 billion is just sitting down there. I again remind all of my friends on the other side who love the green movement of the power generated to run that desalination plant. We know it is supposed to supply 125 megalitres a day. Unfortunately, I do not know how many it has produced at this point in time. It is sitting down there turning into $1.2 billion worth of rusty lemon. Again to the good union friends of those opposite: that is one of the reasons the government is selling its public assets. The cost of that desalination plant, of course, is incorporated into the cost of water that the taxpayers of Queensland will have to endure and see rise over the years ahead.

I reinforce that the Bligh Labor government nearly always makes a decision after the problem or the crisis has arisen. There is no future planning. When it is in trouble with water, power, the ambulance service or the motorways, it puts up the prices for the users and comes with after-the-fact answers that are always very expensive and have put the state into the sad debt situation we are in. This legislation before us today is to pass the buck of increased costs over to the poor old councils in South-East Queensland. Who really pays in one form or another are Queenslanders in South-East Queensland. They are ratepayers; they are taxpayers. They are the same person! The same people will be voting out the Bligh Labor government because of those increases in the water prices that this legislation will lead to in the very near future.

This situation has happened in the running of one of Queensland’s most essential services--that is, water. I agree completely with the member for Buderim that this will be another item for asset sale in the very near future to balance the books and relieve that burden on that bank balance which is looking increasingly like forcing the government into a worse credit rating than it currently enjoys.

When the government realised that it was unable to manage our water supply, it placed it back into the hands of the local councils that are the best ones to manage such a vital service to Queenslanders. They have done a great job managing the water supply over many years. They really are and have always been the best people to give a good, reliable, steady, clean, efficient water supply to areas such as Redlands, Brisbane and the Gold Coast. Unfortunately, this government will make them pay through the nose to keep going on that course. We support the legislation.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (8.58 pm): I rise tonight to speak on the South-East Queensland (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) and Natural Resources Provisions Bill 2009. As honourable members have already heard from the shadow minister, the honourable member for Callide, we on this side of the House support the general intent of this bill. I thank the minister for making available departmental staff to brief the opposition on provisions within this bill earlier this week. It is interesting to note that this is the third reform to South-East Queensland water in four years. Firstly there was the Water Amendment Bill in 2006, which established the Water Commission. Then there was the Water and Other Legislation Amendment Bill and South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Bill in 2007, which gave the government the ability to purchase and control water assets.

The main purpose of this new bill before the House is to return the retail and distribution aspect of water to three council controlled entities. It would appear that the Bligh government was incapable of managing the water grid, with its complex systems and layer upon layer of bureaucracy established by the Beattie government. This bill’s main purpose will be effected by the creation of an act to further restructure the water industry in South-East Queensland and to make amendments to the following acts: the South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Act of 2007, the Statutory Bodies Financial Arrangements Regulation 2007, the Land Act 1994, the Local Government (Aboriginal Lands) Act 1978, the Valuation of Land Act 1994, the Water Act 2000 and the Water Supply (Safety and Responsibility) Act 2008.

The bill before us enables the establishment of three council owned distributor-retailer entities which will take over the provision of water and waste services from council. Notably, these assets will continue to be owned by council, but the functions of the assets will be transferred from individual councils to the three new entities along with the required staff members, and the number of entities will be reduced from 21 to seven. However, this is only the first bill in a two-step process. The second step will contain provisions for these new entities to become operational, and there is no mention of when a further bill to make these entities operational will occur. All three entities will be in place by 1 July 2010.

Once established, these entities will be known as water business 1, 2 and 3. Separately, these legal entities will be responsible for water delivery, waste water transport and treatment, recycled water treatment and supply, operations and maintenance, new infrastructure and retail services including billing and customer service. Water business 1, which covers Brisbane, Ipswich, Lockyer Valley, Somerset and Scenic Rim, will be owned by five council shareholders. Water business 2 will be owned by two council shareholders, being Sunshine Coast Regional Council and Moreton Bay Regional Council. Water business 3 will be owned by three council shareholders, being Gold Coast City Council, Logan City Council and Redland City Council. This business will service a population of some 850,000 people and an area of approximately 2,800 square kilometres and will have $4 billion in assets.

Originally the government was looking at only one entity to oversee all of these areas. However, after much lobbying by the mayors of the Sunshine Coast and Moreton Bay, three entities were agreed upon. The mayors’ argument--and rightly so--was that one entity was unfair as it did not distribute the cost of the growth in South-East Queensland equitably and put the cost of water supply and sewerage growth in the western corridor onto Moreton and Sunshine Coast residents. It is a bit of rich of the minister to say in his second reading speech that he had challenged the mayors when it was they who led the charge.

Queensland councils were, without doubt, short-changed when the Beattie government bought their water assets for peanuts and the Water Commission was established. After much debate and lobbying from councils, the government has decided to give back control of these assets through the creation of these water entities. Queenslanders have suffered through increased water bills because of this Labor government’s ill thought through decision to buy the water assets in the first place.

Firstly, the government established the Water Commission and set up the South-East Queensland water grid. Next, it purchased water assets from the councils for a measly amount of money and water rates rose. The water grid is in chaos, the Tugun desalination plant has serious defects and here we have another piece of legislation to reform our water structure yet again. Let us hope this is more successful than those that have come before it.

Further water price increases are guaranteed as the three new entities will issue separate bills independent of their rate levies. It is my understanding that the bulk water rate will be set by government and all three entities will share in the cost of the water grid, including the Tugun desalination plant. It will be up to the individual councils to set how much they charge ratepayers for the use of water. The Queensland Water Commission has released figures of expected rises but qualifies this by stating that retail figures will be controlled by councils and, in doing so, absolves itself of any responsibility for a high cost to the consumer.

In what is becoming repetitive and predictable behaviour by this Labor government, it has brought in legislation that, more often than not, places a heavy financial impost on local councils--those that are left, that is, after the shameful forced amalgamations across regional Queensland. We can therefore presume, just as was the case with the soaring electricity bills, that the price increase for water will be much greater than the government is letting on. Who can forget Premier Beattie’s deceitful announcement that electricity costs would not rise with privatisation and could be even cheaper? It is so easy for Labor leaders to make promises that they have no intention of keeping, so long as they get their face on the six o’clock news.

Notably, Gold Coast bulk water prices per megalitre increased by $270 in 2008-09 and are predicted to increase by $256 in 2009-10 and by another $243 in 2010-11. This equates to an increase of $769 in a three-year period since the state government took over the water grid--and that does not include inflation. The expected retail bill increases for the Gold Coast are based on an average price which also excludes inflation and the fact that the new entities can set their own costs. These are projected to increase from $503 in the 2007-08 year to $807 in 2012-13, a jump of around 60 per cent. This, I imagine, would be the minimum increase that the people of Queensland can expect. Residents are the losers here while the Labor government attempts to cover its incompetence by shuffling our water supply from one entity to another.

Due to the costly exercise of investigating the debacle at the North Pine water treatment facility, where there was an overdose of fluoride, the government is amending the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act 2008 to enable it to recover costs. This will result in water service providers or recycled water entities who are investigated having to pay the cost of such an investigation--and so they should. However, this does not erase the fact that the government was responsible in the first place. Cost recovery provisions in the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act will enable the government to recoup money spent due to these investigations. This is to ensure that water quality maintains a certain standard and any deviation from this can be readily identified and rectified without further cost to the government.

According to the explanatory notes, the policy objectives of this bill are to deliver significant benefits to the community including improved South-East Queensland regional focus in water security planning and service delivery, enhanced customer interface and clearer accountability in customer service delivery.

The Tugun desalination plant is a key component of the water grid, and I spoke about this project in November 2007 when debating earlier legislation. The state government took over this project from the Gold Coast City Council in 2006 promising to build a plant more than twice the size of the council’s model in a two-year time frame. This announcement was made within two months of a state budget that allocated just over $100 million for investigation, yet $1.2 billion was committed only months later. The rest, as they say, is history.

It would appear that the unrealistic construction period demanded by the Beattie and Bligh governments has seen problem after problem, defect after defect, excuse after excuse and disruption after disruption. This two-year project is now well into its third year and it is not expected to be commissioned until mid-2010. As I said, this is a key part of the water grid. There have been faulty water pipes and water valves with signs of corrosion, pipes have caused roads in Tugun to literally pop out of the ground, numerous houses have suffered damage and the Tugun football club is sinking. All of this has hindered the opening of the facility. WaterSecure, the government’s own entity, handed its report to the Bligh government in July of this year highlighting major problems with the desalination plant. However, it did not include damages caused to residents’ homes or to the Tugun football club.

We have heard every excuse imaginable from king tides, faulty valves, electrical problems, dry weather--and still the plant is not operating properly. During budget estimates this year, the Minister for Infrastructure had the hide to claim that the plant was finished and functioning properly. Now we learn that the monitoring of water quality of our ocean around the outlet pipe has been stopped due to budgetary concerns. The monitoring included photographs of various marine life, documented sites of marine species and water sampling, which revealed a lack of flathead and whiting around the outlet structure when the plant was undergoing trial operations. Environmental concerns about brine output from the plant into the local marine habitat existed from day one of this project, and recent reports from local fishermen indicated that close monitoring is required. It is to be hoped that the relevant minister will take some notice of this issue.

Of even greater concern is what we are drinking from our taps in suburbs throughout the electorate of Currumbin. Supposedly, desalinated water is going into our drinking water in South-East Queensland, yet just how much has never been disclosed by the Bligh government. When my office contacted WaterSecure, a spokesperson who manages the facility could not even provide my staff with information on the capacity that the plant is running at or what percentage of desalinated water is being mixed with the normal water. I ask the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy whether even he knows what is in our pipes.

My office is receiving calls from people who are concerned about the water quality coming from the desalination plant and the fact that it is causing dry and irritated skin. How do we know what is in the pipes that bring water into our homes and what recourse do they have for resulting skin problems? Will these concerns be investigated? I would ask the minister: who will pay for these investigations and who will pay if there are serious concerns affecting people? When the plant is fully commissioned it is expected to produce 125 megalitres of desalinated water per day. But when this will occur, as is so much the mantra of this government, is anyone’s guess.
